column2: Rails, oils, papers and metals were under pressure on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and the market staged a fairly general retreat, with more than half the issues traded losing ground. Sales fell to 1,500,000 shares from 1,630,250 on Friday.

LONDON, June 25--Early steadiness of the pound sterling helped Government funds stage a technical rally in the stock markets today. Further gains in industrial shares were cut back toward the close on Wall Street's weaker opening.
WASHINGTON, June 25--The Justice Department, which is often accused of hiding information from Congress, turned on its tormenters today.

WHEN one has lived in the shadow of the bear's den for 130, years, one gets to know the habits of the bear pretty well. One-gets to know when it is safe to enter the den and when one had better stay far away.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 25-- Justice Bernard Vidal Shaw, who sentenced six Greek Cypriote terrorists to death, was shot and seriously wounded this afternoon.
MOSCOW, June 25--Three new Soviet aircraft were shown to foreign observers today by the Soviet Government.
The late Alben W. Barkley once defined a bureaucrat as "a Democrat who holds a job that some Republican wants."

The statement of principles agreed on by the presidents of seven leading universities to guide their relationships with the corporate donors of funds is a sound answer to a felt need. The corporate gift has been steadily increasing in importance as a source of support. Noting this as "most encouraging," the presidents ...
Abe Stark, president of the City Council, urged both business and government last night to create greater opportunities for Negroes in white collar jobs.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings at Carlton House for the concert to be held on Oct. 2 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the Committee to Save Carnegie Hall and the National Association for Retarded Children.
KANSAS CITY, June 25-- Norm Siebern hit two homers, Hank Bauer and Joe Collins slugged one apiece and the Yankees snapped their fourgame losing streak with a 9-3 victory over the Athletics tonight.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 25--Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King died of a heart ailment at the Naval Hospital here this afternoon. He was 77 years old.

Plans for an integrated bus depot, shopping center and office building were announced yesterday. The project, still in the preliminary stage, would be on the west side of Eighth Avenue from Forty-first to Forty-second Streets, directly north of the Port of New York Authority's union bus terminal.

LOS ANGELES, June 25--A note of cautious optimism about the future of leasing in the nation's major office buildings was sounded by speakers at the opening session of the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers here today.

The Communist-infiltrated regime in Guatemala fell two years ago; on July 2, 1954, in the Presidential palace at San Salvador, a truce was signed setting up an anti-Communist junta of five. As expected, this soon gave way to the Presidency of Carlos Castillo Armas, who had led the revolt with the strong moral backing of the United States.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn upheld yesterday the right of the New York City Transit Authority to discharge an employe because he had invoked the Fifth Amendment when asked whether he was a member of the Communist party.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 25 --Jackson S. Hutto, managing director of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York and a former New York State Superintendent of Banks, died here last night in his home at 12 Uxbridge Road. His age was 51.

TOKYO, June 25--A marked increase in Communist infiltration has been noted in South Korea in recent weeks. The hope obviously is to take advantage of the political division there indicated by the election of May 15 when President Rhee's Government suffered a setback.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (UP)--The Milwaukee Braves, tied in the eighth inning on Willie Jones' three-run homer, came up with three runs in the ninth tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8--5, and run their winning streak under Fred Haney to eleven games.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 24--The ghost of a man dead nearly four years continues to haunt the leadership of the Czechoslovak Communist party.
ROME, June 25--Palmiro Togliatti, Secretary General of the Italian Communist party, has urged Soviet leaders to furnish "guarantees" against a repetition of Stalin's "errors."

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 25--Eddie Moylan of Trenton, scored two victories today as he opened defense of his men's singles tennis title in the twentyninth annual Eastern clay courts championships. He defeated George Gondelman of Great Neck, L.I., 6--4, 6--1, and Dick Walsh of Hackensack, 6--2, 6--4.

The United Nations Security Council is scheduled to take up this morning a thirteen-nation AsianAfrican resolution to "consider the grave situation in Algeria." The driving forces behind this proposal are the Arab nations of the Middle East, who say that conditions in Algeria are a "threat to peace and ...
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 25--Mrs. Leon Weil of Inwood won the qualifying medal in the Women's Long Island Golf Association twenty-sixth annual match-play championship at the Creek Club today.

JERSEY CITY, June 25-- Why do they boo the Dodgers in Jersey City? In their home park, Ebbets Field in Brooklyn, Dodger devotees faithfully cheer each of their heroes when the starting lineups are announced. And they carefully boo each opposing player as his name is called.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- Whether any President, in whatever state of health, can fully meet the responsibilities of a job which Harry S. Truman, who is only one man, today told the British was a "sixman" labor, is a question General ...
THE "Producers' Showcase" had an off-night on Chan nel 4 last evening. Its revival of "Happy Birthday," with Betty Field in the part created on Broadway by Helen Hayes, was very tepid theatre.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 25-- Without challenge, the state presented evidence today that Justice of the Peace Rudolph M. Kammerer of Westhampton Beach had both given and sought favors for traffic offenders.
A twenty-story office building is to be built on the southwest corner of Forty-first Street and Third Avenue.
A memoral to Nikola Tesla, leading inventor in the field of electricity forty years before his death in 1943, was unveiled here yesterday. The centennial of his birth will be on July 9.
CAIRO, June 25--As his first act as new President of Egypt, Gamal Abdel Nasser received the resignations today of all Cabinet ministers who had served under his Premiership.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP)--Clint Courtney's two-run pinch homer in the eighth enabled the Washington Nationals to post a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers today. The defeat was the ninth straight for the Tigers.
WASHINGTON, June 25--The first treaty to prevent double taxation between this country and any of the Latin-American republics was signed today with Honduras.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India agreed today to postpone Mr. Nehru's scheduled visit to the United States early next month.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25-- A Jewish spiritual leader called on his organization tonight to assume the iniative in convening a meeting of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish religious groups to deal with desegregation.

In 1835 George Eden, the second Lord Auckland, was appointed Governor General of India. To his new post he brought his two sisters Emily and Fanny and his nephew William. An account of how the four members of the family reacted to five years in...
WASHINGTON, June 25-- The Senate agreed today to vote tomorrow on a Democratic proposal that would give the Eisenhower Administration a heavy, unwanted increase in funds for the Air Force.

I have been much gratified to learn of the continuing progress of your recovery from your recent illness, but feel that the program of our personal talks should not impose an additional strain on you during your convalescence.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 25-- In 1922, when the American Woolen Company was one of the giants of the textile industry, a pygmy concern, the American Appliance Company, was founded to manufacture radio tubes.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., June 25 --Lou Barbaro shot a threeunder-par 35, 33--68 today at the Hendricks Field course to win the qualifying medal in the State Professional Golfers Association championships.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)-- President Eisenhower expressed regrets today at the death of Admiral King, his former comrade-in-arms.
WASHINGTON, June 25--The United States Information Agency was accused in the Senate today of handling this country's information program with "timidity, hesitancy and cowardice."

DETROIT, June 25 (AP)--Things are beginning to look brighter for the nation's auto makers. Dealer inventories are declining and production is holding steady, although at a seasonally low level. No further major labor layoffs are indicated until the switch-over to 1957 models several months from now.
LONDON, June 25 (AP)--Reinhold Moritzovitch Gliere, noted Russian composer, has died at the age of 81, the Moscow radio said tonight.

THE triumphant survival of the written word owes a lot to the foolishness of radio broadcasting, television and the elephantiastic cinema. It is, therefore, a shade disquieting to have Gilbert Seldes once again telling the clamorous new masters of electronics how they should improve their...
The Republican National Committee will spend $7,000,000 on its 1956 political campaign, its chairman, Leonard W. Hall, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) --The Department of Commerce said today that record exports of goods and services in the first quarter of 1956 were "an important element in supporting the high rate of domestic business activity" during that period.
A new motor called the Inchworm developed by the Airborne Instruments Laboratory of Mineola, L.I., promises to have an important application in the metal-working industries.

A "substantial" amount of relief from aircraft noise has been provided to the metropolitan area during the past few years, a report made yesterday asserted. But, in spite of an intense program against noise disturbance, there still exists a "substantial" objection to operations at the area's three major air terminals, the report said.
State Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco is expected to sign today an order to imprison Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, independent.
THE establishment of Bergdorf Goodman opened a gripe bag last night and let the wrath of 1,500 frustrated shoppers pour out in public.

Economic development should not mean disrupting old cultures, uprooting people or throwing away the best heritage of past centuries, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, said yesterday.
First National Stores, Inc. sales are running ahead of those in the second quarter of last year according to Adrian O'Keeffe, president of the grocery chain.
LONDON, June 25--Johannes G. Strijdom, Prime Minister of South Africa, denied tonight that his country was "drifting into a policy of isolation toward the rest of the world."

"Four wheels, connected by a frame and body and driven by an internal combustion engine has been an ambition of nearly all Canadians." With these words the Bank of Montreal reports on the startling increase in car ownership in the Dominion.
MOSCOW, June 25--The Shah of Iran received an impressive welcome from the Soviet Government today and an equally impressive greeting from curious Moscow crowds.

IT was a dangerous precedent that the Olympic officials established by arbitrarily qualifying Dave Sime for the 200-meter sprint and Bud Held for the javelin throw at the final Olympic tryouts this week-end in Los Angeles. Neither had been able to advance in those events during any of the three preliminary meets, although injury was a factor with each of these top performers.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- Government officials said today that the United States would withdraw its forces if Iceland's elections resulted in a Government favoring withdrawal.

RABAT, Morocco, June 25-- The financial problems of independent Morocco were illustrated by the disclosure today that provisory credits amounting to nearly 21,000,000,000 francs (about $59,000,000 had been established for government expenses for June and July.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 25-- Channing R. Docley, an expert on industrial training and president of the Training Within Industry Foundation, died today of a heart attack in Overlook Hospital. His age was 78. He lived at 41 Oakland Place.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 25-- A New England campaign to win the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination for Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts was started at the annual Governors conference today.

History must reserve a place for Ernest Joseph King. An Ohio railway machinist's son who never saw blue water until he was appointed to Annapolis, Fleet Admiral King commanded in the world's greatest war the mightiest navy ever assembled under one flag and commanded ...

PITTSBURGH, June 25-- Thomas E. Dewey, former Governor of New York, today made his first major courtroom appearance in fourteen years. He argued against the constitutionality of a Federal law that seeks $525,000,000 in taxes from the nation's whisky distillers.

The city of Jacksonville, Fla., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $14,000,000 in the public market on July 24 to finance public utility construction. The city will put out an issue of electric revenue certificates maturing serially on July 1 from 1958 to 1976.

The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries, manufacturers of automotive parts, in the nine months ended May 31 realized a 41.2 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 35 per cent over the totals a year earlier.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Manhattan Democrat, said yesterday that twenty-five students and six faculty mem bers had been told that they could not return next fall to the South Carolina State College for Negroes.
The old Hamburg-American Line passenger vessel Hamburg, remembered by thousands of preWorld War II tourists, is about to embark on a new and less glamorous career.

A 26-year-old paroled convict escaped early yesterday morning from the cell block of the Flushing police station in Queens. He was being held for arraignment on charges of firing a pistol through the windows of homes in the Whitestone section.
The personal background of Maj. Gen. Robert E. Condon, Director of Civil Defense, is being investigated by the office of City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 25-- Gov. A.B. (Happy) Chandler of Kentucky boomed himself for the Democratic Presidential or Vice Presidential nomination today with an outpouring of wisecracks.

With Father's Day barely out of the way, and father still in need of shirts and shoes and possibly even a baseball glove to play catch with son, the Father's Day Council is making elaborate plans for a new and enlarged expansion program for next year.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25 (UP)--Dance Me Loose broke into the victory column for the first time this season tonight at Roosevelt Raceway when he scored a length victory in the $4,000 Wildwood Pace. The time for the Grand Circuit event was 2:04.
HONG KONG, June 25--The Chinese Communist Parliament was told today that "persuasion" would replace harsher methods in the class struggle.

NEWARK, June 25--Sidney Sarner of Ridgefield, Conn., dismissed his attorney today and pleaded his own cause in a contempt hearing in Federal Court here. Mr. Sarner, a real estate developer, is being sued by the Federal Housing Administration for the recovery of $2,426,821 in alleged windfall profits made in a housing development in Fort Lee.

LISBON, Portugal, June 25-- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar was reported today to be planning reforms designed to replace eventually Portugal's authoritarian government with collective political leadership.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 25 --Top honors in the thirtyseventh annual tournament of the Father and Son Golf Association today went to Dr. Robert Millen of Piping Rock and his son, R. Woodward Millen.
The Transport Workers Union asked yesterday for relaxation of the medical requirements for operating personnel of the city transit system.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 25--Funds from an all-day oldtime country auction with which this resort community will open its 1956 summer season on Saturday will be used to restore the Widow's Walk on Sea Captain Rogers' homestead, now the main building of the Southampton Historical Museum.

WASHINGTON, June 2-- Representative William L. Dawson wrote President Eisenhower today that the President had "dissipated any possible claim of privilege" by giving a newspaper reporter access to executive papers denied to Congress.
Twelve hundred organists descended upon New York yesterday and pored through a dozen leading churches to begin their inspection of the unusually fine collection of organs housed in this city.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25-- President Eisenhower was called upon today to use his powers of persuasion to implement the Supreme Court's decision outlawing racial segregation in public schools.

WASHINGTON, June 25--The public wrangle on Capitol Hill today over raising the Air Force budget by $500,000,000 to $1,000,000,000 is merely a reflection of the much more bither fight that is going on behind the scenes in the Pentagon over the defense strategy and missions of the Army, Navy and Air Force.
The role of labor in state and national policies was a recurrent theme yesterday at the opening of the ninety-third annual convention of the State Federation of Labor.
The Carnegie Corporation announced yesterday a grant of $277,000 to the university of Illinois to explore reforms in the teaching of mathematics in high schools.
WASHINGTON, June 28--A single big Federal dam for Hell's Canyon, long-lived Democratic symbol of the public vs. private power issue, won approval today from the House Interior Committee.

LOS ANGELES, June 26-- The growing importance of the module, or building block idea, in office building design was described today as one of the basic tools in the rapidly changing art of tailoring new structures to the complex requirements of tenants.
The nation's railroads are taking a hard look at their multimillion-dollar promotional effort --specifically the Association of American Railroads--and they don't like what they see.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 26-- Republican Governors of twenty states today urged President Eisenhower to seek renomination.

A 22-year-old vagrant who tried to escape from the Harts Island workhouse was questioned by police early this morning after he had told his captors that he knew who had hurled acid at Victor Riesel last April and blinded him.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 26--Yugoslavia and Rumania signed agreements today for close relations between their Governments and their Communist parties. In the Yugoslav view the effect of the declarations will be to help Rumania move toward independence from Soviet domination.
WASHINGTON, June 26--Two Senators attacked the Supreme Court today as "pro-Communist," "insolent," "willful" and "irresponsible."

SUNNINGDALE, England, June 26 (UP)--Pat Lesser and Barbara Romack, the 1955 and 1954 United States amateur champions, respectively, led seven Americans into the third round of the British women's amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- Crude oil imports to East Coast ports must be cut by 4 per cent in the coming quarter, importing companies were told today by Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 26--Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley eliminated the defending champion, Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood, in the first round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's twentysixth annual match-play tournament today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 --Metro Goldwyn-Mayer today cast the lead roles in two of its forthcoming pictures. Leslie Nielsen will play an unemployed newspaper man in "Capital Offense," which Morton Fine and David Friedkin will direct and produce for M-G-M release.

Lester T. Doyle, trustee in reorganization of the Third Avenue Transit System, announced last night that he was withdrawing his plan for reorganization of the bankrupt line in favor of an improved proposal from the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

Floral decorations of white gladioluses, peonies, stock and red roses provided the background in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sara Sue Lewis to J. Samuel Rugg of Santa Barbara, Calif.

Indications interpreted to mean that a major steel strike might still be averted gave the stock market a higher close yesterday. Steels took the lead in the afternoon, Bethlehem Steel rising 3 , Youngstown Sheet ...

A funeral service will be held today at 2 P.M. in Miller Chapel of Princeton Theological Seminary for Mrs. Florence Day Stevenson, widow of the Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, for many years president of the seminary in Princeton, N. J.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nat Lefkowitz of 91 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Beth Lefkowitz, to Burton Lawrence Litwin. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Litwin of 123 West Ninetythird Street.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 28 (AP) --King Hussein dismissed Jordan's Parliament tonight at the request of Premier Said Mufti.
Thousands of motorists had to detour from Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive yesterday when a flood of heavy fuel oil poured across the highway at East Seventy-first Street behind New York Hospital.
WASHINGTON, June 26-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India told President Eisenhower today he thought the President's decision to cancel their early July meeting had been a "wise one."
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 27--President Syngman Rhee today demanded that the Korean armistice be dissolved.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) yesterday completed a 15-year, 4 per cent loan of $75,000,000 to the Tata Iron and Steel Company, Ltd., of India. The funds, in various currencies, are intended to help the ...
One of the most active golfing families in Westchester is the Kuntz clan of the Bonnie Briar Country Club, Larchmont, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, June 26-- Experts on Soviet affairs are inclined to agree that Nikita S. Khrushchev's anti-Stalin crusade has got out of hand.

WASHINGTON, June 26-- Senator Herbert H. Lehman received apologies today from the Department of Defense and "personal regret" from Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, for the search of his office by two security agents.
GENEVA, June 26--The head of the International Labor Organization said today that the process of economic development in the world must be accelerated, but in conditions of freedom.

LONDON, June 26--The fall in sterling value against the dollar helped restrain expansion of business in the stock markets today. The pound fell below $2.80 for the first time since November, closing 3/16 cents lower at $2.79 15/16.

LONDON, June 26--The British Government will cut expenditures of 76,000,000 ($212,800,000) this year, Chancellor of the Exchequer Harold Macmillan announced today. More than half of the sum will be squeezed out of defense.
The marriage of Miss Nancy Moses to Semon Wolf 2d took place last night in the Pierre Roof. The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark performed the ceremony.
The Broadway Association has moved for a city investigation of panhandling, particularly in the Times Square area.

The Army Corps of Engineers began yesterday to remove a sunken barge that blocks the main ship channel to the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn and forces Staten Island ferryboats off the normal route to St. George.
LIMA, Peru, June 26--Five Constitutional guarantees and civil liberties were suspended in Peru tonight for thirty days in the wake of all-day rioting here.
LOS ANGELES, June 26-- Los Angeles Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, today became a permanent threat to James C. Petrillo's seventeenyear leadership of the national union.
Packaged merchandise is helping to pare department store delivery costs by encouraging shoppers to carry purchases themselves, a merchandising consultant said yesterday.
Automobile liability insurance rates generally will rise today, adding $18,000,000 to the cost of private car coverage in the state.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 26 --Political experts foresaw today an unstable Iceland government and growing political unrest made to order for Communist exploitation.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 26--The Government announced today a number of measures to impress Communist ideology on Czechoslovak universities.
Plans for the erection of a statue of the late George M. Cohan on the street he loved most and celebrated in song were announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26-- A many-sided offensive against racial segregation and communism was recommended tonight to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

Almost a year ago the Senate passed a bill, by voice vote, designed to remedy a serious inequity in the Federal Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act. The present late follows the widely accepted pattern of most states in providing that those covered by it shall ...

KANSAS CITY, June 26-- Lou Boudreaus "Mickey Mantle shift" partially stopped the man against whom it was devised, but there was no stopping the Yankees tonight. The American League leaders, keeping pace with their closest pursuers, retained their game-and-a-half ...
Miss Clara F. Porter, one of New York's first bond saleswomen, died Monday in St. Barnabas Hospital, 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx. She had been a patient at the hospital for several years.

BUENOS AIRES, June 26-- Early this morning a bomb exploded in front of the house of Navy Capt, Francisco Poch. It shattered windows in the densely populated Belgrano section and alarmed dozens of neighboring families but there were no casualties.
LONDON, June 26 (Reuters) --Gamal Abdel Nasser, newly elected President of Egypt, declared today he had no intention of making himself "supreme over all the countries of the Arab world."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26-- Lebanese leaders failed today to make the Soviet Foreign Minister declare himself definitely in favor of the Arab countries in the Palestine question.

WASHINGTON, June 28-- Today's White House target for Congressional investigators is a chunky, darkhaired, young-looking man whose nervous energy has led one observer to compare him to "a high school valedictorian--just full of beans."

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) --The Eisenhower Administration's proposed customs simplification law came under attack today before the Senate Finance Committee as a "vicious" effort "to destroy (tariff) protection of American industry and labor."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 --Four television directors, Vincent Donehue, John Frankenheimer, Ralph Nelson and Arthur Penn, have been signed to direct the live productions scheduled for the Columbia Broadcasting System's weekly ninety-minute series, "Playhouse 90," when it begins in the fall.
Phillips Russell, author of "Benjamin Franklin, the First Civilized American," and of "Emerson, the Wisest American," has written a new book about Thomas Jefferson.

A WEEK ago today sandhogs holed through the last segment separating men on the New Jersey side of the third Lincoln Tunnel tube from men on the Manhattan side. The first thing that came through the opening was a gob of silt with hay salt binder.
The Chinese community of New York yesterday greeted Dr. Hollington T. Kong, recently appointed by the Chinese Nationalist Republic as its Ambassador to the United States.

Miss Jane Edmunds Bird was married to George Maitland Nissen of Church Farm, Dry Sandford, Abingdon, England, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 26-- Concern over asserted widespread efforts to impair the principle of separation of church and state was voiced here today by the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

Establishment of a committee of fifty-five business and professional leaders to cooperate with government officials in the redevelopment of lower Manhattan is good news. It enlists the civic interest of some of our most substantial and successful citizens.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) --A Congressional investigation was ordered today to determine why private power companies spent more than $100,000 to paint an allegedly "erroneous" and optimistic picture of atomic power development.
James R. Hoffa, powerful Midwest teamster leader, testified yesterday for ninety minutes before the special Federal grand jury investigating racketeering in the trucking and garment industries.
GUATEMALA, June 26--The Government today imposed a full state of siege in all Guatemala for thirty days.

The Bureau of Labors Statistics has just reported that as of midMay the consumer price index (our closest approximation to an index of the cost of living) had reached 115.4 per cent of its average for the base period, 1947-49, thereby equaling the all-time peak made in October, 1953. The rise since April 15, ...
PHILADELPHIA, June 26-- Paul H. Dike, author and retired research consultant, died yesterday in Abington Memorial Hospital here. He was 78 years old and lived in near-by Huntingdon Valley.

LINDAU, Germany, June 26 (Reuters)--Two of the world's leading nuclear scientists said today they were not satisfied with theories that are the keystone of modern atomic thought. Science must seek a new explanation for the fine points of the atom's structure, they added.

The American woman--from the toddler who loses her shoes at the beach to the mediumgrown-up who has dresses aplenty but "nothing to wear" --is the target for all advertising and product innovation, the Advertising Association of the West was told yesterday.

HIGHLAND PARK; Ill., June 26--Ravinia began its twentyfirst music festival tonight with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra as its instrument. Eugene Ormandy was guest conductor. The soloist, Marian Anderson, received a glowing welcome from the audience of more than 4,000 persons.
LISBON, Portugal, June 26-- Portuguese political leaders have proposed reforms for Portugal's political, social, economic and cultural structure.

Dr. William Sohier Bryant of 30 East Fortieth Street, a leading ear specialist in this city for many years, died yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., where he had gone to visit relatives. He had observed his ninety-fifth birth day on May 15.

WENTWORTH, England, June 26 (UP)--Ben Hogan, finishing more than ten hours' of play on weary legs, exhibited some of the greatest clutch golf of his career today and won the Canada Cup championship by 5 strokes with a final round of 32, 36--68.
AMES, Iowa, June 26--The country's technical colleges were reported today to have lowered their standards and thus contributed to the growing shortage of qualified engineers.
The regimental colors of a New York military unit dating back to George Washington's day were on their way yesterday to the first President's ancestral home in England.

SOMETIMES it seems as if historical events and historical knowledge were moving steadily backward like telephone poles seen from a train window. In one man's lifetime events that shook the world in his youth shrink and grow dim and become the subjects of scholarly investigation. And at the other end of history the remote beginnings of man's ...
PARIS, June 26--Premier Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia indicated today that he would not sign a treaty of alliance with France so long as the "Algerian war" continued.

A taxpayer building on plot 200 by 100 feet at 23-01 to 23-25 Twenty-first Avenue, Astoria, Queens, has been sold by Harold I. Litwin to the Irvmax Realty Corporation, which resold it to an estate for investment. L. J.
The acquisition of television rights to "Green Pastures" and "Three Men on a Horse" by the Columbia Broadcasting System was reported here yesterday.

GALVESTON, June 26 (AP)-- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias; forty pounds lighter then when she started her long battle against cancer in 1953, today said her forty-second birthday was "the finest I've ever had or hope go have."
Charges were made yesterday by Alexander H. Cohen and Ralph Alswang, producers of "The Brass Section," that Hal March had "breached" his contract to star in Max Wilk's ...
WASHINGTON, June 26-- Congress sent to the White House today a record $33,480,000,000 road-building bill carrying "pay-as-you-ride" tax provisions.
EVEN the bridal designers are going along with the Second Decade influence in fashion, making late summer and fall brides a regal procession of Fair Ladies.
WASHINGTON, June 26--The Federal Communications Commission announced today it was considering a shift of all or a major portion of the nation's television operations to ultrahigh frequency channels.

LONDON, June 26 (Reuters) --Joe Bygraves of Jamaica won the vacant British Empire heavy-weight title tonight by gaining a fifteen-round decision over Kitione Lave, the Tongan Terror from the Friendly Islands.
Labor was told by one of its leaders yesterday that it had lain down on the job of pressing for its legislative objectives at Albany.
WASHINGTON, June 26--The Senate added $960,000,000 to the Air Force budget today over the objection of the Eisenhower Administration, The vote was 48 to 40.

When baseball men sit down to a session of serious windjamming, two questions invariably pop up for discussion: What is the difference, if any, between the major leagues? How big is the gap between the majors and the minors?

Boris Vermont of 1225 Park Avenue, chief of the Foreign Versions Department of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. His age was 52.
The proposed institution of lower trans-Atlantic air fares is being watched with keen interest and without concern by passenger shipping officials.
Any motorist interested in saving lives--including his own--would do well to take advantage of the safedriving clinic being conducted this week at the Motor Vehicle Bureau office at 155 Worth Street.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation put a price tag yesterday on backing state development of Niagara River power. It asked for a fixed share of production for the full term of the license the state gets.

TORONTO, June 26 (Canadian Press)--Some hope was held out today that the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company might be relieved of one of its big money losers--the Rio de Janeiro Street Railway System. Henry Borden, president, ...
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26--The Security Council declined today to debate the situation in strife-torn Algeria.

WASHINGTON, June 26-- Senate investigators demanded indignantly today that the White House tell them how a newspaper reporter got access to secret Government documents he used to write the "inside story" of the Eisenhower Administration.
An indepedent transit union threatened yesterday to strike the subways. But the action was contingent upon the Transit Authority's granting a union shop to the Transport Workers Union.
OMAHA, Neb., June 26--The General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches called on churchgoers here today to "support non-segregated practices in selling, buying and leasing property."

WASHINGTON, June 26--The Commissioners of the District of Columbia agreed today to recommend that an investment group including O. Roy Chalk, president of Trans Caribbean Airways, Inc., be permitted to take over the local transit system.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26--The ten American girls in the all-England tennis championships marched to straight-set triumphs today before 23,000 persons, including the former President, Harry Truman, and Mrs. Truman.

When the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth assemble in London at 10 Downing Street this morning they will be holding their seventh such meeting since the war. No other conference is ever quite like these. This gathering will bring together political leaders from various parts of the world. They meet not to dispute but to discuss.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 26-- Two Southern Governors stated today their opposition to Governor Harriman for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
RABAT, Morocco, June 26-- France has raised by nearly onethird the ceiling on the number of United States Air Force troops in Morocco.

ROME, June 26--The summer season of opera at the Baths of Caracalla opened spectacularly tonight with a performance of Gioacchino Rossini's seldom played "Mose." Roman society and innumerable distinguished foreigners, including Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands, made it a gala evening.

The suggestion voiced recently by spokesmen for a number of New Jersey and Connecticut communities that New York State raise to 21 the legal age at which young people may buy alcoholic beverages has already won some influential support.
HEARINGS in Congress are bringing into focus the question whether state game laws should not be enforced by state game wardens on Federal military reservations.
WASHINGTON, June 26--A move to deprive the President of the iniative in imposing quotas on cotton textiles is under way in a combination of southern and New England Senators.
The break in prices of coffee futures yesterday may not result in a break for coffee drinkers.
Confronted by a manager audacious enough to start another left-hander against his Dodgers, Manager Walter Alston did some surprising things with his lineup at Ebbets Field last night.

DETROIT, June 26 (AP)--The Studebaker-Packard Corporation disclosed today that it had completed its run of the 1956 model Packard and Clipper models and had laid off, indefinitely, 3,200 workers in its Detroit plants.

We the voting members of the l956 General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches, reaffirm the actions taken by five previous General Councils in pledging ourselves to work for a nonsegregated church in a nonsegregated society.
ALGIERS, Algeria, June 26-- Actions reported by the French command since yesterday morn ing appeared to have cost the rebels about sixty dead.

An order requiring high school students to attend classes this week, which is generally considered a free period following Regents examinations, was rescinded Monday. Thus, an old tradition still stands.

Aqueduct has been chosen as the locale for this city's "bright new world" of thoroughbred racing, it was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Association, Inc. The association promotes racing in this state on a non-profit basis, under the supervision of the racing commission.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court held yesterday that the dismissal of Melvin L. Barnet, a copy editor, by The New York Times was subject to arbitration.
Prices of several commodities on the New York futures markets moved sharply yesterday. Volume was heavy.
The city should override all obstacles and seize the opportunity to build $1,000,000,000 worth of highways over the next twelve years, Robert Moses declared yesterday, Appearing before the City

The death of a longshoreman in a ship hold accident yesterday brought immediate demands for more rigid safety controls to be written into the next docker labor contract. It also diverted waterfront attention from the imminent imprisonment of the longshore union president.
A Belgian concern was disclosed yesterday to have obtained a contract believed the first under which the steel framework of an American skyscraper will be supplied from a foreign country.
The city and state Health Commissioners urged physicians yesterday to continue to inject children with Salk polio vaccine during the coming polio season.
MOSCOW, June 26--The Soviet Union proudly flexed its muscles a little more today.
The Appellate Division said yesterday that a landlord who buys a house at a price above its assessed valuation may seek a rent increase on the basis of the purchase price.

WESTBURY, L. I, June 26 (UP)--Adios Eden scored a length victory in 2:04 1/5 in the one-mile Fire Island Pace tonight on the Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway. The even-money favorite, Bobby King, was second. Excellent Chief finished third.
The bonds of four Canadian public bodies will be offered to the United States investment public today. The offerings aggregate $51,500,000.

The steel industry was reported ready last night to offer a compromise three-year peace formula if it got specific evidence from union leaders that the offer would head off a strike of 650,000 steel workers at midnight Saturday.
The Giants presented Ruben Gomez with the unaccustomed luxury of a two-run lead over the Cardinals in the first inning at the Polo Grounds last night.

TRENTON, June 26--The final alignment of the proposed $115,000,000 Bergen-Passaic Expressway was announced here today by Dwight R.G. Palmer State Highway Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, June 26--The Government reported today the biggest spurt in the United States Consumer Price Index in three years.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 26--The next commander of NATO's armed forces, General Norstad, never planned a military career. Like his predecessor, Gruenther, he thought seriously of civilian life. Gruenther almost resigned his commission to enter Harvard Business School, Norstad wanted to be a lawyer.
A new "super alloy" that functions at temperatures up to 1,200 degrees was announced yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's research laboratories.

Robert Moses disclosed yesterday that another acre of Central Park was to be converted from greenery to parking lot. The newest inroad into park land will provide space for about 110 cars and school buses to serve visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
THE exhibition of prints by Henri Matisse opening to day at the Museum of Modern Art is the most extensive ever held in New York. It will be on view until Oct. 7.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 26 (AP) --Indiana's Democratic convention turned down tonight national Chairman Paul M. Butler's choice for Governor. But the South Bend party leader survived a bitter fight for power in his home state.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad which was discharged from bankruptcy last spring, had a net income of $1,914,801, or $1 a share on its class A stock, in the first five months this year. The road's May income statement ...
New York was virtually sure of victory yesterday in its uphill fight to remain the nation's engineering center.

Manufacturers of lamp and lighting fixtures as well as bulb producers, are brightening their sales with new and improved products. Lighting innovations--both inside and out side the home--in recent years have sparked a jump in lamp and lighting fixture volume from about $319,700,000 in 1947 to some $550,000,000 last year.
A new block of $89,570,000 of public housing bonds representing the borrowings of thirty-five local authorities was sold yesterday to banking syndicates at public sealed bidding.
The "Kraft Television Theatre" will break into full-time color starting next week.

The results of the national election in Iceland, which produced a potential Parliamentary majority favoring withdrawal of American troops from the NATO base on the island, have aroused concern in all North Atlantic capitals.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 27--Willie Turnesa, a former United States and British amateur golf champion, teamed with Mrs. Sophie Untermyer of Century today to win the Westchester mixed foursomes golf tournament for the second year in a row.

THE concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium have been coasting along in recent years on standard orchestral selections, some big-name soloists and an increasingly large proportion of popular entertainment. It is therefore good to report that last night's program departed entirely from any of the usual Stadium for- ...
NEWARK, June 27 (AP)--New auto insurance rates for New Jersey motorists became effective today.
The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation will ask Congress today to authorize state development of Niagara River power.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities voted today to give Arthur Miller ten days to answer questions on past Communist-front associations or face a citation for contempt of Congress.
The Fire Department yesterday ordered a reorganization of fire prevention inspections of theaters, night clubs and other public places.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, yesterday announced the appointment of Dr. Levering Tyson as assistant to the president on alumni relations.
The new city subway line to the Rockaways--a breezy, openair train ride across four miles of sparkling water to the beach at a cost of only one extra token-- will be opened for business today.
LONDON, June 27--Nine Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth met today to begin their appraisal of Soviet policy.
The Transit Authority promised the Transport Workers Union yesterday to consider the latter's arguments for a union shop. The assurance was given after a one-hour closed meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 27--The House of Representatives today passed, 364 to 51, a bill to give an estimated $356,000,000 of added pensions next year to World War I veterans for disabilities not incurred in the line of military service.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 27-- The United States Supreme Court was criticized by the Conference of Governors today for decisions holding a state law void if a Federal statute dealt with the same subject.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee was urged today not to tamper with the Supreme Court decision barring security dismissals of Government employes in nonsensitive positions.

WASHINGTON, June 26--A bomber pilot of the United States Air Force told Senate investigators today that "natural stubbornness" and "a blind faith" in his country had helped him defy Communist captors for fourteen months in Korea.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 --Warner Brothers discovered today that they had never confirmed the fact that they had purchased the Broadway musical "Damn Yankees." When reports to that effect were circulating last January the studio denied them.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 27 --Miss Janet Drew was married to William Crowe Hutcheson this afternoon in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.
A state of alarm in Guatemala has been tightened to a state of siege after further incidents in which four students were killed and eighteen wounded, seventeen persons exiled and about 200 arrested.
LIMA, Peru, June 27--Calm returned to Lima today. The armed forces and the police stood poised to prevent a recurrence of the bloody rioting of the last two days.
Miss Mary Kujawska achieved a prominence yesterday among her East Side tenement neighbors that she had never had before.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 27-- The Nassau County Department of Health today announced it had issued permits allowing bathing at sixty-eight beaches and denied two applications.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 27-- The leader of the Turkish Cypriote minority warned today that Turkey might quit the Baghdad Pact and break off relations with Britain if London granted a liberal constitution to Cyprus.
A crate of bees mailed from Georgia broke open in the General Post Office at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street at noon yesterday. Postal employes scattered in all directions.
One big splash gave the Dodgers a 6-2 decision over the Cubs yesterday at Ebbets Field in a contest that was delayed for a total of 2 hours 32 minutes by two heavy rainstorms.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)-- Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, made cryptic reference today to a new secret weapon "which will revolutionize anti-submarine warfare."
DUBLIN, June 26--Councilor Robert Briscoe, the first Jewish Lord Mayor of Dublin, a city 90 per cent Roman Catholic, said tonight that he was "humble in the face of such a high honor."
A decline of 762,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
The city is considering asking the Port of New York Authority to make a study of the feasibility of building a new Washington Wholesale Market on West Side piers in the market area.
RICHMOND, Va., June 27-- The hottest topic in the cool corridors of Virginia's capitol is Gov. Thomas B. Stanley's move to tighten his control of the State Hospital Board.

A summer afternoon storm, with winds and a great display of thunder and lightning, caused mild damage and inconvenience in the metropolitan area yesterday.
The House Rules Committee voted yesterday to send to the floor a bill calling for increased workmen's compensation benefits for longshoremen and harbor workers injured on the job.
Optimistic plans of the Colombian Government to reduce a heavy backlog of commercial debt due United States exporters on shipments to that country were disclosed yesterday.
THE first broadbill swordfish landed in Long Island waters this season on rod and reel has been brought in, and it is no great surprise that Hans Hinrichs handled the rod.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27--Sven Davidson and Budge Patty joined Jaroslav Drobny on the Wimbledon sidelines tonight. The third and fourth seeds were upset by a couple of brash youngsters and their departure marked the end of a tennis era.
MOSCOW, June 27--Gen. Nathan F. Twining saw Soviet aircraft engine and assembly plants today and a lot of American-made machine tools.
The crisis in the world Communist movement caused by Western publication of Nikita S. Khrushchev's attack on Stalin appears to be nearing a climax.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) --Senate-House conferees today approved a strict new narcotics control bill. It would permit death sentences for the sale of heroin to minors.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Representative Francis E. Walter has dropped his insistence that visitors from the Iron Curtain countries be fingerprinted.
The Greater New York Fund ended its formal campaign yesterday. It reported $6,030,000 had been received to date, and that it was determined to reach its final goal of $10,000,000 by the end of 1956.

The phenomenal growth of the air cargo business in the last six years and the glowing prospects for its future were outlined yesterday by Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

The New Haven Railroad was charged yesterday with having committed "a fundamental error of principle" in allocating to Westchester's commuters $91,895 a month more than their share of the operating costs.
Seven members of the New York Board of Rabbis departed by plane yesterday on the first leg of a trip to the Soviet Union, where they will investigate the religious facilities available to Jews.
PARIS--This summer the American exodus to Europe, steadily mounting each year, promises to break all records.
The McGraw-Hill Publishing Company plans to split its common stock three-for-one and increase the dividend on the split shares.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- The United States Information Agency said officially today that it had a policy against use of paintings by politically suspect artists in its touring art shows.

Plans for a memorial to John Golden were discussed by friends and associates of the Broadway theatrical producer and philanthropist yesterday afternoon at Sardi's. The meeting also commemorated the eighty-second birthday of Mr. Golden, who died on June 17, 1955.

WASHINGTON, June 27--Administration forces organized on Capitol Hill tonight to stave off an attempt to clip the President's authority to decide when quotas on agricultural imports are necessary.

SUNNINGDALE, England, June 27 (UP)--Polly Riley of Fort Worth won two tight matches by sinking long putts on the eighteenth green today and led three other Americans into the quarter-finals of the women's British amateur golf championship.

Ken Boyer hit two home runs and Hal Smith belted one off Johnny Antonelli at the Polo Grounds yesterday to pace the Cardinals to a 6-0 triumph over the Giants that kept the New Yorkers in the National League cellar.

The tiny motor scooter is making a major impression on the Italian economy. Five manufacturers have produced more than 1,000,000 scooters, which now outnumber automobiles on Italy's streets. Scooter repair shops have sprung up in towns and villages.

OMAHA, Neb., June 27--The General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches authorized its executive committee today to proceed with litigation in a case involving the rights of a Negro delegate.

With steels again in the lead, based on hopes of labor peace, stocks pushed forward yesterday to the best levels of the month. Volume expanded to 2,090,000 shares, the largest since June 8. It compared with 1,730,000 shares on Tuesday.
PINEHURST, N.C., June 27 --George Terry Dunlap, cofounder of the New York bookpublishing house of Grosset Dunlap, Inc., died today in his ninety-third year.
The American Machine and Foundry Company is offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe to $10,897,000 of 4 per cent twenty-five year subordinated debentures at 100.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 27-- Premier Adnan Menderes tonight obtained passage of a bill curtailing meetings of political parties to only forty-five days prior to general elections.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 27-- Although efforts to perpetuate the Balkan Pact may appear to be useless, Turkey believes there is still hope for it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--The United States today rejected views expressed by some delegations in the Trusteeship Council that nuclear tests in the Pacific constituted "moral misuse" of a trust territory.

WASHINGTON, June 27--The Senate opened debate today on the Administration's foreign-aid proposals. Supporters of the program faced a hard fight to fend off heavy reductions.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., June 27 (AP)--A new plan to test teaching by television in public schools will be started on a county-wide basis in this western Maryland area next fall.

ON the day that Aqueduct first opened, Sept. 27, 1894, detectives in Washington reported that thirty-five Treasury Department clerks had attended the races at Alexandria Island, Va. This, presumably, was a heinous offense. Folks who handle money were not allowed to have "sporty" inclinations in those days.

LOS ANGELES, June 27--No sprinter since Jesse Owens, double Olympic winner at Berlin twenty years ago, has created the stir in track and field that Dave Sime has.

WASHINGTON, June 27--An unusual safety measure that has been criticized in Congress as a piece of "special-interest" legislation will be attacked by a panel of shipping experts at a Senate hearing tomorrow.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 27 --Senator Estes Kefauver and Gov. Frank G. Clement of Tennessee agreed today that the state's delegation would go to the Democratic National Convention uninstructed.

WE met a banker the other day who told us that money, unless one is actually impoverished, doesn't mean anything. "It really doesn't matter how much money you earn--the important thing is what you do with it," said Miss Mabel F. Thompson.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)-- A House subcommittee today heard charges that military personnel were violating hunting laws in North Carolina, New Mexico, Wisconsin and Arizona.

The $33,480,000,000 highway construction bill has been passed by Congress with a remarkable showing of unanimity, and its benefits and its new taxes simultaneous with spending begin to go into effect Sunday if President Eisenhower signs the measure, as expected.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 27-- The Federal Government was urged here tonight to take immediate steps to formulate a long-range program to cushion the shock of automation on the nation's labor force.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., June 27--Two full days of clamorous celebration of the past glories as a whaling port of this New England city reached their climax here this evening with a three theatre world premiere of John Huston's new color motion picture of Merman Melville's "Moby Dick."
Dag Hammarskjold left yesterday on an Eastern European tour. He expected to have toplevel talks in Moscow with Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief.

The city of Tulsa, Okla., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $5,500,000 of Independent School District bonds on July 17. The obligations will be dated Sept. 1, 1956, and will come due serially from 1958 to 1971.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) --Ike Chestnut of New York scored an eighth-round technical knockout victory over highly favored Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn tonight.
Industry and union proposals for postponing a national steel strike broke down last night over the issue of retroactive pay.

A 60.4 per cent earnings increase in the final quarter lifted the net profit of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to a record $43,295,295 for its fiscal year ended May 31.

TOKYO, June 27--Okinawa, the gigantic United States air base between Japan and Taiwan [Formosa], will be returned to Japan when tensions relay in the Far East. United States Ambassador John M. Allison said tonight.
MOSCOW, June 27--Questions about the conduct of the Soviet leaders during Stalin's rule were placed before the Soviet public today.
LONDON, June 27 (AP)-- Queen Elizabeth II was the victim of a practical joker yesterday as she reviewed 300 holders of the Victoria Cross, Britain's highest military decoration.

The plan of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., to take over the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation was referred yesterday by Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock to the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 27--The Netherlands has signed a trade agreement with the Soviet Union and at the same time has learned a lesson in Moscow's trading tactics.

NOTHING seems to change as much as the irrevocable past. Year after year, even week after week, we read about startling discoveries concerning antiquity. The historians are forever presenting new interpretations of history. The scientists are always offering new findings in the nature of the universe.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Coffee, copper and hides rose; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes and wool declined, and price movements for cocoa, rubber, sugar and zinc were mixed.

CHICAGO, June 27--A further slump in July soybeans today on the Board of Trade helped unsettle the grain list. Wheat developed special weakness is the absence of aggressive support. Coarse grains held fairly well, considering the favorable crop reports and the downturn in wheat.

WASHINGTON, June 27--A few traces of the salt of the sea remain in the Potomac waters that flow almost along the walls of Arlington Cemetery, and on nights when the gale is east by south the smell of the ocean itself drifts over the slopes of the funeral hill.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)-- Jacob J. Shubert, theater owner, denied today any infringement of freedom of the press or civil liberties in reducing theatrical advertising in The Boston Post and withholding free tickets from its drama critic.
The state's right to investigate possibly illegal payments to labor union officials was reaffirmed yesterday, despite a plea that this field had been pre-empted by the Federal Government.
Those of us who are inclined to take the family for granted had better look to the recent annual report of the Community Service Society.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- President Eisenhower will leave Walter Reed Army Hospital Saturday morning and go to Gettysburg, Pa., according to present plans.

Directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday elected Jack I. Straus to the new post of chairman, Wheelock H. Bingham to president and Elliot V. Walter to president of the Macy's New York division, effective Aug. 1.
LONDON, June 27--Further advances by oil shares, particularly Burmah Petroleum, relieved dull stock-market trading here today.
PARIS, June 27--The French Cabinet approved today a decree authorizing the expropriation of big agricultural properties in Algeria for distribution to landless Moslems.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27--President Tito denied in a speech in Belgrade tonight that Yugoslavia was losing her independence to the Soviet Union.

Electric Bond and Share Company, once 'the nation's largest public utility holding company, is increasing its interest in the chemical industry, George G. walker, president, told 200 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting.

The National Outdoor Advertising Bureau, a cooperative organization formed by advertising agencies in 1918 to handle negotiations with individual operators of outdoor installations, opened new offices for its headquarters and New York division, staffs yesterday at 711 Third Avenue.

A 22-year-old Army veteran suspected of shooting a Baltimore patrolman led five Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in a morning rush-hour chase here yesterday before he was captured.

CAIRO, June 27--Twelve international airlines with flights through Cairo protested today against the Government's recent restrictions on travel abroad by Egyptians.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 26-- A new kind of war has begun in Vietnam, according to President Ngo Dinh Diem.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that Moscow's control over foreign Communist parties had been "very much shaken and loosened" by the posthumous attack on Stalin.
Ten persons were killed and four others were critically injured in four truck-and-car accidents in New York State yesterday.
While trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange is running lower than last year, trading in corporate bonds is up. That is one more indication of investors' caution.

The New York Giants and all of the other eleven teams in the National Football League will be in action on Sept. 30, the opening day of the league's thirtyseventh season. The Giants will be on the West Coast playing the San Francisco Forty-Niners that day.

FROM the Spanish word "barbacoa" (an elevated frame), comes the English word "barbecue." As translated by Americans, it means firepots and grills that are built in, portable or on wheels. All of them are accessorized as efficiently as the American kitchen. And they are not all in the backyard or patio.
Charles Laughton has agreed to return to Broadway next season as the star and director of Shaw's "Major Barbara."
Governor Harriman appeared yesterday to have forgotten momentarily his status as an active candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it would comply with the request of Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, and reduce its crude oil imports from the Middle East in the third quarter 4 per cent below the level of the first half of this year.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 27--Two former champions, the medalist and a newcomer reached the semi-final round of the twenty-sixth annual Women's Long Island Golf Association's match-play championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson reported today that several thousands of Midwestern farmers already had signed to put land into the new soil bank.
This would be a better yachting world if every skipper were a trained meteorologist. The more he knows about approaching storms, squalls and high tides, the safer is his handling of a pleasure craft.
WASHINGTON, June 27--The Administration's civil rights program won approval today in the House Rules Committee. It is now expected to reach the floor of the House the week after next.
THOSE with a sense of tradition as well as taste will concentrate on American food and drink on our chief patriotic holiday next Wednesday.
A WOMAN tires of a dress long before it bores the company she keeps. That is the opinion of Sylvan M. Baar, president of the accessories firm of Baar Beards.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 27 (AP)--Torpid set a world record for 2-year-old pacers on a half-mile track tonight at Roosevelt Raceway when he toured the Westbury oval in 2:02 3/5 to win the $15,000 Knight Dream Pace.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 27 --The man with the inside track to be Premier of Iceland says the election returns have not altered his determination to rid the country of United States troops.
SAN FRANCISCO June 27-- A coalition of white and Negro workers was advocated today to meet a common problem--"getting the Southern political demagoguese off their backs."

Howell E. Jackson's Tick Tock took off his blinkers and won the $24,100 Shevlin Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. Many in the crowd of 15,964 thought he couldn't do it against the likes of C.V. Whitney's Head Man and the Brookmeade Stable's Lawless, among others.
RENO, Nev., June 27--Former United States Senator Edward P. Carville, Democrat of Nevada, died of a stroke here this morning. His age was 71.

CHICAGO, June 27--The two-week summer home furnishings market has not been a good one, but it was not expected to be, retailers and manufacturers reported today in the Merchandise Mart. The market, also being held in the Furniture Mart, ends Saturday.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz clashed yesterday with District Attorney Edward S. Silver on whether the prosecutor had pursued vigorously an investigation into waterfront racketeering.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 29-- Amortizor, a 5-year-old horse driven by Ed Cobb, paced a mile and a sixteenth at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in 2:06 2/5, a world record for a half-mile track.

Three New York Stock Exchange member firms combined yesterday under the name of Winslow, Cohu Stetson, while Cohu Co., Winslow, Douglas . McEvoy and Stetson Co. ceased to exist.
WASHINGTON, July 1--Despite some "soft spots," the general outlook for industrial production and sales in the second half of 1956 was found to be "favorable" today by the Commerce Department.
The Rev. Dr. Emil C.J. Kraeling, pastor emeritus of Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church, Brooklyn, died Saturday night in Saratoga Hospital, Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

PITTSBURGH, July 1--The Giants almost won a doubleheader from the, Pirates today before 23,459 Forbes Field fans. But they were foiled by the Sunday curfew law. They took the first game, 3--2, behind the eight-hit pitching of Johnny Antonelli, plus the fine relief work of Mary--Grissom.
Not all the boy gangsters from the slums of New York go on to Sing Sing Prison, nor do all the wayward girls grow up to be gun molls or prostitutes.
BERLIN, July 1--Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, appraised his week-long visit to Moscow today as worth-while.
The nation's 630 privately supported colleges and universities will receive checks totaling $130,000,000 this week to help them raise faculty salaries.
EAST CHARLESTON, Vt., July 2--The general conclusion of an argument that just ended at the Echo Lake Club here is that the lies of anglers are not astonishing; they are repetitive and unimaginative.
A double explosion in a Queens atomic research laboratory yesterday injured nine persons and created a wide but unnecessary scare of a radioactive fallout.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan took another step yesterday in his crackdown on labor racketeers. He announced the indictment of six present or former officials of a local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
PARIS, July 2-An open break between the French and Moroccan Governments concerning the, movements of French forces in Morocco appeared tonight to have been avoided for the moment.

Admiral Arthur D. Struble retired yesterday from the Navy with four-star rank after fortyone years of active duty. Vice Admiral Frederick W. McMahon succeeded him as Commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier.
The explosive issue of bureauracy in the Soviet Union, first raised by Trotsky and raised more recently by Yugoslav Titoists, appears to have moved to the center of world Communist discussion.
The American Tariff League charged yesterday that the United States "gave far more than it received" in recent tarifflowering bargains with twentyone countries.

Morris Schwartzer, who formerly operated the Biltmore chain of eight cafeterias in New York, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a threemonth illness. His age was 57. He lived at 1506 Sherwood Drive, East Meadow, L. I.
Pasadena, Calif., July 2--The first ballad to be composed by an electronic computer will be played July 15 in a science show on television.
A $52,391 contract for hypodermic syringes for city hospitals was awarded yesterday to the Propper Manufacturing Company. The concern is at 10-34 Forty-fourth Drive, Long Island City.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz., July 2--Army helicopter pilots braved Forty-mile-an-hour updrafts in the Grand Canyon today to begin recovery of the remains of the 128 victims of Saturday's double airliner crash.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 2 --Gov. Leroy Collins said today that he regarded as a "miscarriage of ambition" the boycott activities of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that have resulted in abandonment of public bus service here.

A debt settlement offer by Berlin to restore its defaulted dollar bonds to an interest-paying basis, was made public here yesterday by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council. The council recommended that the offered be accepted.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 2-- The nation's educators called on Congress today to pass a substantial Federal aid bill at this session.
A heart-warming performance of the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto was Erica Morini's contribution to the Stadium Symphony Orchestra concert last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July, 2-- Gov. A. B. (Happy) Chandler, riding the crest of a powerful political comeback, is expected to be endorsed here tomorrow as Kentucky's favorite son for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
A new Soviet program of domestic reform has been spelled out by the Central Committee of the Communist party. The program emphasizes the determination of the Soviet rulers to raise living standards.

MOSCOW, July 2--Diplomatic observers here were impressed today by the Soviet leaders' concern over foreign Communist interpretation of the downgrading of Stalin. The concern was shown in a resolution defending the Soviet party's policy.
The Champion Paper and Fibre Company, a leading domestic producer of paper, yesterday reported record sales and earnings.

IT makes news hereabouts when a hospital invites parents of sick children to take an active part in their care. This revolutionary approach, recommended by many pediatricians and psychiatrists, is old stuff in the Orient, a World Health Organization expert has reported.

Walter Alston, who will direct the National League forces in the annual All-Star game in Washington next Tuesday, yesterday took ample care that his world, champion Dodgers would be represented in this year's classic.
There was good news yesterday for commuters on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
In the insufferable heat in Ebbets Field last night, a gathering of 22,035 steaming fans witnessed a rather extraordinary spectacle.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 2-- Sealed indictments were returned today by the special grand jury looking into charges of official corruption in Suffolk County.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 2-- Both political parties will be asked to include in their 1956 platforms endorsement of equal rights and equal pay for women. The request will be made by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women, which is in session here.
LONDON, July 2--S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Ceylon; announced today Britain had agreed in principle to evacuate the Trincomalee naval base and the Katunayake air base.
Peter Brandwein, a sports copy editor and sports writer for The New York Times, died last night of a heart attack in his home at 1840 Tenbroeck Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 45.
Miss Ann Childton Grace was married yesterday to Paul Taylor Hartman Jr. in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Elkton, Md.

During the depths of the great depression some two score of the nation's 112 Class I railroads (those with operating revenues of more than $3,000,000 a year) either plunged into bankruptcy or teetered on the brink.
WE ARE apt to think of spu moni as an exotic dessert to be found only in Italian restaurants. Actually it can be made easily, quickly and cheaply at home.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP)-- Charles E. Wilson assured Congress today that service men who violated state and local hunting and fishing laws would he "vigorously prosecuted."
The effects of the national steel strike began spreading through the economy yesterday.

The securities underwriting set-ups of two of the nation's largest investment banking organizations--Union Securities Corporation and Eastman, Dillon Co.--are being merged into a new underwriting and brokerage firm with capital resources of more than $17,000,000.
A city magistrate took off his judicial robes yesterday while he sat down with five youths, and for a few minutes Adolescent Court became somewhat of a stage.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 2-- Bishop Anthimos, acting leader of the Greek Cypriote community, has postponed indefinitely his trip to Athens for consultations with the Greek Government.
MOSCOW, July 2-Dag Hammarskjold arrived here shortly before midnight for his first trip to the Soviet. Union since assuming his post as United Nations secretary general.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 2 --This valley of silent steel mills was apprehensive but resigned today as it headed, into the first week of the steel strike.

JERUSALEM, Israel, July 2Comdr. Elmer Terrill of the United States Navy was relieved of his post as chairman of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission, it was learned today from United Nations sources.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2--The Western countries will press the United Nations Disarmament Commission tomorrow for an endorsement of a four-power declaration of principles. The declaration was made in London last spring and ignored by the Soviet Union.

TRENTON, July 2--Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. said today he had directed all twenty-one county prosecutors to meet here with him Thursday. The parley will discuss the New Jersey Supreme Court ban last week on games of skill in which a player bets money and prizes are awarded.
The National Broadcasting Company has bought the radio and television rights to the AllStar baseball games and the World Series for a total of $16,250,000 for five years.
WASHINGTON, July 2--The Grand Canyon air crashes focused official attention today on the need for improved air traffic controls, even in food weather.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 --A new collective bargaining contract covering the employ ment of extras in the theatrical and television motion-picture field has been negotiated by the Association of Motion Picture Producers, the Alliance of Television Film Producers and the Screen Extras Guild.
Shipping circles are worried over Chile's new merchant marive law, reserving half of her foreign trade to Chilean-flag vessels.
WASHINGTON, July 2-The State Department denounced today as "wholly false" the Soviet Communist party's charge that the United States had "instigated and financed" the riots in Poznan, Poland.
CAVALIER, N. D., July 2-- Governor Harriman's exhaustive search for Democratic Presidential delegates led him today to this North Dakota town.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 2--Five' Sunday sailors spent last night clinging to their overturned motorboat in Long Island Sound. At dawn they were rescued by a ketch home
