TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 19-- One of the most effective United States aid organizations in Asia is the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction in Chinese Nationalist Taiwan (Formosa).

CHICAGO, July 2--Some of the larger wheat shows today took advantage of early hedge selling to cover their lines. This took the slack out of the pit. There was also some commission buying on resting orders.
A team of underwater explorers will begin a three-year study of the bottom of Long Island Sound within the next week.
New York's nine major deartment stores registered gains in sales averaging 6 per cent last month, as compared with sales of June, 1955. The increases in the preceding month averaged 7.5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 2-Following are excerpts of the testimony today by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, before the Senate Armed Services Subcommittee on the Air Force:
The Daily Worker in its issue today prints the text of the Soviet Communist party statement on the anti-Stalin campaign.
THE PARTIES--The United Steelworkers of America, A.F.L.C.I.O., representing 650,000 basic steel workers employed by 100 companies.
LONDON, July 2-The British Government's effort to persuade Turkey to agree to eventual self-determination for the Cypriote people has ended unsuccessfully.
It was a sunny afternoon, of the type sent along at this time of year as an aid to good conversation.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Politics, of course, was involved in the addition by Congress of $960 millions more for the Air Force than the President requested.
BONN, Germany, July 2-- Eight countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and a number of welfare organizations are trying to convince West Germany that it should...

WASHINGTON, July 2-A senior member of the Senate Republican Policy Committee disowned today as "shameful" a published charge by that committee's staff that the Communists wanted the Democrats to win the election in November.

A New Jersey Supreme Court decision on June 25 that mechanical games of skill, as well as those of chance, are illegal if the players wager money seems to have thrown the state into wild confusion. Professional golfers found they were playing a tournament for fun--at least temporarily.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 2 (AP)-- Egyptian Princess won the Coaching Club Trotting Oaks today in two straight heats at Historic Track, establishing a world record and moving front and center as the favorite for the Hambletonian Stakes on Aug. 8.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoreman's Association, urged again yesterday that the association's 30,000 members here take No "job action" when he begins a fifteen-day jail term for contempt of court.

The prospect of fair weather promises to send thousands of New Yorkers to near-by beaches and on short automobile trips for the midweek Fourth of July holiday tomorrow. The temperature is expected to be in the 80's, in contrast to yesterday's high of 92 degrees at 6 P. M.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 --Screen Gems, inc., announced today that it had "set aside" $1,000,000 for the development of twenty new programs for the 1957-58 television season.

ANKARA; Turkey, July 2Four Republican members of Turkey's Parliament were stripped of their parliamentary immunity today. The session at which the action was taken was attended only by members of the Democratic majority.

The Federal school-aid bill is now being debated in the House and is expected to reach a vote this week. Although it is very late in the day, the bill still has a fair chance of becoming law providing no anti-segregation rider is attached to it.

Net operating earnings of New York City commercial banks for the first half of the year were well above those of the corresponding period last year, according to initial reports issued yesterday. The rise is due chiefly to greater interest income on loans.

ERNIE KOVACS, entrepreneur of off-beat wackiness, began a summer series at 8 o'clock on Channel 4 last night. He should do well. There were lulls on the premiere, quite a few of them. But there were also a number of spots of fine humor.
ADNAN MENDERES once served as a lieutenant to Kemal Ataturk, the strong man who forged modern Turkey out of the decay of the Ottoman Empire.
Forty-four housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration have called for bids July 10 on $78,129,000 to finance low-rent projects.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)-- A demand for an investigation of the Civil Aeronautics Administration came today from Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida. It followed the crash Saturday of two airliners in Grand Canyon, Ariz., with the loss of 128 lives.

Besides Alfred Drake's starring vehicle, "The Pleasure of Honesty," Alexander H. Cohen is planning to do another play in London. Newly added to Mr. Cohen's overseas agenda is a comedy, temporarily labeled...
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2--Yugoslavia has proposed to the United States that future aid be earmarked for the development of power and aluminum resources.
The first completed consolidatibn of a Congress of Industrial Organization national union with its American Federation of Labor opposite was announced yesterday. It involved rival barber unions.
Carl Schuster's Zig Zag, was declared the winner yesterday of the William H. Johns Memorial Trophy for the best corrected time in the Bayside Yacht Club'S Cornfield Lightship race.

NORTHPORT, L. I., July 2-- Edward Modell, supervisory gardener at the Northport Veteran's Hospital, received the Veterans Administration's exceptional service award here today for his aid in rehabilitating mentally ill patients through gardening activities.
The world's struggle toward disarmament is a little like the drunkard's efforts to reform: he cannot quite stop drinking but neither can he escape a guilty feeling every time he wanders into a bar.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) believes business should give financial aid to colleges and college students. It is taking cosiderable space in newspapers to quote the endorsements of the idea by two college presidents and two students.

HOYLAKE, England, July 2 (UP)--Gary Player, a 21-yearold South African took the lead in the first qualifying round for the British Open championship today. He set a record for the long, difficult Hoylake course with a three-under-par 68.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 2-- A State Department official issued a warning here tonight on possible Soviet aggression under the new mask of antiStalinism. He declared that it might be more successful in achieving Russian goals than the old policies.
LONDON, July 2--The strike movement in Britain's automotive industry suffered a setback today in the face of continuing reductions in employment caused by shrinking markets.

CARACAS, July 2--Venezuelan Government spokesmen said today they would probably have an announcement tomorrow regarding oil concessions. Meanwhile. it was learned that eight important blocks in the Maracaibo Lake area had been authorized.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane is offering for public subscription a new issue of $20,000,000 of first mortgage, 3 7/8 per cent bonds of the Florida Power Corporation due in 1986, at 100.897 to yield 3.82 per cent.
Historic Castle Clinton at the Battery is to be fully restored as a national monument and museum at a cost of $498,500.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP) --Boths the United and Trans World airliners, which apparently collided before crashing in the Grand Canyon Saturday, were off course to the north, officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration said today.
GETTYSBURG, July 2-Cheerful reports about the President's convalescence were issued today by his physicians, his press secretary and President Eisenhower himself.
The city rejected yesterday the report issued Sunday by Attorney General Jacob K. Javits holding the state blameless in the June 12 Brooklyn landslide tragedy.

Traditionally, the commercial banks like to be free of debt to the Federal Reserve System on statement days--the last day of each quarter. This is so they won't show any indebtedness on their statements to stockholders.

Blue Banner of the Rokeby Stable was the winner of the Distaff Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. With Eddie Arcaro riding, Blue Banner came along in the stretch to beat Mrs. Ian Montgomery's Peignoir by a half-length in a stirring finish.
PARIS ISLAND, S. C., July 2 (AP)--Fourteen witnesses testified today in the court-martial of Marine Sgt. Arthur E. Ashcraft on charges, he maltreated eleven recruits.

WASHINGTON,. July 2 (UP)-- The chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee said today the nation's defenses against hydrogen bomb attack soon would be based "upon ground-to-air missiles using nuclear warheads."
AT the age of 59, Hollywood designer Howard Greer has succumbed to a severe case of nostalgia.

CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP)-- The Cincinnati Redlegs regained first place in the National League tonight on Johnny Klippstein's eight-hit, 2-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. A standing-room-only crowd of 28,635 saw the Redlegs drop Milwaukee to second place.
The first Federal indictment in this district for wiretapping was returned yesterday against Charles V. Gris, a private investigator.

LONDON, July 2--Labor troubles in the United States and Britain affected most sectors of the stock market today. No substantial selling developed but Government bonds and industrial shares fell further. Losses among the bonds ranged up to 8s9d ($1.22 ).
WIMBLEDON, England, July 2--Ham Richardson of Westfield, N. J., sad Vic Seixas of Philadelphia gained the Wimbledon tennis semi-finals today.
ALBANY, July 2-The Public Service Commission authorized the New York Telephone Company today to increase its rates by $15,745,000 a year.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 2--Skis, sweaters and perhaps even an occasional snowball will provide a deviation from the summer athletic norm in this Adirondack community Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP)-- Instailment credit hit another record high in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The purchase of the Chemical Construction Corporation (Chemico) from the American Cynamid Company by the Electric Bond and Share Company was announced yesterday. The price was understood to have been $4,000,000 in cash.
The annual Turf Charity Ball at the Monmouth Park Race Track, Oceanport, N. J., which since the first fete in 1947 has raised almost a half million dollars for charity, will he held on July 28.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2--An application was filed today with the Federal Housing Administration for a Government-insured mortgage on a $5,000,000 international housing development in Westchester County. It first was projected three...
MOSCOW, July 1--The justconcluded visit here of United States Air Force leaders has raised the question as to how the Soviet planes they saw compared with American aircraft.

Social workers have transformed boy thugs into honor students at college, Admittedly, it does not happen often. But that such a triumph is achieved at all reassures agencies treating juvenile delinquency that they are on the right track.

Steels, coppers and rails lost ground and aluminums gained in a quiet session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. It was a day of smaller volume-- 1,610,000 shares, against 1,776,700 on Friday--and of generally moderate losses, many of them reduced by a show of strength near the close.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)-- Secretary of State Dulles has told Congress the chances of the Soviet Union's starting a war are less than they were a year ago.

ROME, July 2--Senator Umberto Tupini of the dominant Christian Democratic party was proclaimed Mayor of Rome late this evening. His election was a grave blow to the Left-wing Socialists, allies of the Communists, who had hoped to force him to take them into the city government.
Washington, July 2 (UP)-- The value of farm real estate has risen 4 per cent in the last year with both buildings and land showing gains, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 2--Eight thousand dockers walked off ships in the harbors of Sydney, Newcastle, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Hobart today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP)-- The nation's airlines moved today to meet the troublesome problem of "no-shows" --passengers who reserve space on flights and then fail to use it.
BERLIN, July 2--The number of persons arrested following the crushing of last week's riots in Poznan, Poland, was reported today to be nearing 1,000. Most of the prisoners were said to be young.
Joey Giardello struck early and suddenly to score a firstround knockout over Tony Baldoni in the scheduled ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 2--Guatemalan political exiles, most of them students, are contributing heavily to the problem of Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz, Chief of State, in maintaining internal order.

TO be alive is to be in peril. This indis-- putable truism should give a sense of exhilarating daring to all existence, whether one is only running desperate risks of being bored to extinction by the humdrum or facing the unimaginable confrontations of the future.
ALBANY, N. Y., July 2 (UP)-- State Commerce Commissioner Edwart T. Dickinson today appointed a special departmental committee to study industrial conditions in Brooklyn.
Coffee futures tumbled the 2cent-a-pound daily limit in most positions during trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

FORT HANCOCK, N. J., July 2--This venerable Army installation was reactivated as a fullfledged "Class One"' base today. The occasion was marked by a parade and a demonstration of Nike guided missile batteries.

THE most puzzling aspect of the balloting by the fans for the annual All-Star teams is the alarming way the total votes sloughed off this year, the first time the poll was conducted by the office of the Baseball Commissioner instead of an outside agency. Have the fans lost interest or weren't the original poll-takers able to count?

The Hambletonian, harness rac-- ing's trotting classic, may have to find a new home after its next stand at Goshen on Aug 8. The famous race, held at Good Time Park since 1930, has been running into financial troubles-- big ones.

HOYLAKE, England, July 2 (AP)--Gary Player, a 20-year-old South African, has Gene Sarazen to thank, in part, for the record-breaking 68 he fired in the first round of the British open golf qualifying over the stern Hoylake course today.

WASHINGTON, July 2-- Charles E. Wilson repeatedly declined today to promise increased B-52 bomber production. He assured Congress, however, he would not impound an extra $900,000,000 voted mainly for that purpose.

The problem of Cyprus, which appeared to be on the way toward solution as between Britain and the Greeks, has run into new complications as a result of determined Turkish opposition to the British concessions.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3-- Two Brazilian diplomats called Communist agents by a Government investigatory commission in 1953 were appointed today to consular posts in Montreal and Oporto, Portugal.
Charles J. Wagner, an attorney and cousin of Mayor Wagner, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital of a liver ailment. He was 49 years old.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 3-- Governor A.B. Chandler was endorsed today as Kentucky's favorite son for the 1956 Democratic Presidential nomination.
A city fireman was booked on a homicide charge yesterday in a fatal stabbing that the police said involved a $75 debt owed by the victim.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3--Governor Harriman returned to New York tonight with high hopes that on the second or third ballot, he would have support for the Presidential nomination from the majority of the Minnesota delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
DETROIT, July 3 (AP)--The auto industry's "Big Three"-- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler--built 3,082,129 cars and 456,103 trucks during the first half of 1956.

WASHINGTON, July 3. (UP)-- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, called on President Eisenhower today to repudiate a Republican campaign document contending that Communists want a Democratic victory this year.

MANILA, July 3 (Reuters)-- Following is the text of the joint statement on United States military bases made today in Manila by Vice President Richard M. Nixon and President Ramon Magsaysay of the Philippines:

PARIS, July 3--One cause for NATO's decline is refusal by its members to delegate to the alliance even a modicum of authority over their individual national affairs.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 3-- Adlai E. Stevenson, front-running candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, began a five-day tour today of the Midwest farm area.

If the city's magistrates decide to follow the lead of Magistrate Walter J. Bayer, they will soon be carrying little toy cars in their pockets. Magistrate Bayer began carrying the cars on Monday. They are part of a plan he has developed that cuts down the trial time of signal light cases.
CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP)-- Home runs by Vic Wertz, Jim Busby and A1 Rosen and a fourrun eighth inning today carried the Cleveland Indians to a 9-3 victory over the last-place Kansas City Athletics.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The State Department announced today that in mid-June it had expelled Col. Ivan A. Bubchikov, an assistant military attache of the Soviet Embassy.

Police Commissioner Kennedy's continued concern over the strength of his force is well justified. Although yesterday's actual strength was 22,859, against an authorized quota of 22,963, the outlook is bleak for building the city-wide protection needed.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)-- Jim Lemon's triple with one out in the eleventh, inning scored Roy Sievers and enabled the Washington Senators to gain a 6-5 triumph over the Boston Red Sox today.

GUATEMALA, July 3--President Carlos Castillo Armas observed the second anniversary of his coming to power today. He pledged that his Government would fight to exterminate "the menace of international Communist slavery."

Directors of the Boeing Airplane Company yesterday voted to split the stock two for one. One additional share for each share held will be distributed Aug. 6 to stockholders of record July 13. Trading in the company's stock was the second most active yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 3--Authorities on the Soviet Union said today they discerned indications that a group in the Kremlin was attempting to take credit for curbing Stalin's activities.

THERE are some cynics who claim that rowing is the silliest sport of all. It's the only one, they insist, in which men com pete by sitting down and going backwards. Be that as it may, rowing still is one of the most important of all Olympic endeavors, outranked only by track and swimming.

WASHINGTON, July 3-- The country's most vocal crusader for Negro rights is a Protestant minister who likes tweed jackets and a pipe. He owns three homes, two sports cars and two boats and says he has a family income of $115,000 a year.

Major league baseball players, pleased with the $3,250,000-a-year radio-TV deal completed by Commissioner Ford Frick for the world series-All Star game rights, might cash a monthly retirement check of $400, their attorney said yesterday.

GENEVA, July 3--The American coal industry is making a serious effort to establish itself as a regular contributor to Europe's energy needs.
National Broadcasting Company radio will present a thirteen-week series of discussions on "Can Freedom Win," startins on July 12.

THE television and radio industry was startled last month when Mrs. Mildred B. Zorbaugh became vice president and special assistant to the president of the American Broadcasting Company, for she is believed to be the first woman to achieve this rank at a major network.

Trading in commodity futures was dull and featureless in the New York markets yesterday. Most of the volume was limited to evening of holdings prior to the Independence Day holiday. Prices closed irregularly.
TOKYO, July 3--A group of 335 so-called Japanese "war criminals," released recently by Communist China, landed at Maizuru this morning.

An official of the New York office of the State Training School for Girls complains bitterly that there is more public prejudice against a girl who has had an illegitimate baby than against a boy who has committed homicide.
Another teamster union official was found guilty yesterday of contempt of court and sentenced by Federal Judge Gregorg F. Noonan to six months in prison.

TRENTON, July 3--Gov. Robert B. Meyner intimated today for the first time that he Would veto a bill designed to legalize games of skill in which the player bet money and prizes were awarded.

THE Lower East Side Neighborhood Association pre sented last night the first of eight free symphony concerts to be heard on successive Tuesdays in the East River Park Amphitheatre, East River Drive at Grand Street.
Under the leadership of steels, which advaneed despite a paucity of favorable news, the stock market had a good pre-holiday session yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3--Increase of 10 per cent or more in Government compensation to veterans with service-connected disabilities was approved today by the House of Representatives Veterans Affairs Committee.
WASHINGTON, July 3--Following is the prepared text of a Fourth of July address by Vice President Richard M. Nixon in Manila, as released here by the State Department:

The opening and closing bell tolls regularly in Milan's stock exchange--one of the large exchanges of the world-but it tolls for almost no one. There has been hardly a sale for three weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today a bill to require the President to notify the Senate of the terms of all non treaty international agreements.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 3 --Today, ninety-three years to the day after the Confederacy received its mortal wounds on the outskirts of town, President Eisenhower celebrated a different type of milestone.
The possibility of a large shake-up in the Police Department was seen yesterday as detectives filed reports on their activities over the past thirty months.
DETROIT, July 3 (AP)--The Detroit Baseball Company announced today that eight syndicates had officially bid for the Detroit Tiger franchise and Briggs Stadium.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3--The Soviet Union told the United Nations today to call on its members for a renunciation of war and the use of atomic weapons in settling international disputes.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP)-- The Commence department reported today that foreign visitors spent $645,000,000 in the United States last year. The spending was a record amount.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 3 --Joseph J. Byrne, retired vice president in charge of traffic of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western. Railroad, died here last night at his home, 34 Luddington Road, after a long illness. His age was 87.
The Aluminum Company of America says it has produced the largest diameter aluminum pipe ever extruded in the United States, and possibly in the World.

RED BANK, N.J., July 7-- Miss Suzanne Settle Stephens was married here this afternoon to Donald Brook Castleman in the First Baptist Church. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Walter Stephens of Little Silver. Mr. Castleman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Godwin Munn Castleman of Brooklyn.

CORTLAND, N.Y., July 12 (AP)--Naomi Venable of Poughkeepsie, the 1955 champion, and Mrs. George Trainor of Rochester gained the final of the New York state women's amateur golf championship today.

The best of the divertissements at the Jamaica race track yesterday was the seventh race--a run of a mile and three-sixteenths for a $7,500 purse. The winner, in a highly exciting bit of business, was the Brae Burn Farm's War Piper, the 2-to-1 second choice.
TORONTO, July 12--Delegates to the American Newspaper Guild convention agreed unanimously today to play a more active role in national politics.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 12 --Officials of the Garden City Jewish Center expressed renewed confidence today that they would obtain a permit for a synagogue here.

BERLIN, July 12--The Communist press of East Berlin offered today a choice of explanations about the riots in Poznan, Poland. One newspaper blamed United States agents and another the economic difficulties of the workers.

SILVER BAY, N.Y., July 12 --American churches are "fiddling" with their denominational differences while Southeast Asia burns with the increasing fires of communism and nationalism, mission executives stressed at a conference today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12--The Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club took home the first championship in its history when it won the Syce Cup, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound, today.

Miss Charlotte E. Carr, one of the nation's best-known social workers and the city's home relief director in the turbulent mid-Nineteen Thirties, died yesterday at her home, 31 West Eleventh Street. She was 66 years old.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 12 --President Eisenhower made it "absolutely" clear today that he still wanted Vice President Richard M. Nixon as his running mate this fall.
CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP)-- The Philadelphia Phils scored five times in the top of the ninth tonight to defeat the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7-4, and reduce Cincinnati's National League lead to a half game.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 12--Pakistan has urged the United States to set up a permanent food bank in Pakistan to fight famine throughout Asia.

Secretary of State Dulles used the word "disaster" when he appeared before the Senate Appropriations Committee yesterday to plead against the House bill which would cut the foreign aid appropriation for the coming year to $3.6 billions.
CHICAGO, July 12--An answer to an accusation that 150 Communists were among the members of the American Federations of Television and Radio Artists was given today at the federation's convention.
MUNICH, Germany, July 12-- The approach by United States unions to the problem of automation was offered today as an example that should be followed by West German unions.
CHICAGO, July 12--Buying demand subsided in all grain pits today following the strength shown in coarse grains yesterday.

The long contract dispute between the Metropolitan Opera and the American Guild of Musical Artists, which on June 6 finally seemed to have been resolved, has flared up again. The new point of disagreement involved the status of Robert Herman, the opera-loving son of "Babe" Herman of baseball fame. The 31-year-old stage director, who acts as assistant to the Metropolitan's artistic administrator, may lose his job.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 12 (AP)--The Louisiana Legislature early today completed the wildest session in many years. Gov. Earl Long caused most of the uproar.

TWO of the leading choices at meat counters for this week end are turkeys and chuck roasts. Both require considerable cooking, but for small families they do provide more than enough for one meal. For a second and perhaps even a third appearance, they can come to the table as cold cuts.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The House of Representatives passed a bill today to increase compensation for 2,000,000 war veterans with service-connected disabilities. The vote was 391 to 0 for the increases costing approximately, $172,000,000 the first year.

Mr. and Mrs. T.F. Davies Haines of 1115 Fifth Avenue and Fishers Island, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Haven Haines, to Dwight C. Minton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Minton of New Hyde Park, L. I.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 12-- Shortly after it was announced today that the ransom note in the Weinberger kidnapping was signed "your baby sitter," a blackout was clamped on news of the case.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)-- The Treasury announced today that on Monday it would offer $12,938,000,000 of 2 per cent Treasury notes in exchange for two issues bearing lower interest rates and maturing Aug. 15 and Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 478,297 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
SUGAR, spice, everything nice --including snips, snails and everything but puppy dog tails, make the Washington Market a fascinating visiting place for youngsters of both sexes.

MOSCOW, July 12--A. V. Topchiyev, secretary of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, was named today as plenipotentiary of his government to the new joint nuclear research institute of eleven Communist countries.
A total of 759 pints of blood was given Wednesday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12--The Soviet Union agreed today to limitations on conventional armed forces proposed by the United States, Britain and France as a first step toward world disarmament.

THE weather report on the car radio said it was 90 de grees in New York. We had the heater turned on and the windshield wipers going. There was a flurry of snow in Yellowstone Park and a nip in the morning air.

Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was light. Copper, cocoa, zinc, sugar and onions rose; coffee, rubber, hides, cottonseed oil and wood declined, and potatoes, burlap and silk closed mixed.
ELLENVILLE, N. Y., July 12 --The world premiere of Jose Limon's "The Emperor Jones" was the featured event on the program of the third week of the Empire State Music Festival, which opened tonight.

Ocean-bottom explorers at the Lamont Geological Observatory of Columbia University have constructed a new sampling device that will enable them to grasp a diameter-foot crosssection of sediment from the ocean bottom.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 12--Tim Holland of Rockville and George Baird Jr. of Brookville shared the lead in the qualifying round of the Long Island amateur golf championship today.

LONDON, July 12--The recent advance in oil share prices was halted today, Increased selling brought losses to Shell, Burmah and Canadian Eagle Bearer. Prices steadied in interoffice dealings after the market closed.
Brilliant sunshine yesterday greeted the rededication of City Hall, resplendent in its new dress of Alabama gray-veined limestone and Missouri red granite.

MOSCOW, July 12--The sessions of the Supreme Soviet contained only one very mild surprise today. That was that there were no debates, no challenges to the Government that some observers thought would take place on the basis of recent published statements.

MONTREAL, July 12 (AP)-- Sale of 16 per cent of the common stock of the Howard Smith Paper Mills, Ltd., to the Dominion Tar and Chemical Company, Ltd., has been announced in a letter to Howard Smith shareholders.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The Administration is not exercised at this point about the general economic effect of the steel strike.

READING, Pa., July 12--The four-day feud between Mayor Daniel F. McDevitt and the city's two daily newspapers, The Times and The Eagle, simmered down a little today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (UP)--Two Californians, one man from Florida and one from Tennessee played through rain and fog at Harding Park today to reach the semi-finals of the national public links golf tournament.

CHICAGO, July 12 (UP)--Dale Long clubbed his first home run in more than a month today to break a tie in the eighth inning of the second game and give the Pittsburgh Pirates a sweep over the Chicago Cubs, 2--1 and 5--4, before 19,077 fans.
GENEVA, July 12--The World Jewish Congress protested to the United Nations today against Arab efforts to boycott Jewish concerns in Europe and the United States.

LONDON, July 12--Prime Minister Eden announced in the House of Commons today that Lord Radcliffe, an eminent jurist, would go to Cyprus tomorrow for consultations preparatory to drawing up a constitution for the strife-torn colony.
WASHINGTON, July 12--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year,

Deborah Rabinowitz, an 8year-old Queens schoolgirl, received formal thanks yesterday from President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt for the $2 she had mailed him to "buy some clothes for the Arab children."
In an all-cash deal a large East Side property has been sold by Simon Brothers, builders, for $1,500,000. Robert Zeiller, an investor, is the buyer.

There the diners see motor cars and vans as mouse-sized, far below, and plodding humankind as even lesser figures. It must be a godlike feeling.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (Ap)-- Irving Charles Velson, an observer on the New York waterfront for the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, refused today to tell Senate investigators whether he was a Communist.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa lost another battle yesterday in his campaign to sell abandonded city hospital sites to private real estate developers.

WASHINGTON, July 12--Investigating Senators called on the University of Chicago today to destroy recordings of jury deliberations that a research team made in a Federal Circuit Court. The recordings were made at Wichita, Kan., in 1954.

Plans to merge the Oldbury Electro-Chemical Company into the Hooker Electrochemical Company were announced yesterday by officers of both companies.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)-- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it was making an emergency, purchase of 200,000 pounds of zirconium from Japan. The metal is used in nuclear reactors.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12-- Diamond Hal, a black 5-year-old pacer driven by Joe O'Brien, won the $25,000 National Pacing Derby tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. He beat six rivals in the mile and a quarter test.
Soviet attempts to break up the defense alliances of the free world by threats or by smiles have met another rebuff, this time at the hands of the Shah of Iran.
LONDON, July 12--Despite the earnest efforts of the United States delegates, East-West politics were interjected today with some bitterness into the Congress of the International P. E. N. Club here.

WASHINGTON, July 13--The Government has approved the sale of $1,100,000 worth of steel sheets to the Soviet Union.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 13--Attempts to check the inflationary spiral that has climbed steadily here since the new administration took office in March were dealt a severe blow today by the Indonesian Government Monetary Board.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- Speaker Sam Rayburn assured Governor Harriman today that he would do his utmost to break a Rules Committee deadlock and bring the Niagara power bill before the House of Representatives.

Orlando Zulueta of Havana scored a surprise victory over Ludwig Lightburn at Madison Square Garden last night. Boxing carefully through the ten rounds, Zulueta gained a unanimous decision over his opponent from Belize, British Honduras.
WASHINGTON, July 13--The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended today a substantial restoration of funds to the Eisenhower Administration's foreign aid bill.

PARIS, July 13--The tragedy of errors embroiling three Allies over Cyprus shows no sign of getting better. Turkey, undoubtedly encouraged by Britain's attitude, has sworn to invade the island rather than see it go to Greece.
WASHINGTON, July 13--The South's new manifesto, pledging a fight with every legal weapon against the Administration's civil rights bill, was received calmly by the House of Representatives today.
WASHINGTON, July 13--The mushroom growth of the television industry was aptly illustrated this week when Philo T. Farnsworth, one of its grand old men, got another patent at the ripe age of 49.

LENOX, Mass., July 13-- Despite chill, damp weather tonight, the sixth program of the Berkshire Music Festival attracted an audience of about 2,200 listeners, which is double the seating capacity of the small concert hall for which the event was first scheduled.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford said today that the "introduction of new weapons" might ultimately make possible a reduction in military manpower.

TOKYO, July 13--Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu was named today to head the Japanese delegation that will renew peace talks with the Soviet Union. The talks are expected to be resumed in Moscow within two weeks.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 13 (AP)--Millionaire Nashua and eight others were entered today for the $100,000-added Monmouth Park Handicap tomorrow, and it should be like taking candy away from babies for the colorful syndicate galloper.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today adopted a change in its rules designed to encourage public utility companies to take a larger part in the development of atomic power projects with a minimum of red tape.
LONDON, July 13--The International P.E.N. Club completed today what was believed to have been the largest and most successful congress of its history.
MOSCOW, July 13--Soviet leaders sent a message to the West German Social Democrats today. This presaged a new turn in Moscow's dealings with various German political and economic groupings.
ATLANTA, July 13--Southern Democratic leaders assembled here tonight to consider means of strengthening their bargaining position at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month.

CHICAGO, July 13--Commission buying today broadened for wheat futures after a period of weakness in the early trade. The market moving up as much as 2 cents from the low spots, with July at times tight.
The President Adams, fourth of the American President Lines' luxury freighters, will leave today on her maiden voyage in the company's round-theworld service.
ROME, July 13--Pope Pius XII has acknowledged and lauded the fortitude shown by Roman Catholic clergy and laymen in the East European Oommunist countries who suffered persecution for their faith.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 13--Inspector Stuyvesant Pinnell, chief of Nassau detectives, today drew his own curtain of silence around the kidnapping of Peter Weinberger. It was similar to that of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which entered the case on Wednesday.
Superintendent of Schools William Jansen said yesterday that a bill would probably be introduced in the next Legislature to permit the establishment of community school districts in the city.

Directors of the Square D Company, manufacturer of electrical distribution and control equipment, yesterday voted to split the common stock three for one and increased the quarterly dividend by 10 cents.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 13-- Miss Ann Harriet Lubin, daughter of Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner, and Mrs. Lubin, of 1095 Park Avenue, New York, was married this evening to Lawrence Benjamin Buttenwieser. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Buttenwieser of New York and Bedford Village.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13-- An antitrust suit filed against the Philco Corporation in 1954 was ended today by consent decree in United States District Court here.
PARIS, July 13--Representatives of the Tunisian Government angrily broke off their talks with French officials today.
Woes keep piling up for Cleveland's Indians in their futile chase of the front-running Yankees.

Shipments of refined copper to domestic fabricators in June dropped to the lowest level since last August, when much of the copper industry was on strike. The monthly report of the Copper Institute said yesterday that deliveries had fallen to 128,573 tons from the 140,587 tons shipped in May.

FROM Ridgewood, N.J., a reader writes to ask for help with a baking problem. The bottom of a sponge cake she made recently had a thick rind "as tough as shoe leather." She reported that her oven had recently been checked, so it did not seem the temperature could have been wrong.

President Victor Paz Estenssoro of Bolivia is considering establishment of an advisory stabilization council to curb the nation's spiraling inflation. The project is interesting for several reasons.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 13 --Mrs. Celina Garden Herbert of New York was married here this afternoon to Antonio Arraiz of Westport and Caracas, Venezuela, in the Congregational Church.

RIO de JANEIRO, July 13-- A public debate on Brazilian foreign policy has begun here as President Juscelino Kubitschek prepares to fly to Panama for the conference of hemisphere Presidents.
BUENOS AIRES, July 13-- Provisional President Pedro Eugenio Arantburu has begun a personal campaign to restore peace in the Argentine Army and heal a split with Roman Catholic Rightist nationalists.

Japanese garment makers are shifting from cotton blouses to dresses and other apparel, a section of the United States industry charged yesterday. Japan recently restricted exports of blouses to the United States.

I think they are among the most striking and picturesque features of that land of green.

WATERTOWN, N.Y.-- For more than a century the Thousand Islands section of the St. Lawrence River had been one of New York State's great vacation areas. It is famous for its fishing and boating; there is good swimming.

Last week the Warner-Chilcott Laboratories of Morris Plains, N.J., announced the discovery of releasin, a highly elusive female sex hormone which, when it is produced in sufficient quantities, may save seven one of ten infants who are threatened with stillbirth. It is estimated that 140,000 unborn infants may be saved each year out of an estimated 200,000 in this country alone.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 14-- President Eisenhower's physicians said today that his recovery from surgery had "gained momentum" and that he was "steadily regaining his strength." But by the time the first frost comes, dead leaves and fruit stalks begin to stand out. Soon the border looks bare indeed; the shrubs can break this flatness.

The swing to the liberal arts has become an accomplished fact in teacher education. Greater emphasis on liberal arts has been a major theme at educational conferences in recent years. ZURICH, Switzerland, July 15 --Business in Interhandel common stock dominated the share market last week. Turnovers exceeded anything known for many years. Some of the leading Swiss banks placed single orders for 500 Interhandel shares at one time. Day after day the price kept rising.

MOSCOW, July 13--A treasure trove of rare Jewish and Hebrew historical documents, manuscripts and books has been gathered in Leningrad, it became known today, They are being catalogued by outstanding Soviet scholars.

CHICAGO, July 15--Last week's market was notable for the relative steadiness of wheat futures during the heavy marketing season, a slump in July soybeans, and the strongest demand for oats in a long time.

Another significant step on the long and rocky road toward a United States of Europe has been taken as a result of the Fresh National Assembly's endorsement of the project for a European supranational atomic energy community to be known as Euratom.
The steamship charter market has rebounded this month from the doldrums of late May and June. Last week, for the second time in a row, rates climbed and volume was good.
WASHINGTON, July 15--The return to Washington today of President Eisenhower, who still is convalescing from his operation June 9, has raised serious questions about his trip to Panama this week.
ALGIERS, Algeria, July 15-- A French force clashed today with a strong rebel band near Nedroma, in western Algeria.

Ever since 1950 Prof. George Katona and his staff at the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan have been asking questions of their fellowconsumers. Is business getting better or worse? Will your own position be better or worse a year from now? Are you going to buy a new house or a home in the next year?
WASHINGTON, July 15--The International Monetary Fund reported today that 1955 saw even greater progress than 1954 in the direction of reducing exchange controls and restrictions around the world.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 15-- Monetary authorities have just announced the latest measure on the outstanding commercial debt. It is estimated at $240,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 15-- The Eisenhower Administration has about two weeks more to complete the legislative record it will take to the voters in November.
If the National League could make up its mind as to the winner of the pennant in that circuit, the world series could start this week.

ATLANTA, July 15--Miss Ellen Birk, president of the Wellesley College class of '56, became the bride this evening of Howard William Phillips, a law student at Harvard. The ceremony was performed in the Standard Town and Country Club by the Rev. Jacob M. Rothschild.

WASHINGTON, July 15--Lastminute changes in Operation Alert 1956 have cut considerably the original plan for week-long absences of top officials. The White House and defense agencies made the changes.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 --All of the competition on the second day of Larchmont Race Week today was by ninety-two of the smallest centerboard craft that had morning starts.
WASHINGTON, July 15--The Soviet Embassy put out today a breezy description of the forthcoming issue of USSR, a pictorial monthly magazine the Russians will distribute in the United States.
For New Yorkers who had not gone away for the week-end, the biggest attraction in town yesterday was the Wanamaker fire.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 15--President Gamal Abdel Nasser was greeted today with a floral shower in Sarajevo, spiritual seat of Yugoslavia's 1,500,000 Moslems.
LOS ANGELES, July 15--Oscar Miestchaninoff, Russian-born sculptor, died at his Hollywood home yesterday.
Despite annual production equal to or exceeding that of the United States, Russia is encouraging the import of machine tools from the West, a metal trades editor has reported.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America is seeking a wage increase of 28 cents an hour and improvements in fringe benefits for approximately 35,000 East Coast shipyard workers.

WHAT mother hasn't urged her balky youngsters to "eat up that nice lunch; hot food is good for you in the summertime"--while she herself sips iced tea as a substitute for the noontime meal. With just a little ingenuity and a wise selection of foods attractively offered, it is possible to revive waning appetites of children during the hot weather.
Miss Waverly Scott and Francis Melville Skinner were married yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by the Rev. Edwin J. O'Brien.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 --Music from the prolific pen of Cole Porter will be the theme of a ninety-minute musical revue, "The Cole Porter Festival." It will be presented as the initial offering on the "Ford Star Jubilee" series over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Oct. 6.

Gen. J. Fred Miles of Louisville is no military genius. He is a field marshal of oil wells, banks, refineries, pipe lines, steamboats and race horses. He commands a business empire that runs into the millions of dollars. He acquired it the hard way, with ninety-nine per cent toil and one per cent luck.
A verbal battle is in prospect before the City Planning Commission next Wednesday over a proposed change in the zoning law.

MILWAUKEE, July 15 (UP)-- The league-leading Milwaukee Braves swept a double-header with Pittsburgh today. They won the opener, 3--2, on a basesloaded walk in the eighth and took the second game, 4--1, behind young Taylor Phillips, who scored his first major league victory.
BONN, Germany, July 15-- Jawaharlal Nehru has put himself on record in support of freedom for the Soviet Union's satellite countries.
LOUIS NORMAN NEWSOM, the Great Showboat, moved majestically across the room on the eve of the All-Star game last week and swiftly buttonholed his victim. Bobo's eyes were sad, his expression pained.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 15--Tim Holland of the Rockville Country Club regained the Long Island amateur golf title today. In a scheduled 36hole final at his home course, Holland defeated the 1946 titleholder, Mal Galletta of North Hills, with a birdie at the thirtyseventh hole.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 15--Fear of reprisal is hampering the defense of S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon, one of his defense attorneys charged here today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) --Secretary Quarles said today that there was in progress a study of military manpower that could involve "far-reaching changes" in the American armed forces.
There is a substantial movement of business into the city despite "occasional sensational reports" to the contrary, the City Planning Commission reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) --Brazil has contracted to buy twelve surplus coastal freighters from the United States at a total cost of $8,326,344. The unit price is $693,862.

WASHINGTON, July 15--The White House campaign strategy for dealing with President Eisenhower's illnesses is reminiscent of advice given by the White House staff in 1936 when President Franklin D. Roosevelt was seeking a second term.
Subway travelers were urged last night by the Transit Authority to use west side lines because of disruptions on east side arteries as a result of the Wanamaker Building fire.

A fire in the empty old John Wanamaker store building was pronounced under control at 6:45 o'clock last night, twentyfive hours after it was first reported. But it was still billowing gray clouds, with occasional flare-ups of orange flame.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) --Homers by Lou Berberet and Jose Valdivielso paced the Washington Senators to a 7-3 victory today after Wally Burnette's sixhit pitching in his major league debut enabled the Kansas City Athletics to gain an 8-0 triumph in the first game of a doubleheader.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 15--Jordan walked out of an emergency meeting of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission today because of its support of a resolution calling on her to halt raids into Israel.
Courage, stamina and resourcefulness were needed by the more than 600 firemen who fought the Wanamaker blaze Saturday night and yesterday.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 15 (Reuters)--Each opposing party leader today forecast certain victory in the current national general elections. The voting began in the north on Friday and will be held here Tuesday.

New Yorkers battled yesterday to cope with disrupted subway lines but were promised some relief for this morning's travel peak.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company achieved record sales and earnings in the first half of this year. The net profit of $26,234,963 exceeded the earnings for all of the calendar year of 1955.
WASHINGTON, July I6 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had suspended a stock offering by the Military Investors Financial Corporation of Houston, Tex.
BONN, Germany, July 16-- The heads of government of West Germany and India subscribed today to controlled and supervised disarmament as a means of securing world peace and the welfare of all nations.

CHICAGO, July 16--The Dodgers made it two straight over the Cubs today but only after extreme harassment for them and the Ladies Day throng of 35,958, largest Wrigley Field crowd of the season.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- President Eisenhower vetoed the $2,136,400,000 military public works bill today on the ground that it carried a Congressional invasion of executive authority.

Despite a slight decline last month, building contracts awarded in the eastern part of the country broke virtually all records in the first half of 1956, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation, publisher of construction reports.
JOHN RINGLING NORTH, a vigorous man of 52, is almost as devoted to following his instincts as are the quadrupeds of the huge circus he bosses.
MARION, Ohio, July 16 (AP)-- Dr. Frederick C. Smith, former Republican Representative from Ohio died in Marion General Hospital today after a long period of failing health. He was 72 years old.

Sanderson Porter has leased the entire seventh floor of the fifteen-story office building at 72 Wall Street. Occupancy of the 18,000-square foot space will consolidate operations of the engineering and construction firm that are now spread over six floors in 52 William Street.

LONDON, July 26--Today American buyers and representatives of the United States press settled down to a strenuous three days at London's wholesale fashion houses. This is the third year of the London fashion week, organized for overseas buyers and press.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 16--The defense of S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon started laying the groundwork today for a thorough courtroom review of Marine recruit training.
PITTSBURGH, July 10--The "Greatest Show on Earth" played under canvas tonight for the last time.

SAGINAW, Mich., July 16 (AP) --Arthur R. Treanor, a former executive of Michigan's Booth Newspapers, Inc., died today at his Saginaw home. His age was 73. He retired in 1946.
BERLIN, July 16--A leading East German official acknowledged today that some state industrial enterprises had set production norms that "grossly violate" workers' interests.

WASHINGTON, July 16-- Democratic and Republican supporters of the Administration's civil rights bill won their first test in the House of Representatives today. They defeated by 151 to 103 a Southern Democratic attempt to stretch out debate.

WASHINGTON, July 16--Admiral Arthur W. Radford's conception of the United States' long-term military future is receiving sympathetic consideration in high quarters of the Government outside the Pentagon.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 16-- President Iskander Mirza of Pakistan expressed concern about Palestine today.

NEAR-BY farmers who grow green beans are not com plaining about the weather in recent weeks. It has been ideal for that native American vegetable, which ranks tenth in popularity among fresh produce (potatoes being first).

The Independent Grocers' Alliance (I. G. A.) Stores announced yesterday that completely automatic food stores, utilizing a combination of electronic equipment and conveyor belts, would be installed in about a dozen test areas beginning in September.

Eddie Arcaro's ride aboard Blue Banner of the Rokeby Sta ble decided the outcome of the main race at the Jamaica race track yesterday. Refusing to give up in the stretch against a strong challenge on the part of the favorite, Arcaro brought Blue Banner home by a head.
TWO summer replacement programs of unusual in terest were seen for the first time yesterday afternoon on Channel 4.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP)--An eleven-man syndicate headed by a pair of radio executives plunging into baseball far the first time paid a record price of $5,500,000 today for the Detroit Tigers and Briggs Stadium.

MILWAUKEE, July 16 (UP)-- Henry Aaron's line drive home run over the 402-foot mark in center field gave the Milwaukee Braves a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today. It was the seventh straight triumph for the league-leading Braves.
A former salesman who told the police that he was "just trying to be helpful" when he twice telephoned the parents of kidnapped Peter Weinberger was arrested yesterday.
William Tully of Yonkers and Henry Van Rensselaer of Greenwich, Conn., won the New York State clay court tennis doubles championship yesterday.

Synthesis of a second hormone from the body's master gland-- the pituitary--has been announced in the Journal of the American Chemical Society by a team of chemists at the Cornell University Medical College, New York City.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16--The Disarmament Commission instructed its working subcommittee today to continue negotiations for the limitation and control of armed forces along lines suggested by the Western powers.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- The Senate voted tonight to increase Federal grants to the states for needy aged, blind and disabled persons so they would get at least $5 a month more.
AT fashionable Lord's a team of American college court tennis players is engaged in a three-day match with Oxford and Cambridge.

BERLIN, July 16--A. D. N., official East German news agency, indicated today in a dispatch from Moscow that the Soviet Government had decided to abandon all attempts to negotiate on German unity with Dr. Konad Adenauer, West German Chancellor.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 --The African continent will continue as the locale of the next two Warwick Productions films, Irving Allen and A.R. Broccoli, the company's producers, have decided.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- President Eisenhower more than doubled his normal convalescent work time today in his first day back at the White House office.
BONN, Germany, July 16-- Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, has assured Bonn he will not recognize East Germany, the West German Information Office announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 16-- Negotiators for the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America met for two hours today. They made no apparent progress toward settlement of the sixteen-day-old strike. The meeting was recessed until 2 P.M. Wednesday.

MOSCOW, July 16--The Soviet leadership warned today that Communist-led countries and parties abroad, while privileged to develop according to their own needs, must not abandon proletarian internationalism and international contacts.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)-- Trevor Gardner, former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, believes the United States may develop an intercontinental ballistic missile ahead of the Soviet Union, according to testimony released today.
A call for an emergency appropriation of Federal funds to put more radar on the nation's airways system was the highlight of a ceremony yesterday opening a new hotel next to La Guardia Airport.

Farmers in this state are rapidly discovering the advantages of irrigating crops in dry spells. But as in other parts of the country, their right to use the water needs clarification, a conference of legislators, officials and experts from nine northeastern States was told yesterday.
Trade show activity picked up here yesterday with three major semi-annual events in progress.
Walter Alston, the Brooklyn manager, admitted that he had lectured his players between games of the twilight-night double-header at Milwaukee last Friday night.

Commodity futures were mostly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was light. Coffee, rubber, cottonseed oil, wool, tin and burlap rose; potatoes, copper and hides declined, and sugar and cocoa were mixed.
PARIS, July 16--The meeting tomorrow in Paris of the finance ministers of seventeen European nations will be dominated by what might be called the too successful economic recovery of West Germany.

Net sales and earnings of the Continental Can Company for the six months ended June 30 were the highest for any comparable period in the company's history, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, board chairman, reported in the semi-annual statement released today.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits moved in Supreme Court yesterday to obtain injunctions against operators of three large duck farms in Suffolk County and to prevent them from continuing operations.
BUENOS AIRES, July 16-- Argentina's financial mission to the United States hopes to obtain at least $400,000,000 in "emergency" credits, an authorized spokesman said today.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP)--Motor vehicle production in United States factories has strengthened slightly. The car makers built 111,504 cars and 21,825 trucks last week. This contrasted with a slow start during the Independence Day week that brought out only 68,110 cars and 11,505 trucks.
Norman Edward Webster, senior partner in Webster, Horne Elsdon, certified public accountants at 50 Broadway, died on Sunday at his home, 390 West End Avenue. He was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 16--"It is hard to understand," wrote Dorothy Thompson in her syndicated newspaper article today, "why the Presi dent and the Republican party do not propose Sherman Adams as a candidate for Vice President."
PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, July 17--They buried the circus here before an overflow crowd.
CHICAGO, July 16--Orville E. Hodge, auditor of public accounts in Illinois, resigned today under an investigation of alleged misuse of public funds.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 16-- Governors of the six New England states, ending a three-day conference here today, asked the White House to establish quotas for Japanese textile imports.

FORT DIX, July 16--An Air Force investigation continued today into the crash of the C-118 on Friday in which forty-five persons were killed.
Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, has ordered dock workers to stay on the job today, and not to mark his release from jail with mass demonstrations.

CINCINNATI, July 16--In the first inning of the getaway game between the Giants and the Redlegs at Crosley Field tonight, the first three Giants hit the first three pitches delivered by Cincinnati's Art Fowler. Don Mueller singled, Red Schoendienst singled and Willie Mays was safe on an infield error, filling the bases.
MOSCOW, July 16--The United States declared today that the Soviet Union was holding at least ten officers and enlisted men from two missing United States planes.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- Poland protested today against alleged flights over Polish territory by United States aircraft in late June and early July.

THE long awaited run of school tuna off Long Is land's shores has arrived. They moved in over the week-end and those who were waiting for them in their favorite section of the Atlantic brought in heavy catches.
DETROIT, July 16--The Chrysler Corporation announced today nine new management appointments aimed at strengthening for the company for intensified competition.

JERUSALEM, July 16--Premier David Ben-Gurion was expected to tell Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, that final settlement of the Israel-Arab dispute could be brought about only by direct negotiations.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 16--Substantial support for Governor Harriman as the Democratic nominee for President appeared tonight to be developing among New Jersey convention delegates in the populous northern part of the state.

The Maternity Center Association, Inc., 48 East Ninetysecond Street, will benefit from the Dec. 19 performance of "Happy Hunting" at the Majestic Theatre. The new Lindsay and Crouse musical will star Ethel Merman.
Maurice P. Davidson, founder of the City Fusion party, which helped to elect the late Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, died yesterday at his home, 355 River side Drive. He was 76 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16-- Chief Federal District Judge Michael J. Roche refused today to overrule a court order calling for issuance of new mariner papers "forthwith" to seamen barred from West Coast docks as security risks during the Korean War.
Restriction of imports as a means of maintaining defense industries was criticized strongly yesterday in a report released by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
DUBLIN, July 15--Sybil Connolly has gone Russian in a really magnificent collection of autumn models that won enthusiastic applause from an audience of international fashion experts.
OTTAWA, July 16--The Canadian Government introduced today its bill for sharing the nation's wealth with the provinces so that have-nots will get as fair a proportion as the haves.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 16--Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century carded a 41, 39--80 to earn medalist honors in the qualifying round of the twelfth Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at the Metropolis Country Club today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 16 --The International Civil Aviation Organization voted today to establish a panel of experts to recommend measures for meeting problems of the jet age.

Wayne Bethea, a Bronx heavyweight, gained the unanimous decision over Jimmy Slade of the West Side in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Bethea weighed 194 pounds, Slade 180 .

In a market full of eddies and tide rips, stocks rose yesterday to new peaks. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks touched a record high at 348.67 and closed at 346.88, up 1.21 points. The industrial average made a new historic high at 586.36 and closed at 583.34, up 2.23 points.

If there has been one achievement that the present Administration seems to have set its heart on, next to bringing the Federal budget into balance, it has been to see the Gross National Product (the nation's total output of goods and services) reach an annual rate of $400 billions.
WASHINGTON, July 16--The Senate overrode Southern opposition tonight and confirmed the President's nomination of Solicitor General Simon E. Sobeloff to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.

CAMBRIDGE, England, July 16--The first of six major European cemeteries and memorial chapels for the American dead and missing of World War II was dedicated here today. RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 16-- Seven witnesses appeared today before a special Suffolk County grand jury investigating charges that bookmakers and other gamblers had operated under the protection of county officials.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture opposed today a bill to make surplus cotton available to textile mills in this country.
MANILA, July. 16--The Senate ended the Philippines' technical state of war with Japan tonight by ratifying the San Francisco peace treaty of 1951.
TRENTON, July 16--The State Legislature failed today to override Gov. Robert B. Meyner's veto of a bill to legalize boardwalk and amusement park games of "skill."

The sponsor of the "Goodyear Playhouse," a long-running drama series on the National Broadcasting Company television network, is considering a proposal to drop the program and present a film series on Tuesday evenings from 8:30 to 9 o'clock.

SINGAPORE, July 16--About sixty suspected members of dreaded Chinese secret societies were rounded up by the police last night. The arrests were made in the first all-out drive to control the sinister groups that have held the colony in the grip of terror for years.

A $100,000 public participation box-top project for the benefit of the United States Olympic Committee went over the top yesterday. WASHINGTON, July 16--The Government reported today that Amerians earned income at a record rate again in May.

Gary, Ind., borrowed $4,089,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of sanitary district bonds due serially on Jan. 1 from 1958 to 1986.
GENEVA, July 16--World economic growth in the last ten years has set a record, Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, said here today.

Twelve firemen were injured fighting a four-alarm fire yesterday afternoon in a factory at 9 and 11 West Fourth Street, near Mercer. This is just six blocks from the Wanamaker building.

SILVER BAY, N.Y., July 16 --Christian workers have been crucified on trees in isolated areas in Southeast Asia, mission executives reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 --The hard sounds of practical politics at the Democratic National Convention next month will be softened by the singing voice of Frank Sinatra, according to the publicity division of the National Democratic Convention Committee.

DESPITE the continuing popularity of conservative jewelry, men are leaning more and more toward "gimmick" cuff links and key rings.
WASHINGTON, July 17--Civil rights legislation moved forward in the House of Representatives today. However, it was stalled on the Senate side.
LONDON, July 17--A political dispute arose today in Nigeria, one of Britain's rich "model" colonies in West Africa. Like the Gold Coast near by, it is on the verge of independence.
DETROIT, July 17 (UP)--Will Harridge, the American League president, today notified the Detroit Tigers the league owners had unanimously approved the announced sale of the club.
WASHINGTON, July 17--The Office of Defense Mobilization is pressing for a speed-up of tests to determine the extent and quality of nickel deposits in the Philippines, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP)-- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to create thirty-five judgeships.
NEWARK, July 17--The Public Utilities Commission today approved plans by the Erie Railroad to make Hoboken the principal terminal for its passenger train service.

Oil, aluminum and construction issues shot forward in yesterday's stock market, with the result that The New York Times industrial and combined averages both made new highs.

BALTIMORE, July 17 (AP)-- Don Ferrarese pitched a threehitter and Bill Wight followed with a six-hit job as the Baltimore Orioles swept, a doubleheader with the faltering Chicago White Six by 5-3 scores before 21,209 fans tonight.

The Metropolitan Opera Association announced last night that it had canceled the 1956-57 season because it could not agree with the American Guild of Musical Artists on the status of Robert Herman, a stage director.
