WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) --The American home will be the topic for speeches by seven women members of Congress at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month.
MOSCOW, July 17--Nikita S. Khrushchev delivered a slashing attack on Western concepts of a "free world" during a reception at the Kremlin tonight.
The thirty-two-family apartment house at 1260 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Geisinger Germain, operators, from the 1260-62 Grant Avenue Corporation. M. Kenner was the broker.

MOSCOW, July 17--The Soviet Union and East Germany signed a joint statement today reiterating the stand that the unification of Germany was impossible without direct negotiations between the East and West German Governments.
The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation turned in the highest sales for any quarter and any six months period on record, according to the semi-animal statement issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)-- Futures trading in agricultural products ran at a record level during the fiscal year ended June 30, the Commodity Exchange Authority reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17-- The Plymouth Monthly Meeting of the Society of Friends told a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that it had employed Mrs. Mary Knowles as an expression of Christian belief.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) --The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved today President Eisenhower's five nominees to the United Nations General Assembly despite a protest against one --Paul G. Hoffman.

Bill Colleran, director of the "Hit Parade" and television spectaculars, has been assigned to do the directorial chores for the first feature film in the wide-screen Cinemiracle process. Louis de Rochemont is the producer.
PARIS, July 17--France rejected today the latest Soviet proposals for uncontrolled disarmament by the voluntary action of individual states.
The Disarmament Commission of the United Nations has wound up its most recent deliberations and has once again referred the problem back to its "working subcommittee."

Twenty years ago today the world crossed one of those watersheds of history that mark the end of one era and the beginning of another. Rebel generals in Spanish Morocco raised the standard of revolt and the Spanish civil war began.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is completing the purchase of two office building sites, one on each side of the Avenue of the Americas between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets:
LONDON, July 17--Common shares continued to improve on the stock market here today and most Government stocks showed increases of about 226d (35 cents) on the 100 unit.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) --The House of Representatives accepted President Eisenhower's veto today and passed a $2,300,000,000 military construction bill omitting Congressional curbs on guided missile and military housing programs.

Carl Sherman of 590 West End Avenue, treasurer of the New York State Democratic Committee and State Attorney General from 1923 to 1925, died yesterday in Larchmont, N.Y., where he was on vacation. He was 65 years old.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 17--Mrs. Peter Pesci of Dellwood upset the defending champion, Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis today in the first round of the twelfth Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at the Metropolis Country Club. The score was 4 and 3.
TRENTON, July 17--Gov. Robert B. Meyner criticized the State Legislature today for its failure to assure an extension of rent control before recessing last night until Sept. 17.

MILWAUKEE, July 17--Victory came at last to the Giants tonight. They upset the leagueleading Braves, 8--6, in eleven innings, but while snapping their seven-game losing streak and Milwaukee's winning skein of the same number, the New York club lost face.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses surrendered unconditionally yesterday to the Central Park mothers in the Tavernon-the-Green dispute. The mothers won the two goals they

CHICAGO, July l7--The purchase of Steven's Candy Kitchens, Inc., from Mrs. Walter A. Krafft by a group of Chicago business men was announced today. The transaction was disclosed by Rodney O. Daly, the company's new president and chief executive officer.

The Lexington Avenue IRT subway will resume full service by 8 A.M. Friday for its 250,000 daily riders. This will, be the sixth day after flooding from the Wanamaker fire undermined its roadbed last Saturday at the Astor Place station.
GENEVA, July 17--The Soviet Union has challenged the United States to a contest in the field of education.

A shimmering sun fashioned of golden wire by a New York sculptor and a little copper man that was cast by a Sumerian artist 4,500 years ago, new acquisitions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will go on display today.
WARSAW, July 17--Recent charges of anti-Semitism in Poland will be among matters inquired into by three members of the New York Board of Rabbis who arrived here yesterday from Moscow.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 --This was the first day of three that some part of the Larchmont Yacht Club's big Race Week fleet was not rendered hors de combat by uncooperative Long Island Sound breezes.
LONDON, July 17--The outgoing Gold Coast Cabinet summarily dismissed its representative here today.

WASHINGTON, July 17-- President Eisenhower received little to brighten his convalescence today when Republican Congressional leaders briefed him on his legislative program's prospects in the closing days of Congress.

CHICAGO, July 17. (AP)--The Wimbledon champion, Shirley Fry of St. Petersburg, Fla., won a first-round-match in the national clay-courts ten is championship today while seeded men players turned in second-round victories.

ROME, July 17--The report that Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, had suffered arsenic poisoning in Rome caused general amazement here today. When she departed for New York last May it was said here that the Ambassador was in a rundown condition" from overwork and needed rest and a "general physical check-up."

The council of the Organization of American States will meet in Panama today in connection with the 130th anniversary of the first inter-American conference, convened there in 1826 by Simon Bolivar. On Saturday the council meet
The man who shot and killed the Soviet Minister to Poland in Warsaw on June 7, 1927, arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
Julius Gerber, former executive secretary of the New York Socialist party, died on Monday night in his home at 130 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 85.

OTTAWA, July 17--(Canadian Press)--Virtually the entire $60,000,000 Eastern Canadian boxboard industry has been accused by the Restrictive Trade Practices Commission of having maintained an illegal price-fixing combine since 1935.

LONDON, July 17--The second day of London's fashion week was ushered in by Jacqmar with a collection of forty models especially designed for the American trade. In fact, the prices were announced in dollars. This Jacqmar collection combines impeccable tailoring with exclusive world-famous Jacqmar fabrics. These are eminently "ladies clothes"--simple and elegant--in fact, real British classics.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 17-- Citizens of the Gold Coast went to the polls today to tell Britain what kind of independence they want within the Commonwealth. Their choice is between centralized government and a federal system.
Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregularly lower yesterday. Trading in most markets was dull, but the domestic sugar contract registered the most activity of the year.
Johhny Kucks, the Yankees' right-hander, became the major leagues' most successful hurler this season as he blanked the Detroit Tigers, 4--0, at the Stadium last night.
WASHINGTON, July 17--The State Department revealed today a program to spend $3,500,000 in Israeli pound's on fortyfour cultural, scientific and humanitarian projects in Israel.

The General Electric Company, one of the nation's largest industrial enterprises, chalked up another record in sales and earnings for the first six months this year, according to the semi-annual report issued by Ralph J. Cordiner, president.

ALBANY, July 17 (AP)--Republican legislative leaders said today that suspension of the state's campaign to wipe out brucellosis in dairy cattle indicated "inexcusable ignorance" by the Harriman administration.

Fourteen Ohio State Penitentiary inmates who volunteered last month to be injected with live cancer cells have experienced "a marked local reaction" to them, Dr. Chester M. Southam said here yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., July 17 (AP)--Anne Quast of Everett, Wash., won the last three holes today to rob Meriam Bailey of Palatine, Ill., of an upset victory in the first round of the women's Western amateur golf championship.
New York's dock labor chief was released from jail yesterday. He pledged himself to "fight for the best agreement we can get" from waterfront employers in contract talks that begin Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 17--The Senate passed tonight a bill calling for major innovations in the Social Security program. The bill would set up a system of disability insurance and lower the retirement age of women to 62.
A HARD-DRIVING flamboyant man who defeated one revolt and is bringing about another faces an uphill political fight in the Philippines.
Yesterday was Anniversary Day in two agencies.
WASHINGTON, July 17,(UP) --The Small Business Administration reported today that it doubled its lending activity in the fiscal year ended June 30.

SKYSCRAPER excavations in town were only raw, gaping earth wounds until the Rockefellers, raising their Center twenty-five years ago, put fancy boarding around the job with ports for what came to be known as "sidewalk superintendents."

WASHINGTON, July 17--Intensive White House pressure is being brought to bear on Republican Senators to persuade them to vote against the Democraticbacked Hell's Canyon project. The bill would authorize, a high Federal dam in Hell's Canyon of the Snake River on the IdahoOregon border.
CHICAGO, July 17--Wheat futures eased a little today on free selling following the sensational upturn yesterday.
Exporters are finding increased advantages in use of the Colon Free Zone in Panama as an "advance base" for sales to Latin America, a trade group was told yesterday.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 17-- Note to the girl in charge of menus at John Kucahickas diner in White Plains, N.Y.: Make the top item for Friday swordfish steak. Your boss caught a 250-pound broadbill today about fifteen miles south southeast of Montauk Point.
MANILA, July 17--President Ramon Magsaysay will visit the United States.
A local home finally has been found by Sol Hurok for his importation of the Old Vic from London. Mr. Hurok has obtained the Winter Garden, where the troupe will settle down on Oct. 23.
PANAMA, July 17--Panama and Costa Rica adopted precautionary security measures today in connection with the forthcoming meeting of American Presidents here on Saturday.

The law of supply and demand, working within the structure of the sugar quota system, raised prices for the raw commodity yesterday.

The State of Michigan borrowed $16,000,000 yesterday in the public market on two issues of serial bonds. The money will be used to extend its system of limited access highways.
Trains World Airlines told the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington yesterday that world air transport needed another American globe-girdling service.
Governor Harriman's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination was again associated indirectly with former President Harry S. Truman yesterday.

When the clock ticks off adjournment for this election-year session of Congress there may be time for sober afterthoughts about the erratic handling of appropriations for the United Nations technical assistance program over the last three years.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) --A joint Congressional conference committee agreed today on a compromise bill to authorize construction of the first atomicpowered merchant ship.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP)-- Pittsburgh's Dick Groat delivered a two-out, two-run tenthinning double tonight, enabling the Pirate pitching ace, Bob Friend, to score his fourth straight Victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, 4--2.

THE SMALL, four-pound to ten-pound turkeys featured frequently at meat counters lately are a good buy for many summer menus. They may be roasted and served cold at a picnic, barbecued over an outdoor grill, or presented at home with suitable seasonal accompaniments.
WARSAW, July 17--The carrot of material gain as opposed to the stick of political pressure will figure increasingly in the incentives offered by Communist planners to the Polish population.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17-- The presidents of Pacific Coast Conference universities opened the way today for possible "melioration of penalties" against senior students declared ineligible to play football this for receiving illegal financia1 aid.

Grants totaling $425,893 have been awarded to Harvard University, Yeshiva University, and Loyola University in Chicago, by the National Institute of Mental Health. The grants are intended to develop a mental health curriculum for theological students.
The Department of Health held out the hope yesterday that 1956 woud prove to be a "low polio" year in the city.

Dr. Malcolm Goodridge, a general medical practitioner and specialist in internal medicine here for many years, died Monday in his home at 333 East Fifty-seventh Street after a long illness. Dr. Goodridge was 83 years old.
PARIS, July 17--The Tunisian delegation, which broke off negotiations with French negotiators last Friday, returned to Tunis today.

LANSING, Mich., July 17-- Gov. G. Mennen Williams called today for immediate legislative action to increase and extend jobless benefits. But the Republican-dominated Legislature, meeting in special session, showed no inclination to act on his recommendations.
WASHINGTON, July 17-- Egypt turned definitely to the West today for help in building the High Dam at Aswan on the Nile.

The Senate is studying the return of assets seized from German nationals during the war. The proposal is tied to the payment of war damage claims of United States nationals against the West German Government.

BALTIMORE, JULY 17--Mr. and Mrs. William Goldsborough Nicholson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Chase Nicholson, to James Marshall Tuck of New York and Paris. He is the son of Mrs. Snowden Fahnestock of Washington and S. Pinkney Tuck of Paris and Geneva.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) --Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said today President Eisenhower's re-election would plunge this country into an unprecedented era of "irresponsible government and a lack of leadership."

CINCINNATI, July 17--Walter (Smokey) Alston, the manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, whose alleged "gutless" charge against his players was headlined in local papers, regards the incident as closed.

Ingrid Bergman, who has been living in Italy for seven and a half years, will return to this country in the fall in connection with a television appearance on the "Ed Sullivan Show."

PULA, Yugoslavia, July 17-- Advocates of peaceful coexistence from three continents meet tomorrow at Brioni to suggest steps for winding up the "cold war."

Tommy Goodwin plays golf in the same spirit of adventure in which he hunts for buried treasure. The sun-tanned, strapping athlete makes Westchester his bailiwick for part of the year and spends seven months in the Bahamas.
Cotton futures rose 1 to 3 points (5 to 15 cents a bale) yesterday in light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices moved within a 12-point range.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP)--Ted Williams' 400th major-league ome run--a majestic 430-foot drive into the right-field bleachers--beat Kansas City, 1--0, for Boston tonight. The Red Sox took the first game of the twilight-night program, 10--0.

CINCINNATI, July 17--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wilfred Sagmaster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Sagmaster, to Leonard Reade Fahs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Z. Fahs of Weehawken, N.J. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

NEWARK, July 18--The Prosecutor of Union County admitted today before the joint legislative committee studying wiretapping that on three occasions he had intercepted telephone conversations. State law forbids wiretapping.

The Metropolitan Opera may, after all, lift its golden curtain on Oct. 29.

Five new housing projects costing $77,865,000 were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission in a race to beat the July 31 Federal contract deadline. The projects will provide low-rent apartments for 4,900 families.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 --R.K.O. is taking no chances on Diana Dors' slipping away. The studio has signed Britain's version of Marilyn Monroe to a multiple picture contract.

WASHINGTON, July 18--A Democratic Eenate subcommittee accused the Eisenhower Administration today of a secretive and dangerous relaxation of controls on Allied shipments to Soviet bloc nations.

WASHINGTON, July 18--By a voice vote today the Senate approved the highly controversial Customs Simplification Bill, the first major foreign trade measure to gain approval in this session of Congress.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18-- The National Broadcasting Company is planning a filmed situation comedy series based on "Baby Snooks," the famous character created by the late Fanny Brice.

Leallah's reputation as the "wonder filly" of the season grew at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The 2-year-old daughter of Nasrullah took the $22,100 Astoria by almost a length over Marullah, to the satisfaction of the form followers in the crowd of 21,491. Leallah, owned by Charlton Clay, paid $2.70.

PARIS, July 18--The first steps were taken today toward a non-supranational and limited European project for developing nuclear energy for peaceful purposes. The move is in contrast to the supranational pool plan being negotiated by six continental nations.

Second-quarter sales and earnings of the Johns-Manville Corporation were the highest for any three-month period in its history, L.M. Cassidy, board chairman, reported yesterday. Half-year sales also set a new high record.

Circus performers whose names are on the "unfair" list of the American Guild of Variety Artists for ignoring picket lines must pay a $2,000 fine before the union will permit them to appear on the Ed Sullivan television show July 29.
Charles P. Sullivan, former District Attorney of Queens County, died last night at Flushing Hospital. His age was 70. Mr. Sullivan's residence was at 142-30 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

The Babylon, L.I., Union Free School District 3 yesterday borrowed $1,468,000 on an issue of bonds maturing serially on June 1 from 1957 to 1985. WASHINGTON, July 18-- The Government is prepared to move against thirteen individuals and companies it believes have been guilty of marketing "defense nickel" at sharp profits.

WASHINGTON, July 18--The Senate opened formal debate tonight on the controversial Hell's Canyon power project. Democrats charged the Eisenhower Administration, meanwhile, with putting extreme pressure on Republican Senators to vote against the bill.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 18 --A proposal by a suburban police chief for a tri-state communicating system to control traffic congestion on main metropolitan highways gained impetus today.

BONN, Germany, July 18-- The West German Government and its Opposition agreed today they could not accept the procedures laid down by the Soviet and East German Governments for the reunification of Germany.
The United States Court of Appeals upheld unanimously yesterday the conviction and five-year sentences imposed on two labor union officials charged with a conspiracy to extort $64,000 from dairymen.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York breezed through her first test in the national clay courts tennis tournament today, defeating Virginia Carpenter of Oak Park, Ill., 6--1, 6--1.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) --Representative Carl Hinshaw, Republican of California, said today the recent crash of two airliners in the Grand Canyon probably had occurred because the two pilots had been sightseeing.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- John Foster Dulles left it up to the military experts today to decide whether there should be a reduction in United States ground forces, here or abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) --President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill authorizing a $4,000,000,000 foreign aid program to bolster free nations for the next twelve months. However, he has a fight on his hands to get that much money.

CINCINNATI, July 18--A fourrun first inning, capped by Sandy Amoros' home run off Johnny Klippstein, was decisive for the Dodgers at Crosley Field tonight. They beat the Redlegs, 6--3, and Carl Erskine gained his seventh triumph.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. is offering for public subscription today a new issue of $50,000,000 of Inland Steel Company first mortgage 3 per cent bonds at a price of 100 to yield 3.47 per cent. The obligations will come due on July 1, 1981.
ALBANY, July 13(AP)--State tax collections are $39,000,000 ahead of last year's pace, the administration reported today. Republican sources predicted a $20,000,000 budget surplus.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. July 18--No chilled vodka was served by the Soviet delegation at the international summer banking school at Rutgers University tonight. No caviar, either.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 18-- Of all the game fish in the sea, none--when fighting the hook and line--can outjump the mako shark.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 --The Larchmont Yacht Club's thirty-first junior day, marking the start of open junior sailing on Long Island sound in 1956, today drew the largest turn-out of young skippers ever gathered for one regatta in the east.

PANAMA, July 18--Provisional President Pedro Eugenic Aramburu of Argentina notified Panama, today that he would accept an invitation to attend the conference of Hemisphere Presidents opening Saturday.
Cotton futures moved 1 point up to 11 points off yesterday. Only the May delivery was firm. Business was light all day.
WASHINGTON, July 18--The House Ways and Means Committee marched up the hill and down again today in a playful test of sentiment for tax relief.
LE HAVRE, France, July 18-- Maurice Thorez, secretary general of the French Communist party, proclaimed unity of action with French Socialists as the party's major goal today.
MANILA, July 18--Albert F. Nufer, 61-year-old career diplomat, arrived here today to take up his post as United States Ambassador to the Philippines.
The Transit Authority has dismissed the president of the American Transport Union from his job as a subway car maintainer. The authority charged him with unauthorized absences and other infractions.
Higher education in this country received a record $142,149,000 in gifts during 1954-55, a gain of 7.4 per cent over the previous year's high.

THE invitation arrived in an envelope that was covered with the printed informa tion, in the brightest of red, white and blue letters that the "world's heavyweight championship" was to be decided in Toronto next Wednesday night.

LONDON, July 18--Aquascutum has been the makers of fine coats since 1850, when its founders started tailoring in Nash's Regent Street for men only. It was not until 1900 that the concern branched out into women's wear.
MILWAUKEE, July 18--For his part in the uproar at County Stadium last night, Ruben Gomez, the Giants right-hander, today was fined $250 and suspended for three days.
VIENNA, July 18--Matyas Rakosi, First Secretary of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party, has resigned. He is to be succeeded by Erno Gero, a First Deputy Premier.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)-- The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved today legislation providing for this country's participation in the new International Wheat Agreement for three years beginning Aug. 1.

The President of the Republic of Egypt, Gamal Abdel Nasser, with his collaborators was staying at the invitation of the President of the Federal Peoples Republic of Yugoslavia, Josip Broz Tito, on a state visit to the Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia from July 12 to 19, 1956.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP)--Mayor Richard Daley pledged today the help of all city Government forces to fight the spread of poliomyelitis on Chicago's West Side.
A 6-week-old baby was fatally injured and three other persons were hurt yesterday in a gas explosion that destroyed a house in Long Island City, Queens.
Enough votes to nominate Adlai E. Stevenson for President on the second ballot at the Democratic National Convention were claimed yesterday by one of Mr. Stevenson's New York supporters.

SAN JUAN, July 18--Four officials of the Commonwealth Government testified today that air service from Puerto Rico to the United States mainland was inadequate. They said Puerto Rico needed better service if it was to maintain the pace of its economic development.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18-- Discord that has troubled the Plymouth monthly meeting of the Society of Friends over a $5,000 award from the fund for the Republic was emphasized today before a subcommittee of a House Committee on Un-American Activities.

It wasn't difficult to pick the winner of the $10,000 race that headed Jamaica's program yesterday. All a horse player had to do was to bet on the only stakeswinner in the line-up of six 3year-old fillies.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Action on the wage and hour act took place on two fronts today.
The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in the first six months this year registered the highest sales and earnings for a first half-year period in its history, Morse G. Dial, president, reported.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 19--Ransford J. Abbott, former New Jersey State Highway Commissioner, died of a heart attack today while he was at the wheel of his car. The car swerved off Route 38, five miles east of here, and crashed into a telephone pole.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 19-- Capt. Frank Mundus, the "monster" fishing skipper of the Cricket II, had Louis and Mrs. Edith Roberts of New York as his guests today.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday changed the date of its special meeting in September to avoid convening on a religious holiday.

Ramon Magsaysay, who rose from a village lad to become President of the Philippine Republic, is the subject of a biography that John Day will publish in the autumn. The co-authors of "The Magsaysay Story" are Gen. Carios P. Romulo and Marvin M. Gray, an American who for several years published The Manila Evening News.
MOSCOW, July 19--The reputations of two famous Yiddish writers of the Soviet Union who disappeared in late 1948 were publicly rehabilitated today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)-- The man who built the atomic submarine Nautilus believes "our entire culture and civilization will have to be changed" in a generation or two if the problem of dwindling power resources is not solved.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Eisenhower Administration announced its first balanced budget today. The surplus in the fiscal year 1956, which ended June 30, was about $1,754,000,000. It was the first Federal surplus since fiscal year 1951.

BANNING, Calif., July 19-- Clarence Mott Woolley, former chairman of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, died last night in Hoag Hospital, Newport Beach. His age was 92. He had resided here and in Palm Springs for more than ten years.
WASHINGTON, July 19-- President Eisenhower will still be a convalescent when he leaves here tomorrow night for the conference of American Presidents at Panama.

BONN, Germany, July 19-- The Government informed a group of foreign correspondents today that it was deeply disturbed by the possibility that the Western Allies might decide to reduce the size of their forces in Germany.

JERUSALEM, July 19--Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, spent five hours alone with Israeli Premier David Ben-Gurion today. He explored the mood and temper of the Israeli leader, who has been threatening a sharper policy toward the neighboring Arab states.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July 19--More than a hundred barge captains of the New York Trap Rock Corporation will scan the skies over the Hudson River near here today. But they will not be interested in fleecy clouds. They will be looking for a yellow helicopter.

The will of the late Thomas J. Watson Sr., former chairman of the board of the International Business Machines Corporation, was filed for probate yesterday in the New York County Surrogate's Court.
LONDON, July 19--Sir Harold Caccia, Deputy Under Secretary of State in the Foreign Office, is to be the next British Ambassador to Washington.

Loans to business by leading New York City banks declined $39,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank also reported that reserves of member banks throughout the country were under less pressure at the close of business Wednesday than at any similar time since last January.

LONDON, July 19--Business expanded on the stock market today, especially in industrial shares, which closed strong. By contrast, oils lost some of their recent buoyancy, and a reaction in sterling lowered Government funds by 1s3d ,(17 cents), or twice as much.

ROME, July 19--Eleanora Garnett, opening the series of Italian fashion shows here, has straightened, simplified and more clearly defined the body line than in any of her previous collections.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Administration scored a major victory today for its "partnership" policy of power development. The Senate voted, 51 to 41, to reject a Democratic-sponsored bill authorizing a Federally built high dam in Hell's Canyon on the Oregon-Idaho border.
CINCINNATI, July 19 (AP)-- Who broke the big clock at Crosley Field? That was the question that exercised the Redlegs today.
Sharon Mauhs of Cobleskill, a lawyer and cattle breeder, was reported yesterday to be in line for appointment by Governor Harriman as State Conservation Commissioner.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 --Columbia has signed four key men for its movie version of the Edwin O'Connor novel "The Last Hurrah."

MILWAUKEE, July 19--Joe Adcock, the man who got hit twice the other night, did some hitting himself today. He was the top gun in a fierce fifteenhit offensive that brought the league-leading Milwaukee Braves a 13-3 victory over the New York Giants before 22,117 rainsoaked fans at County Stadium.

LONDON, July 19--The Government defeated in the House of Commons tonight, by 319 votes to 246, an Opposition move to cut the Colonial Office budget by a token sum of 5 ($14) as a protest over the handling of the Cyprus issue.

At 4:10 P.M. today the warbling sound of the sirens continuing for three minutes means that the public in New York City--this means you --is to take shelter at once and stay there until the three-minute steady, all-clear blast begins at 4:22. This is part of the first day's program of a nation-wide civil defense exercise.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 --There was better wind for the yachts today to break the monotony of little air or none that has been the main characteristic of Larchmont Race Week since Sunday. There were 190 starters for a romp in a sou'wester in the afternoon after 108 small ones had staggered through morning catspaws.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 19--Mrs. Henry Pomeroy Davison has offered Peacock Point, her estate on Long Island Sound, for the annual country fair to benefit the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown on Sept. 8. Mrs. Davison is honorary chairman of the benefit committee.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 19-- Daniel A. Fischheimer of Chicago upset Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the United States titleholder, today in the third round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.

Only a few hours before our new Ambassador to the Philippines, Albert F. Nufer, arrived in Manila it was announced that President Ramon Magsaysay would visit the United States early next year. WASHINGTON, July 19--The United States withdrew today its seven-month-old offer to help Egypt build a huge dam at Aswan on the Nile.
The Dearborn, Mich., School District borrowed $14,000,000 in the public market to finance building construction on an issue of bonds maturing serially on Oct. 1 from 1956 to 1973.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) --Charles E. Wilson, Secretary, of Defense, said today that differences of opinion in the Pentagon were "normal" in view of the complexity of defense problems.

WASHINGTON, July 19--The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight that current atomic tests in the Pacific had proved it was now possible to minimize the "widespread fallout hazard" from nuclear explosions.

Having had a neat elevengame winning streak snapped, the Yankees lost no time yesterday setting up plans for a new skein. They polished off Bucky Harris' Tigers, 7 to 3, in the series finale at the Stadium before 11,099.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 19--It is a courageous composer who believes he can add something to Shakespeare's poetry. Carl Orff, the German composer, has had the temerity to undertake such a task and his music justifies his audacity.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 19-- Plans have been furthered at recent luncheon meetings at the clubhouse for the annual Turf Charity Ball to be held on the night of July 28 in the clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Race Track.
Cotton futures market lost 10 to 15 (50 to 75 cents a bale) points yesterday. Business was moderate on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CINCINNATI, July 19--A two-run homer by Gus Bell in the sixth inning was enough to beat Sal Maglie, but the Redlegs added four more in the seventh to subdue the Dodgers, 7--2, at Crosley Field tonight.

Immediate recognition of the Motormen's Benevolent Association as bargaining agent for its members in the city's subways was asked yesterday at a Transit Authority departmental trial.

CHICAGO, July 19--Irving Mages, president of Mages Sporting Goods Company, Chicago, announced today that he has offered to buy a controlling interest in Davega Stores Corporation, operator of a chain of thirty sporting goods stores in the East, principally in New York and New Jersey.

Jean Lacombe, a Frenchman who is due to arrive here some time today on his eighteen-foot sloop Hippocampe, left Atlantic City yesterday morning without even saying where he hoped to tie up in New York.
From Erivan in Soviet Armenia has come a dramatic appeal to President Eisenhower to permit the return to the United States of a group of Armenians who emigrated to the Soviet Union during 1947-49.
The physician who has been treating Clare Boothe Luce, the United States Ambassador to Italy, said yesterday that "unquestionably" she had been the victim of "excessive amounts of lead and arsenic."
LAHORE, Pakistan, July 17-- Pakistani peasants are protesting against the Government's attempt to take them off land they have been farming for nine years.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, July 19--A nation-wide alert to test the Federal Government's ability to function in the face of a massive hydrogen-bomb attack opens tomorrow morning.

PITTSBURGH, July 19--A flurry of rumors of new industry proposals to end the national steel strike swept Pittsburgh tonight in the wake of President Eisenhower's expressed concern over the slow pace of negotiations.

CHICAGO, July 19--Most grains were firm and worked a little higher in the early trade this morning, but profit taking became the rule of the day on the upturn and the sharp recessions from the early top levels were registered before the markets steadied.

Plans for a new apartment building on the East Side were announced yesterday by George A. Bowman, Inc., brokers. They have sold two five-story tenement houses on plot 50 by 100 feet at 307-09 East Sixty-fifth Street, near Second Avenue, for the Michel family. The buyers were Carrie Komito, Samuel Bluth, Louis Fortgang and Sidney Offit.
WASHINGTON, July 19--The United States rejected outright today a Moscow protest earlier this month that United States bombers had violated Soviet territory on three days in June.
WASHINGTON, July 19-- President Eisenhower will leave by plane tomorrow night for Panama for a type of diplomatic conference that he has made his specialty.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 19 --Tallahassee city buses will start rolling again Aug. 2, almost one month after service was discontinued because of a boycott by Negroes here.
New Yorkers will be required to clear the streets and take shelter for fifteen minutes beginning at 4:10 o'clock this afternoon as part of the third annual nation-wide Civil Defense exercises.
BUENOS AIRES, July 18-- This cosmopolitan capital of the tango has become a "cow town" for a week.

Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, have selected the Eugene O'Neill tragedy, "Long Day's Journey Into Night," in preference to anything else to mark their return to the Broadway stage. Absent since 1951, the acting couple will portray the author's father and mother in the autobiographical drama.
MANILA, July 19--President Ramon Magsaysay said today that the basic needs of the people were the key to the battle against communism in the Philippines.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19-- United States scientists requested the cooperation of Latin-American Governments today in the earth satellite project.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19-- The Arab political world has taken two heavy body blows this week.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 19--Britain is heading into some bad labor troubles, it is agreed on all sides here in the heart of the British industrial world. Talks during the last three days with trade union officials, workers and employers in Coventry and Birmingham lead to the conclusion that the strike of about 35,000 workers against the British Motor Corporation Monday is almost inevitable.

Reflecting a sharp rise in sales, consolidated net income of the Gillette Company rose $16,209,877 in the first six months this year to set a record for any similar period. The report of Carl J. Gilbert, president, listed net sales at $102,933,090, which compares with $84,458,968 for the initial half of 1955.
WASHINGTON, July 19--The House of Representatives voted tentatively today to protect citizens from discriminations that would deny them their civirights because of their sex.

SHREVEPORT, La., July 20-- Mr. and Mrs. William Ormond White have made known the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Bragg White, to William J. Curtin Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Curtin of Auburn, N.Y.
PANAMA, July 20--Presidents of the American republics were gathering here today for the conference opening tomorrow.

Normally the costs of borrowing on commercial paper and bankers' acceptances follow each other up and down in the everfluctuating money market. However, on Thursday one went up and yesterday the other went down.

The nation's 3,800 broadcast ing stations ceased normal operations for fifteen minutes yesterday, as most went off the air and the rest into Civil Defense duty. It was the country's first full-Scale daytime test of its radio-control system.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 --Walter Catlett will portray his old friend, the late Gov. Alfred E. smith of New York, in "Beau James," Paramount's biography of the late James J. Walker. Bob Hope will star as the debonair New York Mayor.

WASHINGTON, July 20--Secretary of State Dulles' decision against aiding Egypt to build the Aswan High Dam was strongly backed within the State Department, in Congress and by the British, it developed today.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 20-- The west span of the $5,000,000 twin bridges connecting Long Beach with the mainland of Long Island at Island Park will be opened officially at 3 P.M. on Wednesday. The bridges will eliminate one of Nassau County's worst traffic bottlenecks.

Percy W. French, retired New York interior decorator and art dealer, died Thursday in a Morris Plains (N.J.) nursing home after a long illness. Mr. French was 85 years old and lived at 2 Beekman Place. His work embellished a past era of lavish expenditures by millionaire art patrons.

MONTVALE, N.J., July 20-- Elias Aron, a former manufacturer of men's and boys' hats and caps, died today at the Montvale Sanitarium here after a long illness. He was 83 years olds and lived at 11 Burton Place, Cresskill.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 20--An entertainment, dinner dance and fashion show known as "Hampton Night," will be held here on July 28 at the Bath and Tennis Club. The Suf-folk County Air Force Base's Nursery Fund will be the beneficiary.

When Prime Minister Nehru arrived in Yugoslavia for his talks with Marshal Tito and General Nasser he said "wearily" to the correspondents: "It really is extraordinary that we cannot meet in a friendly way without you gentlemen attaching the highest importance to it." The implication is that this was to be just a cozy little old home week in a pleasant Yugoslav resort.

Even the placing judges, with the photo of the finish in front of them, had trouble in deciding on the one, two, three order in yesterday's sixth race at Jamaica. It was a six-furlong sprint in which Howard A. Flanigan's Two Stars, the favorite, won by a nose from two fillies that dead-heated for second.
Just when the nation's private utilities felt they had beaten public power for this session of Congress, the House Appropriations Committee set them back yesterday for a bid loss.

ROME, July 20--Simonetta and Fabiani: The midnight garden showing of this husband and wife team was held at their house on the Appian Way under a full moon-- a setting as dramatic as their collections. The fashions they offered made many of us think back to the early cinema era of Jean Harlow and Myrna Loy as panels blew and drapery flew in the campagna breezes.
LONDON, July 20--Industrial shares turned irregular today after their advance yesterday. Most other issues were barely steady.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 19-- Turkey today started the observance of the four-day Kurban Bayrami (Festival of Sacrifice), the most important religious holiday of the Moslem religion.
The vanguard of the New York National Guard left last night for annual training maneuvers at Camp Drum, near Watertown, N.Y., and other areas.
The Transit Authority was accused yesterday of having caused the June 14 wildcat strike of subway motormen by blunders, bad faith and "doublecrossing" its men.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20-- Dr. Lightner Witmer, retired author, lecturer and international authority on the mentally retarded, died last night in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Devon, a suburb.

Existing legislation to control campaign expenditures in national elections has for years been hopelessly ineffective and totally unrealistic. Although present laws limit a candidate to spending $25,000 and $5,000 for Senate and House respectively, it is known that actual expenditures often run much higher-- over $100,000 per candidate for the Senate in one recent case.
PITTSBURGH, July 20-- Negotiations to end the national steel strike reverted today to the torpid state that preceded President Eisenhower's expression of concern Wednesday.

The Norwegian training ship, Statsraad Lehmkuhl is scheduled to arrive here Tuesday for an eight-day visit. The 1,701-ton auxiliary bark, which serves as a school ship in preparing young men for Norway's merchant marine, has aboard 150 students and twenty-six officers and crew members. She is commanded by Capt. Bjarne Bro.
Increased commuter rates on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad ranging from 18 to slightly more than 25 per cent were approved yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
LONDON, July 20--The British Government withdrew today its offer to help Egypt build the proposed High Dam across the Nile River above Aswan.

OLIVE HILL, Ky., July 20-- White and Negro boys and girls who recently abandoned a South Carolina work project sponsored by the Methodist Church because of threats against them have encountered no hostility here.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (UP)-- Smoky Burgess hit a two-run homer with two out in the last of the twelfth tonight to give the Cincinnati Redlegs a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The victory was the sixth in seven games for the Redlegs.
WASHINGTON, July 20--Democrats of the House Appropriations Committee voted today to force the Eisenhower Administration to begin a new $400,000,000 Federal atomic power program.

They love their tennis at the County Tennis Club of WestChester and they don't mix it with anything else. There's no swimming pool at the club, no golf course, no squash courts. Members join the club for just one reason--to play tennis, and they play it the day long until it is too dark, and the year long until the weather is too cold.

MILWAUKEE, July 20 (AP)-- Bob Buhl, a right-hander, threw a two-hit shutout and Henry Aaron and Toby Atwell smashed home runs to give the first-place Milwaukee Braves a 10-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
The Benjamin Chew, the first of four Government-owned Liberty ships being "upgraded" for more speed and more economical operation, has passed her acceptance trials.

RICHMOND, Va., July 20 (AP) --A dissident group of stockholders today won control of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corp. and ousted Joseph A. Howell as president. Its margin of victory was nearly 2 to 1.
BONN, Germany, July 20-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer called home his ambassadors in Washington and London today for information on reported plans to reduce the Western allies' forces in West Germany.
CANTON, Mass., July 20-- Doug Ford successfully began the defense of his Professional Golfers Association championship today.
The billion-dollar candy Industry has been firming its summer sales with new items that withstand heat and humidity. Traditionally, summertime has been the slow season for the candy business.
Commodity futures were dull and featureless in most New York markets yesterday. Volume generally was limited to evening of holdings for the week-end, Prices closed mixed.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)--Firstseeded Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., was upset in the quarter-finals of the national clay court tennis championship today by Sammy Giammalva of Houston, 7--5, 6--8, 6--3.

PARIS, July 20--An important new discovery of cave drawings by prehistoric man in southwestern France was reported today.
LONDON, July 20 (AP)--The International Wheat Council announced today that its new 1956-57 wheat agreement would become effective on Aug. 1.

BOULDER, Colo., July 20-- The support of Colorado's twenty-vote delegation to the Democratic National Convention was courted here today in personal appeals by Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.

Fewer than twenty paying guests today occupy the 1,300room Lincoln Hotel, described as one of the largest in the Times Square area. BONN, Germany, July 22 --Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has decided to inform four key allied governments that he is opposed to a reduction of conventional armaments and a withdrawal of allied troops from West Germany at this time.
WARSAW, July 22--Poland celebrated her National Day today. It was the twelfth anniversary of the foundation of the Polish Communist Republic.

ROME, July 22--Colorful collections of millinery, jewelry and fabrics wound up the autumn fashion showings here. Italian hatman, Cesare Canessa, shaped coal scuttle bonnets and cloches from vivid colored felt.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 --The Motion Picture Industry Council in a statement today protested the recent objection by the National Legion of Decency to the motion picture "Storm Center."

BOONTON, N.J., July 22-- Jules Gatesy and Jim Tingley of Shackamaxon had trouble putting today but little trouble anywhere along the fairways as they repeated their performance of yesterday to win the eleventh annual New Jersey State Golf

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 22--Bob Wilke and Larry Bell of the Lehigh Country Club, Allentown, Pa., won the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament today by beating Henry Kowal and Bill Bogle on the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) --House investigators warned manufacturers of military planes today to avoid any taint of "old school tie" favoritism in hiring retired military officers as top executives.
PITTSBURGH, July 22--As employes of steel customers flocked back to work from plant vacations, the steel strike last week took on a more somber look.
PARIS, July 22--A decree freezing prices, signed by Paul Ramadier, Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, was published yesterday. It limits prices to their present levels with limited exceptions.

Subsidiaries of the Sinclair Oil Corporation have agreed to purchase the crude oil and natural gas properties and other assets of the Southern Production Company, Inc., according to an announcement by the two companies over the week-end.
State Senator MacNeil Mitchell of New York said yesterday that he would propose to the Legislature a plan for the state to help the city solve its automobile parking problem.
The General Acceptance Corporation of Allentown, Pa., has an option to acquire the Securities Credit Corporation of Denver for about 132,000 shares of General Acceptance.
CANTON, Mass., July 22-- Three of the nation's leading professionals and one newcomer to the tournament gained the semi-finals of the Professional Golfers Association championship today.
PANAMA, July 22--President Eisenhower proposed today a special commission to "hasten the beneficial use of nuclear forces" throughout the Western Hemisphere, both in industry and combating disease.

IN SUMMER, Southern tradition dictates that hot corn bread accompany vegetable plates. Try this and also other quick-to-make breads with hotweather meals. Corn sticks, actually corn bread baked in special pans, might be served with a mixed vegetable salad.
All set to wind up a highly successful home stand with a grand flourish, the Yankees suffered a slight, though embarrassing, setback at the Stadium yesterday.
LONDON, July 22--Equity prices advanced on a broadening front in active trading on the stock market last week.
WASHINGTON, July 22-- Democratic leaders agreed today that President Eisenhower's health and his absences from the White House would be a major issue in the election campaign.

Following the conditional cancellation of the American and British offers to aid Egypt in the construction of the $1.3 billion Aswan Dam, the Soviets now declare that they have no present intention to finance the project.
A Brooklyn laborer was held in $15,000 bail yesterday pending trial for assertedly pointing a pistol at a policeman and twice pulling the trigger. If failed to fire.
IF the night be pleasant this coming Saturday, townsfolk may look upon a rare festival on the Riverside Drive dance mall at 105th Street.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 22 (AP)--An Air Force two-engine plane made an emergency laading here today after they pilot reported a collision with an unknown object, possibly another aircraft.
WASHINGTON, July 22--Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended July 21:

At the request of France the Security Council has voted with rare unanimity to recommend the admission of Morocco, the larger part of which was formerly a French protectorate, to membership in the United Nations.
A dizzying about-face by industry and union leaders resulted in a decision last night to resume negotiations to end the national steel strike.

Not a bashful man, Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht, president of the Reichsbank under the Weimar Republic and again under Hitler, has written an autobiography to demonstrate that he was almost always right.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP)--Mickey Vernon drove in five runs today as the Boston Red Sox stormed from behind to defeat the Detroit Tigers, 8--6.
A new miniature television camera and a portable transmitter, which combined weigh nineteen pounds and can transmit a picture to a relay station more than a mile away, were
WASHINGTON, July 22--Issues involving foreign aid, civil rights, atomic power and housing are the major obstacles to Congressional adjournment this week.

CHICAGO, July 22--Wheat and rye futures scored sensational advances early last week on the Government announcement that on Sept. 4 the export trade would be turned over to private exporters, who would be given subsidies in kind from Government stocks.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 22-- New Yorkers face restrictions on summer week-ends when they attempt to visit some of Fairfield County's near-by public beauches, picnic groves, and golf courses.
In both the ringing speech of President Eisenhower and the formal five-point declaration at the Panama meeting of American chiefs of state there was something of a new emphasis.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 22 (AP)--Changes in the rules for election to baseball's Hall of Fame were adopted today providing for admissions in alternate years by votes of the baseball writers and a special oldtimers' committee.

A public offering of 100,000 shares of common stock of Leeds Northrup Company is being made today by a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. at a price of $21.50 a share. Concurrently, Leeds Northrup is offering 15,000 shares of new stock directly to its employes.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 23-- A new Gold Coast Government was sworn in today, with Dr. Kwame Nkrumah as Prime Minister.
MINEOLA, L.I, July 23--The Garden City Jewish Center won its State Supreme Court battle here today for the right to use its property to establish the village's first synagogue.

In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola yesterday morning, Miss Camilla Marianne Gimbernat was married to Sgt. Richard Rhea Walker, U.S.M.C. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Raymond Gimbernat Jr. of Oyster Bay and Land's End, Smithtown, L.I.

BONN, Germany, July 23-- The Bonn Government is prepared to remind London that Britain cannot withdraw any of her armed forces from West Germany without the approval of a majority of the members of the Western European Union.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP)-- Johnny Temple singled home the winning run in the eighth inning tonight as the Cincinnati Redlegs defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4--3. Hershell Freeman, a relief pitcher, then squelched a ninthinning Pittsburgh rally.
LONDON, July 23--The British Government believes there has been "an essential change in the international outlook in the past two years," Prime Minister Eden told the House of Commons today.
Ambergris, paying $27.90 for $2, won the $23,100 Wilson Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

COVENTRY, England, July 20 --The walls of the new Cathedral of Coventry are about to rise. The reinforced concrete foundation of the building has been completed and most of it has been faced with stone.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) --John W. McCormack, House Democratic leader, said today that a Roman Catholic Vice Presidential nominee "would be a decided asset to the Democratic party" in the November election.

LONDON, July 23--Implied criticism of Earl Attlee, former Prime Minister, and other Labor party figures who have accepted hereditary peerages emerged today. It came in a resolution that will be presented for discussion at the annual Labor party conference in October.
MOSCOW, July 23--Airmen patrolling Soviet sky borders have instructions not to fire at planes that violate the nation's airspace, a ranking leader of the Soviet Air Force said today.
ROME, July 23--The two youngest children of Mussolini were declared today to be incapable of supporting themselves. They are to receive a pension from the Government.

CAIRO, July 23--The Egyptian Finance Ministry reported today it received assurances from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development that the proposed Aswan dam was economically sound only ten days before the West withdrew its offer to help the project.

WASHINGTON, July 23-- Harold E. Stassen, White House disarmament adviser and member of President Eisenhower's Cabinet, announced today his support of Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts for the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23-- Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice, explorer of the Amazon, author and member of the summer colony here for forty years, died here today at his estate, Miramar. He was 80 years old. He had been ill for the last month.
Carson Lundin, architect for a twenty-seven-story office building to be erected on the east side of Third Avenue from Forty-fifth to Forty-sixth Street, have estimated the cost at $5,125,000.

The National Broadcasting Company, still keenly interested in opening up a Sunday evening hour for the Dinah Shore and Bob Hope television shows, has renewed its efforts to bring about the necessary program realignment for the fall season.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) --Nine grants to help colleges and other organizations conduct research and demonstrations in hospital service and administration were announced today by the Public Health Service. The awards total $367,182.
The 14,600 days of Evelyn A. Paul as a secretary for Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) have spanned great changes.

The letter sent to Congress by David J. McDonald, president of United Steelworkers of America, and released to the press, contains many misrepresentations and distortions about wages and profits in the steel industry, it was charged today in a statement issued in behalf of the twelve steel companies involved in the negotiations with the steel workers' union.
Today's new film is "Phantom Horse," a Japanese drama in color about a young boy and his horse, at the Normaadie Theatre. Heading the cast are Ayako Wakoa and Yukohiko Iwatare.

The New York City Housing Authority plans to borrow $76,693,000 on temporary loan notes on Aug. 7 for twelve low-rent projects subsidized by the Public Housing Administration. The notes will be dated Sept. 4, 1956 and will come due on Feb. 8, 1957.
SANGLEY POINT, the Philippines, July 23--Admiral Arthur W. Radford said today that no reduction of United States military forces in the Far East was now being contemplated.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The House of Representatives passed the Administration's civil rights bill by a vote of 279 to 126 today.

Who owns the manuscript of Paul Gauguin's "Intimate Journals?" The question was posed yesterday in the form of a complaint in New York's Supreme Court. The suit asks that the French artist's literary-art creation be awarded to its rightful owner.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 23 --A four-point program designed to prevent integration of the races in Florida was unanimously passed today by the State Senate. It acted three hours after the State Legislature had convened in special session.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 --Twentieth Century-Fox Telivision Productions will expand its interests by entering the fild of TV commercials.
Cotton futures closed barely steady yesterday, 1 point lower to 11 points higher, with a moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.

In good health again, John C. Wilson is resuming his status as a producer much sooner than he thought he would. Mr. Wilson, who hasn't figured as a sponsor since he introduced "Quadrille" here in 1954, will put on "The Feathered Fauna." The Golden is to receive the Charles RobinsonJean Dalrymple comedy in midOctober.

NEWARK, July 23--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today risked being cited for contempt of Federal court. Through a subordinate he announced his intention to defy an order signed here by Federal Judge Alfred E. Modarelli.
LAST Saturday there was a yachting anniversary that was almost unnoticed and entirely uncelebrated.

WHEN Spaniards pack a lunch they usually tuck in a bottle of light, dry sherry, wrapped in wet newspapers to keep it chilled. At a Spanish beach party, in particular, sherry is ubiquitous, for the fortified wine Americans too often serve ...

BOSTON, July 23--Christian Archibald Herter, who was urged today by Harold E. Stassen for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination, is the kind of a diplomat who could talk down a Prussian officer intent on shooting him as a spy. He did so in World War I.
The International Longshoremen's Association, independent, has opened a campaign to increase workmen's compensation benefits in New York State.
DETROIT, July 23 (AP)--The auto makers are holding output fairly steady, although considerably below the seasonal average.
ABERDEEN, S.D., July 23-- Governor Harriman of New York accused President Eisenhower tonight of having committed "one of the most ignoble acts of any President" by "breaking faith with the farmers."

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission today tightened its rule governing small stock issues and proposed a new regulation aimed directly at penny" stock issues by new companies.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 23 --Percy A. Staples, president of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation, was found dead in his suite at the Hershey Hotel today. He had apparently died in his sleep during the night. He was 73 years old.

THE islands that are the delicate and mystical locale of this fable--or extended parable--are seven in number and three in dramatic relevance. The seven islands form a chain, something like a water snake swimming downstream, in the midst of the healing waters of the Ganges.

The property in the Bowery area that Charles Gulden, Inc., mustard manufacturer, occupied for ninety-three years has been sold. The Gulden concern is moving to Saddle Brook, N.J., and expects to be out of the old buildings by Aug. 15.

BEIRUT, July 23--Efforts for a settlement of the tax dispute between the Lebanese Government and the Iraq Petroleum Company have begun, but it was impossible tonight to learn whether any headway had been made.
The city-state, modern as well as historic, is back in the news. Therecent conference of May

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 23-- The first of four scheduled "Candlelight Concerts," presented on behalf of the Transylvania Music Camp, took place here tonight at the home of Judge and Mrs. Junios G. Adams.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The Government announced tonight the end of the 1956 series of nuclear tests in the Pacific.
Billions of checks may one day flow through the nation's banking system untouched by human hands.

LONDON, July 23--Miss Patricia Bromley was married here this afternoon to John Richard Franco Jr, in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, Chelsea. The bride is the daughter of Rear Admiral Sir Arthur Bromley, Royal Navy, retired, and Lady Bromley of 59 Cadogan Square. Mr. Franco is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franco of Detroit.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., July 23-- Gardner Callahan Teall, writer, editor and artist, died yesterday in the Northern Dutchess Health Center here. He was 78 years old and recently had lived at Ward Manor, a home for the aged at near-by Red Hook.
The American Jewish Congress laid the groundwork yesterday for a court challenge of what it calls a religious quota system of assigning probation officers to Children's Court.

EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, OPERATION ALERT., July 23--Soviet bloc nations in Europe more than doubled their orders for United States goods in the first half of this year, Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks announced today.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 22--The Benelux countries--Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg--are about to enter upon their first trade agreement as a unit.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23--The greatest honor baseball can bestow upon an individual went today to Henry Benjamin Greenberg and to Joseph Edward Cronin--Hank and Joe, as they were called, respectively, during their playing days and as they are called now that they are successful front-office executives.

CANTON, Mass., July 23-- Jack Burke, overcoming a fivehole deficit, gained the final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship in a thrilling extra-hole match today at the Blue Hill Country Club.
The Blaw-Knok Company, manufacturer of steel-making, construction and other industrial equipment, had @ net income of $3,557,972, or $2.27 a share, on sales of $78,000,000 in the first half.
LONDON; July 23--Worth, the oldest of the London dressmaking houses, appropriately enough headed the parade of designers showing autumn and winter fashions.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) --Congress completed today action on a compromise bill authorizing construction of the first atomic powered merchant ship by the United States.

Between early 1952 and 1956 the number of individuals owning shares in publicly held American corporations rose from 6,490,000 to 8,630,000, it was reported yesterday by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Jan Peerce, Metropolitan Opera tenor, returned yesterday from a month-long tour of the Soviet Union strongly convinced of the benefits to be won from a greater exchange of artists between the United States and the Soviets.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 23 --Capt. Walter E. Zimmerman, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Zimmerman, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Zimmerman, to Ensign Don Elliott Kennedy, U.S.N., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Banta Kennedy of St. George, S.I., New York. The wedding will take place in December.

WASHINGTON, July 23-- When President Eisenhower led the first Republican Administration in twenty years to office in January, 1953, many Americans with long memories were plain scared--about their bread and butter.

Ambrose Cort, who served for thirty years as principal of the William J. Morrison Junior High School (Public School 73), Brooklyn, died on Sunday in his home at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had lived since his retirement. His age was 82.

Warner-Pathe, a pioneer newsreel service, will be discontinued on Aug. 23. The service was founded in 1900 by Charles Pathe and was operated for the last nine years by a subsidiary of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc. The announcement was made yesterday by Warner News, Inc., the subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, July 23-- Nine Far Eastern countries lying in the shadow of Communist aggression received the bulk of United States economic and technical assistance in the fiscal year ended June 30.
PANAMA, July 23--President Eisenhower held separate private conferences today with ten Latin-American Presidents or Presidents-elect.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23-- Victor Seixas started in quest of his seventh Pennsylvania State tennis championship today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) --Senator William Langer made an unsuccessful bid today to advance President Eisenhower's postal rate increase bill.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. A. Bradhurst Field Jr. of Mostly Stone, Sloatsburg, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Pearsall Field, to George Robert Kaplan of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kaplan of Boston. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

Mayor Wagner has called for restudy of a new law that has required signs on the inside of apartment doors since July 1. The signs emphasize that doors leading to public halls must be kept shut as a fire precaution.

To anyone caught in the city's traffic maelstrom it is no cause for wonder that Commissioner Wiley took no time out the other day to celebrate his fifth anniversary as head of the Traffic Department. The Commissioner is the first to acknowledge that many problems still must be solved.

When France generously espoused Moroccan membership in the United Nations the whole question of the qualifications for such a membership was again automatically raised. The Security Council unanimously agreed that Morocco had those qualifications.

WASHINGTON, July 23--An Argentine financial mission seeking some $450,000,000 in loans completed today the "first phase" of its talks with Government agencies. It will leave tomorrow for a round of meetings with New York financiers.

Sales of the Davega Stores Corporation for the first quarter of its fiscal year were 11 per cent higher than in the three months ended May 31, last year. H.M. Stein, president, so informed stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday,...
PANAMA, July 23--The United States is planning a new policy in its program of LatinAmerican assistance and relations.

Cottonseed oil futures fell to new lows for the present movement yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. The decline was one of the sharpest of the year. Trading was active. Final quotations tumbled 35 to 70 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 427 tank cars.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 23-- Robert Steinmeyer of St. Louis, tied at the top with James T. Sherwin at the end of the fifth round, defeated the New Yorker today to take the undisputed lead in the national open chess championship.

Suslov and Kirichenko of the party Presidium went to France for the French Communist party meeting. Mr. Mikoyan slipped off secretly to Hungary and then not so secretly to Yugoslavia.

Capital Airlines will announce today an order for fourteen British Comet IV jet airliners.
EMERGENCY PRESS HEADQUARTERS, Operation Alert, July 23--High Government officials wound up their part in "Operation Alert 1956" at noon today and headed back to Washington.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 13-- Turkey badly wants a huge loan from the United States. More specifically, the Administration of Premier Adnan Menderes needs the funds to hold its prestige.
GUATEMALA, July 21--Three industries--one new, one existing and one about to start--have been approved in principle as regional industries by a group of Central American experts.
Rails rose sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but industrials made a modest retreat, coppers, chemicals and papers leading the march downhill.

During recent weeks I have made a thorough and thoughtful review of the political situation and I have concluded that in loyalty to President Eisenhower and to the principles and objectives for our country which he represents, I should do what I can to nominate Governor Chris Herter of Massachusetts for Vice President at the coming convention.

WASHINGTON, July 23--Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee assailed today what he describes as a new drive to create a general staff system in the armed services.
CHICAGO, July 23--Prices for grain and soybean futures were weak today in all pits during the forepart of the session.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23--The New York Giants defeated the Detroit Tigers, 11-10, in the twelfth inning of the annual Hall of Fame major league exhibition game today. Dusty Rhodes' two-run homer decided the contest for the Polo Grounders.
FLORENCE, Italy, July 23--The Boutique houses of Rome, Florence, and the northern cities show black and bright knitted sports clothes out front for winter.
LONDON, July 23--Light selling attributed to the auto strike and early Wall Street influences brought widespread small losses to industrial stocks here today.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 23--The survivors of Platoon 71 depicted S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon today as frustrated and depressed by his failure to instill discipline among them.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 23-- Last night the moon was full and there was a great swath of silver across the gently swelling sea as the "monster fishing" boat Cricket II passed the Montauk Point Lighthouse.

Michael F. Walsh, a retired justice of the State Supreme Court and a former New York Secretary of State, died Sunday night at his home, 1193 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, after a two-year illness. He was 62 years old.
TRENTON, July 23--Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. warned today that an "outright prohibition" of wiretapping would place every law enforcement official in New Jersey in a "strait-jacket."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 23--Excellent approaches and fine putting enabled Mickey Homa and Tom Goodwin to post six birdies on the way to a one-stroke victory in the Westchester County Golf Association's annual pro-amateur championship today.
LENOX, Mass., July 23--Contemporary music can be fun. The number of attractive pieces on a program of chamber music presented at Tanglewood tonight was gratifying.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23 (UP)--Lyman Hanover scored a length victory in the $4,000 Delaware Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Hugh Bell drove the winner over the mile and a sixteenth in 2 minutes 14 seconds.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) --The Philadelphia Electric Company reported today total revenue for the first six months of this year of $117,812,783, compared with $107,905,940 for the similar period last year.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 23--A cautiously optimistic look at the American economy, in terms of the historical perspective, was taken today at the opening of an annual week-long business conference at Stanford University.

In a desperate last stand against eviction from a doomed apartment house, a building superintendent threw acid at wreckers yesterday and then barricaded himself in his basement apartment. He was promptly dragged out by the police and charged with assault.
A contract was signed yesterday assuring the 1956-57 season of the Metropolitan Opera.
A 37-year-old New York City policeman, with five departmental citations, was accused yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court of stealing sixty-four used bed sheets.
A new industry peace offer is expected when the off-again, onagain negotiations in the national steel strike resume here this afternoon.

The Interstate Commerce Commission opened a public hearing yesterday on the application of the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company for permission to abandon its ferryboat service between Jersey City and Manhattan.
LONDON, July 23--A major strike in Britain's automobile industry started in low gear today. More than half of the workers remained at their jobs, defying union orders and picket lines.
BALTIMORE, July 23--Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, brother of President Eisenhower, was elected president of Johns Hopkins University today.
CAIRO, July 23--Dag Hammarskjold said today the ArabIsraeli cease-fire he arranged three months ago was in good working order.
Thirty-nine persons were recovered from lifeboats in a dense fog yesterday after a Panamanian tanker and a United States freighter collided at the entrance to New York harbor.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 23-- Representatives of industry and banking circles and the Commonwealth said today that air service between Puerto Rico and the mainland was inadequate.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP)--Joe Louis, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, today was de nied a wrestling license by the Illinois Athletic Commission because a commission physician reported he had a damaged heart.

There is this melancholy aspect to getting out of school and going swimming and hiking, playing baseball and tennis and admiring Mickey Mantle in person and on television: The vacation will end, inevitably, and school will resume.
JERUSALEM, July 23--Premier David Ben-Gurion's Government angrily demanded today an accounting from Dag Hammarskjold on the attitude of Jordan toward implementing the cease-fire agreement.
Erno Gero, new First Secretary of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party, has disclosed "wavering and procrastination" among Hungarian Communists in carrying out the new anti-Stalin line.
NEW DELHI, India, July 23-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, who has spent the last month looking into the troubles of Europe and the Middle East, returned today to a desk-load of Indian problems.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 --Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer apparently is not as confident as it was a few months ago that Grace Kelly will be returning here to do a movie in the near future. The studio had Princess Grace and James Stewart teamed, on paper at least, to costar in "Designing Woman."
CHICAGO, July 23 (UP)-- Herbie Flam swept two sets after the intermission today to defeat Eddie Moylan, 3--6, 6--3, 1--6, 6--3, 6--3, and win the national clay courts singles championship.
A major effort to promote greater integration of Negro and Puerto Rican pupils in the city school system is being mapped by the Board of Education.

Vladimir Golschmann, conductor of the St. Louis Symphony, who had not conducted the Stadium Symphony Orchestra since 1951, returned last night to lend his own particular brand of vitality to the Stadium season.

VIENNA, July 23--A summary of recent changes in Hungary and an indication of the direction the Hungarian leaders believe the country's affairs should now take were given today. They appeared in a resolution of the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party's Central Committee.
DETROIT, July 24 (AP)--The Baltimore Orioles took advantage of Bob Miller's wildness to score five first-inning runs and rolled to an 11-5 victory over the Tigers in the second game of....
WARSAW, July 24--Polish workers who rioted in Poznan in the last week of June will be tried early in August.

CORFU, Greece, July 24--King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece and the citizens of Corfu gave a warm welcome today to President Tito of Yugoslavia. The Yugoslav Communist leader, accompanied by his wife, arrived at this island in the training vessel Galeb, escorted by two destroyers.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- Nine grocery products companies that supply retailers with almost everything from beer to paper napkins got into trouble with the Federal Trade Commission today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- The White House set in motion a diplomatic reshuffling today with new assignments for four foreign service officials.

WASHINGTON, July 24--The national Consumer Price Index rose last month to 116.2, the highest level on record. This was eight-tenths of a point, or .7 per cent, and was attributed primarily to food prices.

TOKYO, July 24--Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu leaves tomorrow for Moscow and negotiations with the Soviet Union for a treaty of peace. He has more unified backing of the Government and people than seemed possible for any Japanese envoy a few days ago.

GENEVA, July, 24--Britain warned the United Nations today that unless the steadily rising expenses of internationtal agencies were curbed, she would have to reconsider her participation in their programs

WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J., July 24--Ernest A. Holmes, a marketing consultant for A.S. Bennett-Cy Chaikin, Inc., and Carlos Franco Associates, both of New York, died here on Monday in his home on David Lane of a cerebral hemorrhage.

Automation has at last won a bridgehead in one of the most difficult fields for it to conquer: retail trade. The Independent Grocers Alliance (I. G. A.) will open in September what it calls "completely automatic food stores" in a dozen test areas including New York.

Reneged, a black 3-year-old son of Revoked-White Samite, returned to the races at Jamaica yesterday after a lay-off of almost a year to win the featured seventh race, a $5,000 allowance event at six furlongs.
