HENRY HIGGINS, the only Shavian character who seems destined for a more enduring popularity than Candida and St. Joan, asks with his usual vehemence in the opening number of "My Fair Lady," "Why can't the English teach their Children how to speak?" If they could or would, he goes on, "these verbal class distinctions" would....
A part interest in the fee underlying the Stevens Building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street has been sold by the estate of Simon Ottinger to Webb Knapp, Inc.
The Gulf Oil Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries increased earnings 50 per cent in the first half this year, establishing a new record for any similar period.

Mrs. Irene de la Begassiere, who told the police she was the former wife of a French marquis, was accused last night of stabbing a young man identified as the son of Countess de Beaurepaire.
CUBI POINT NAVAL AIR STATION, the Philippines, Wednesday, July 25--Admiral Arthur W. Radford declared today that there still was a grave threat of Communist aggression.
NEW DELHI, July 24--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru took on today the additional responsibility of the finance portfolio.
MOSCOW, July 24--The name of one of the Soviet Union's most distinguished actors and producers, Vsevolod E. Meyerhold, was rehabilitated posthumously today.
CHICAGO, July 24--The expected gay dash of the Yankees through the West, calculated to finish the American League flag race for keeps, ran into an unexpected snag tonight.

The nation's largest passengercarrying railroads--the Pennsylvania and the New York Central --are ready to concede all firstclass traffic to the airlines. They will try to drive more frugal travelers into coaches.
This is the fourth in a series of articles analyzing the record of the Eisenhower Administration at the start of the Presidential election campaign.
The racketeer in advertising has a method all his own: THE offers a wristwatch "built to give years of service" for practically nothing. (Just invest $11.25 for a set of puzzles in a contest.)
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 --The Los Angeles Board of Education yesterday voted 4 to 3 to include $50,000 in its current budget to initiate an educational television experiment.
WASHINGTON, July 24Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield made a plea today for lower pay to railroads for transporting mails other than first class.

The City Planning Commission has, we think, acted wisely in drafting and approving a broad rezoning of the easterly parts of the Washington Square and Greenwich Village sections to harmonize with the present and prospective development of the entire region.
CANTON, Mass., July 24-- Jack Burke, the new Professional Golfers Association champion, proved today he could be an expert on links real estate.

Preliminary plans for redeveloping a 110-city-block area in downtown Brooklyn were laid before Mayor Wagner yesterday at City Hall. The overall cost, including private construction, has been estimated as high as $250,000,000.
Miss Basilia Livingston Welch was married to Wilfrid Ismay Abel Smith yesterday afternoon in the home of the bride at 116 East Sixty-third Street.

LONDON, July 24--A striking degree of bipartisanship was demonstrated again today in the House of Commons as the twoday debate on foreign affairs ended.
The Transit Authority won a temporary injunction yesterday forbidding the Motormen's Benevolent Association to strike the subway lines.
Ellis Knowles declares it is gutter nonsense" to regard 40year-old golfers as "old men." At the age of 69, Knowles acknowledges as much enthusiasm for the game as he did in his college days.
CAIRO, July 24--President Gamal Abdel Nasser angrily accused the United States today of lying about the Egyptian economy when it withdrew its offer to help build the High Dam at Aswan.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 24 (AP)--Fleetwood, a blackhulled yawl sailing out of Chicago, was declared the official over-all winner today in the forty-ninth annual running of the Chicago-to-Mackinac Island yacht race.
LONDON, July 24--Oil stocks responded to renewed American buying in late business today. Other markets, though still restrained by the auto strike, were firmer than yesterday.
PANAMA, July 24--All the Latin-American Presidents agreed here last week-end that close hemisphere cooperation was needed to propel this vast region along the road of economic development.

Last night at Ebbets Field the Dodgers got the help they have been needing from Duke Snider, Gil Hodges aad Randy Jackson. As a result, they beat the Redlegs, 10--5, before 22,239 joyfully noisy Flatbush fans.
NEWARK, July 24--A quonset hangar at Newark Airport is taking on a new look to meet the demands of large modern aircraft.
OCEANA, Calif, July 24 (AP)-- Ella Young, Irish poet and former University of California lecturer, died at her home here yesterday. She was 88 years old.

FOR many women, decorating a new home from scratch is a nerve-shattering experience. For Hanny Josephs, who did it herself without a decorator, it was a delightful lark. She's actually sorry now that it's finished.
Officials of the International Flower Show hiked over the concrete and marble vastness of the New York Coliseum yesterday and planned their spring planting early.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 19 points (95 cents a bale) off, with the weakness in the distant positions.
WASHINGTON, July 24--The Senate approved today a $4,110,920,000 foreign aid appropriation as the Eighty-fourth Congress pressed wearily toward the end.
WASHINGTON, July 24--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. was considering today what specific steps to take in view of the threat of a Federal judge in New Jersey to cite him for contempt of court.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (UP) The Philadelphia Phillies scored six runs in the sixth inning for a 7-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. Those six in the sixth helped Curt Simmons gain his sixth triumph against six losses in his sixth complete game of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- The Public Health Service announced today that seventeen states had returned part of their allotments of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine.
CANTON, Mass., July 25-- Railying in the afternoon round of the final, Jack Burke of Houston won the Professional Golfers Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- The House of Representatives ended abruptly today Democratic efforts to force the Administration to undertake a new $400,000,000 atomic power program.
A battle-by-battle account of the naval war between Japan and the United States will be published in November by DevinAdair. Called "Death of a Navy:

Everit B. Terhune, retired publisher of The Boot and Shoe Recorder and former senior vice president of the Chilton Company, publishers of trade magazines, died--yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital as a result of a hip injury. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) --The Department of Commerce said today consumer spending was the "basic supporting element" in the economy during the first six months of this year.

LONDON, July 24--The British Colonial Office has decided to appoint a commission of inquiry to investigate the dispute over banking practices between colonial authorities and Dr. Nnamde Azikiwe, Prime Minister of the Eastern Provinces of Nigeria, Dr. Azikiwe, Nigeria's most powerful politician, threatened last week to resign.

The reappraisal of Western military, political and economic policies is again underlined by the foreign policy debate in the House of Commons. This reappraisal is due to two developments which, in Prime Minister Eden's words, have changed the international outlook in the past two years.

BUENOS AIRES, July 24 (UP) --Crewmen of the Argentine liner Entre Rios, just back from the Soviet Union, reported today that former Russian residents of Argentina who went home on the liner's previous trips offered as much as $5,000 each to be smuggled back to Argentina.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock yesterday approved a plan for the reorganization of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation. It was the first time in seven years of negotiations that any plan had won court approval.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Wednesday, July 25--The New Castle Town Board reluctantly submitted early today to the overwhelming pressure of the community and enacted the severest building restrictions of any town in Westchester County.
CLEVELAND, July 24 (UP)-- Mike Garcia shut out the Washington Senators for the third time this season, holding them to three hits tonight. While the Cleveland Indians made twelve in an 11-0 triumph.
The tolls charged on the Pennsylvania Turnpike still are caught in the glare of financial and political headlights.

FORTY years ago, Prof. Edmond Bronk Southwick, entomologist and Shakespearean scholar, designed for the west side of Central Park what he called The Garden of the Heart. It spread over two acres of rocky hillside near the Swedish Cottage at Eighti eth Street, a glory of posies.
WASHINGTON, July 24--Two lawyers and an oil company were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today for alleged violations of laws to regulate lobbying.

CRISP, thin wafers are the ideal accompaniment for summer desserts--ice cream, puddings and fruits. Besides being thin and slightly brittle, they should be delicate in flavor for too district a taste would overshadow that of the dessert.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 24 (UP)--Governor Harriman of New York, here to "talk politics" with Gov. Frank J. Lausche, said today that his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination was "gaining strength every day."

TORONTO, July 24 (UP)--Archie Moore will risk a sure September shot at the world heavyweight crown tomorrow night in a fifteen-round fight with James J. Parker of Toronto at the Maple Leaf Baseball Stadium.

RYE, N.Y., July 24--Charlotte De Cozen of Montclair and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells posted a five-underwomen's-par 68 to lead the way in the qualifying round of the tenth annual women's Metropolitan Golf Association. Four-ball best-ball championship tournament today.

Net income of the Bulova Watch Company for the fiscal year ended March 31 rose 18 per cent to $3,483,190 from $2,951,821 in the previous year, Arde Bulova, board chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 --Tommy Munnell, the Pequot Y.C. teen-ager who was invincible during Larchmont' Race Week--except on Junior Day-- atoned for that deficiency by romping to victory as the fourday Eastern Junior Race Week opened under the auspices of Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- Harold E. Stassen's campaign to drop Vice President Richard M. Nixon from this year's Republican Presidential ticket ran today into the deadliest boomerang in recent American political history.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 --Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to day ordered "rigid" enforcement of the states's blasting regulations. He took this action to prevent a repitition of the dynamite explosion that occured yesterday on a Connecticut Turnpike construction site here.

Price movements on the New York commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless. Cocoa and hides rose, potatoes, cottonseed oil, wool and copper declined, and final quotations for coffee, sugar, soybean oil, rubber and burlap were mixed.
A panel of business men agreed yesterday that store sales of high fidelity sound instruments this year will reach a volume of more than half a billion dollars.
George A. Dixon, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in his home at 410 Park Avenue after a brief illness. He was 65 years old. His family long has been prominent in New York.

Three apartment houses occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 15, 17 and 19 East Eightysixth Street have been sold by the Sagamore Land Corporation to Alfred L. Kaskel, president of the Carol Management Corporation. Mr. Kaskel plans to erect on the site an eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building designed by Philip Birnbaum, architect.
The New York Red Cross Blood Program received 503 pints of blood Monday. Included were 203 taken at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, from employes of downtown concerns.
Thirteen of fifteen permanent guests--the only paying residents in the 1,300-room Lincoln Hotel--yesterday asked from $7,000 to $10,000 to leave their rent-controlled rooms.
City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses suffered a defeat yesterday in his effort to block construction of an office building.
There was no occasion for Ruben Gomez to dash for the Giant clubhouse last night in his heralded return engagement with Joe Adcock and the Milwaukee Braves.
WESTBURY L.I., July 24(AP) --Newport Honor won the one mile Dutchess Pace by a neck from Mighty Storm in 2:04 4-5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Merry Eden was third.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24--The Soviet Union denied today that a member of its delegation to the United Nations and a Russian employe of the United Nations Secretariat had attemped to persuade a former Red Army captain to return to his homeland.

It's all set for Sir Ralph Richardson and his wife, Meriel Forbes, to perform here in "Waltz of the Toreadors" under Harold Clurman's direction. The reassuring news was brought back from London over the week-end by Robert Whitehead, importer of the Jean AnouilhLucienne Hill script.

Memories of long-forgotten clipper ships were revived yesterday, when the three-masted Norwegian bark Statsraad Lehmkuhl sailed majestically up the harbor under full sail. The 258-foot vessel was handled smartly by her crew of 146 young trainees, who have come here for an eight-day visit. They are on a training cruise that forms part of their five-month curriculum.

A syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. is offering for public subscription today a new issue of $30,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation. The securities bear 3.8 per cent interest and will come due on July 15, 1981. They are priced at 100.
The long-rumored sale of Carnegie Hall became a reality yesterday. A New York realty concern bought the sixty-five-yearold concert hall from the company that has owned it since 1925.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24-- Victor Seixas and Arthur Larsen, former national titleholders, each lost a set today in the Pennsylvania State grass court tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.

Uranium's importance to Canada and the world may prove to be greatly overemphasized, according to Hardwick Stires, president of the Scudder Fund of Canada, Ltd. "The.... low content of uranium securities in our portfolio makes apparent our lack of confidence in the metal for the long term," Mr. Stires told a press conference yesterday in the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Helen Dryden, the nation's first successful woman industrial designer and once the highest paid woman artist, has had her semi-monthly Welfare Department check reduced from $39.20 to $30 because she refused to heave a drably furnished East Side hotel room.
The eighteen-year-old mystery of the disappearance of Isaac Babel, Soviet writer of Jewish origin, appears to be moving toward a solution.

TEL AVIV, Isreal, July 24-- Steps by an American leader of Reform Jews to introduce religious services in Jerusalem in accordance with the Reform ritual have stirred the Isreali rabbinate to organize resistance.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24-- The chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission envisioned today a mulitiplicity of problems for regulatory bodies to deal with as nuclear power takes its place in the utility field.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 24-- British Army public relations officials here took press representatives today to see the conditions prevailing at a detention camp is Kokkinotrimithia.
DETROIT, July 24--A delicate cleaning has uncovered a panel painting by Jan Van Eyck at the Detroit Institute of Arts.
WASHINGTON, July 24--The Soviet Ambassador transmitted to the United States Government today a formal disarmament appeal by the Supreme Soviet to the parliaments of the world.
MUNICH, Germany, July 24-- United States Army commanders are worried about the deterioration of relations between the 100,000 soldiers under their command and the Civil population of Bavaria.
Robert G. Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, warned here yesterday against Communist efforts to drive a wedge between the United States and the British Commonwealth.
An Oslo bus company electrician will report for work at 7:30 o'clock this morning in the West Farms repair shops of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in the Bronx.
LEE, Mass., July 24--The San Francisco Ballet gave its formal East Coast debut tonight at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.
Gen. Simon Bolivar, who called thg first hemispheric conference at Panama in 1826, was honored yesterday on the 173d anniversary of his birth.
A television network is expected to pay Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures $500,000 for the rights to televise "The Wizard of Oz" twice.

The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday it was preparing a multi-million dollar damage suit against the General Motors Corporation.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 24 (AP)--District Judge Toby Morris today defeated Representative Victor Wickersham in a run-off primary for the Democratic nomination in Oklahoma's Sixth Congressional District.
BOSTON, July 24--Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts wore his best diplomatic poker face most of today.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- Southern Democrats blocked an attempt today to force the Administration's civil rights bill to the Senate floor for consideration. The House of Representatives passed the measure yesterday, 276--126.

Rails remained firm in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday but weakness in chemicals and coppers undermined the industrial list. The New York Times average--after making a new high--closed with a small loss on the day.
The city opened its modernized Staten Island ferry terminal at the foot of Manhattan island at noon yesterday.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 24--S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon led his platoon so far into Ribbon Creek that he was swimming and treading water shortly before six of his men drowned, two survivors of the night march testified today.
Industry and union leaders reached a tentative settlement yesterday on all major issues in the national steel strike.
WASHINGTON, July 24--A committee of Congress once called the Consumer Price Index "the most important single statistic issued by the Government."
FLORENCE, Italy, July 24--Roberto Capucci, Italy's youngest name fashion de signer, has topped his last season's success with further innovations in his evening collection.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- The Defense Department estimated today that the nation's sixth Forrestal-class aircraft carrier, to be built at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, would cost about $194,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 24--A House Government Operations subcommittee said today that indiscriminate hiring of outside experts and consultants by the Government had created "abuses" that should be regulated by the Civil Service Commission.
The Maryland State Roads Commission borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds maturing on Aug. 1 from 1957 to 1971.
The mighty king of the tyrant dinosaurs, leading the "march" of anicent Cretaceous bones at the American Museum of Natural History, has had a hall named after it.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 24-- The Rev. Conrad Klemmer, who from 1911 to 1947 was the only Estonian pastor of the Lutheran Church-Missouri doing organized church work in this country, died yesterday in his home here after a long illness. His age was 74.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 24-- Robert Steinmeyer of St. Louis played Anthony F. Saidy of Fordham University to a draw in forty-seven moves to retain his lead today after seven rounds of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.
NEW DELHI, India, July 24-- The British, who usually take a determinedly calm attitude toward India, are plainly worried about Soviet economic penetration of this country.
JERUSALEM, July 24--Maj. Gen. E.L.M. Burns, United Nations truce supervisor, warned both Israel and Jordan tonight against any attempt to seize Mount Scopus by military force.

PARIS, July 24--The Finance Committee of the French National Assembly appeared tonight to be hopelessly deadlocked in a dispute over methods of financing the exceptional military expenditures in Algeria.

Allergic as they are to victory, the Giants found another way to blow a game last night at the Polo Grounds. This time Bob Lennon, a substitute outfielder who was rushed into the contest strictly for defensive purposes, misjudged a ninth-inning liner and the league-leading Milwaukee Braves scored twice.

LONDON, July 24--Harold Macmillan, Chancellor of the Exchequer, called thirty of the most influential British and foreign bankers trading in Britain to the Treasury today to urge them to continue their tight rein on credit.

PARIS, July 24--In "Darkness at Noon," Arthur Koestler's profound indictment of Communist justice, the police interrogator confides to a doomed party leader: "The political utility of your confession will lie in its voluntary character." Later, he adds: Your testimony at the trial will be the last service you can do the party."

New York Telephone Company reported yesterday continuing gains in operating revenues and net income in the June quarter and for twelve months ended June 30.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24-- Current comment on the United States refusal to finance Egypt's High Dam at Aswan is an interesting example of the Arabs' critical and suspicious attitude toward the West today. It also demonstrates their willingness to believe the best of the Soviet Union.

The premier ship of the United States merchant fleet is now on her ninety-first voyage. On board is a man whose opinion will weigh heavily when the country comes to the final decision on a sister liner.
A sharp acceleration of Puerto, Rico's program to lure new industries was announced yesterday. The goal is 905 factories by mid-1963, more than twice the number developed so far under the program.

SPRINGFIELD, IIL, July 24 --Orville E. Hodge, the deposed auditor of public accounts of Illinois, was indicted here today on 276 counts charging confidence game, embezzlement and forgery. The indictment was returned by the Sangamon County Grand Jury.

CHICAGO, July 25-- Acme Steel Company, Chicago steel fabricator, has entered into and agreement to purchase the net assets, including physical properties, of Newport Steel Corpo-I ration, a Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation subsidiary, Acme announced here today.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that President Eisenhower seemed to have acquired more "vim and vigor" from his three-day trip to Panama.

The damaged freighter Fairisle rolled over in thirteen feet of water in Gravesend Bay early yesterday morning. The 449-foot vessel had been at anchr there since Monday afternoon.

AN all-Tchaikovsky program attracted an audience of 5,000 to Lewisohn Stadium last night. The attendance would have been larger had not rain, about a half hour before concert time, frightened away potential customers.
PARIS, July 25--Premier Guy Mollet agreed today to give the French public a chance to lend the Government funds for pacifying Algeria before collecting the money through taxation.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Attorney General Jacob K. Javits reaffirmed yesterday their support of Vice President Richard M. Nixon for renomination.
LONDON, July 25--Twelve thousand workers making bodies for British Ford cars today joined the strike of the automotive workers in the Midlands, where nearly 33,000 are out.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 25 (UP)--Former King Leopold, who abdicated in 1946, will return gas an adviser, on atomic energy for Belgius, an official post, it was announced today. The former king is now in Brussels.

WASHINGTON, July.25-The House voted today to set up a $5,000,000,000 "experimental" flood insurance program despite charges that it would saddle the nation with "a tremendous debt."

CLEVELAND, July 25 (UP)Herb Score pitched his ninth victory of the season and struck out ten batters in the process as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Washington Senators today, 11--3, for their fifth straight triumph.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)Plans were announced today to put the United States abreast of other nations in radio astronomy, a science in which it is said to be lagging.
CHICAGO, July 25.-The Yankees went back to running the show with a firm hand in the American League tonight..
WASHINGTON, July 25--The House voted 373 to 9 today to cite Arthur Miller for contempt of Congress.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25The defending champion, Louise Brough, was eliminated from the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern states tennis tournament today and a 17-year-old California girl gave a marvelous display against Althea Gibson.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)-- A Congressional committee said today hunting trips into Mexico by Joseph M. Swing, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, were "improper and unnecessary" and involved "improper use" of Government funds.
CAIRO, July 25--Sudanese Premier Abdullah Khalil was reported today to have said his country expected to buy heavy tanks and jets from Czechoslovakia.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)The House Rules Committee reversed itself today and cleared the $156,000,000 Fryingpan-Arkansas project bill for a vote by the House.
MOSCOW, July 25--There are indications the Soviet Union has achieved a record grain harvest despite relatively poor results in the Ukraine.

LONDON, July 25 (AP)--Bill Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., carried off the honors in the major individual jumping event at White City Stadium today.
LONDON, July 25-Britain's observance of the 100th anniversary of George Bernard Shaw's birth has touched off a critical trend toward downgrading his work as a playwright and social philosopher.
The nation's leading manufactuner of cigar-making machinery was charged with restraining trade yesterday and within half an hour had agreed to comply with Government recommendations.

The theory that Communists no longer subscribe to a doctrine advocating the overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence was aired yesterday in Federal Court at a trial of six men charged with such intent.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) --The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to legislation permitting automobile dealers to sue manufacturers who "coerce or intimidate" them.

State Senator Walter G. McGahan, Republican of Queens, has asked Mayor Wagner to rescind his appointment of the three members of the Brooklyn Sports Center Authority.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 25 -Real estate developers and building contractors banded together today in a move to upset in Supreme Court the new zoning law of the town of New Castle that slows runaway house construction to a walk.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 25-Jerome Blum, American painter, died here Monday after a long illness. He was 82 years ol.:

The Department of Welfare has taken another look at the case of Miss Helen Dryden, whose semi-monthly payments it had reduced from $39.20 to $30. Yesterday it announced they had been increased to $44.72.
King Hairan, a Florida-bred 2year-old, won the sixty-sixth running of the Great American at Jamaica yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 25President Eisenhower has faced a number of stubborn dilemmas in the last four years but no other problem on the home front has been comparable to the one on farms.
WASHINGTON, July 25Senator Eugene D. Millikin of Colorado, a powerful member of the Republican leadership, said a farewell today in the Senate.

JERSEY CITY, July 25--The Dodgers, who had been unable to produce a homer in three previous games at their Roosevelt Stadium home-away-from-home, found the range of the distant fences twice tonight to defeat the Redlegs, 2-1.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25-- An Atomic Energy commissioner defended here today the A.E.C. against charges that it was too slow in developing commercial nuclear power. The charges had been made recently in a House Appropriations Committee report.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation went back into the black in the second quarter, following the settlement of its five-month strike on March 20.
Soviet authorities appear to have launched a comprehensive but publicly unannounced drive to rehabilitate Jewish literary victims of past purges; both livine and dead.
On Aug. 3 the Ding-Dong School bell will summon thousands of preschool-age livingroom pupils to the television screen for Miss Frances' 1,000th appearance as teacher of this popular morning program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 --The National Broadcasting Company is storing up acorns in the form of new programs against a cold winter.

The sugar industry is making plans to fight harder to retain its customers and to get more of them.

DUBLIN, July 25--The "grave" position faced by the Republic of Ireland as a con-I sequence of inflationary pressures and a critical balance of payments problem was stressed today by Finance Minister Gerard Sweetman.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 25-According to evidence introduced today at his court-martial, S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon spent the afternoon of April 8 drinking vodka and mulling over the ides of taking his platoon into the swamps to teach it discipline.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 25--The development of a radar device for speedy surveying of distances up to fifty miles was announced today by the Signal Corps.

A conspiracy to hand over the annual sports show here to The New York Daily Mirror was charged in a Supreme Court suit yesterday. The producer of the trade exposition asked an injunction and $500,000 punitive damages, as well as compensatory damages.

New York City has borrowed $20,000,000 in anticipation of tax collections on an issue of shortterm notes bearing 2 per cent interest, the office of City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The notes are dated July 26 and will come due on Oct. 29.

Capt. Piero Calamai was appointed master of the Andrea Doria in December, 1952, when the luxury liner was ready to enter the Italy-North American service. Then 54 years old, he was one of the youngest officers to command a major Italian Line passenger vessel.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 25 (AP)--Mrs. Charles U. Bay's Greek Spy scored his first stakes victory today in the $24,500 Lamplighter Handicap before 25,137 persons at Monmouth Park.

LAHTI, Finland, July 25 (UP) --Billy Tidwell of Emporia (Kan.) State Teachers, tonight equaled the winning time of 3:46.3 for the 1,500-meter run made in the last Olympic Games. Joseph Barthel, the Olympic Champion, was third in the race won by Tidwell.
Msgr. John J. Carberry of Brooklyn was consecrated a Roman Catholic Bishop yesterday in a ceremony that reaches back to ancient Rome.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange eased 1 to 11 points yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)House opponents of legislation to authorize New York State to build new power plants at Niagara Falls won assurances from Senate leaders today that they would oppose efforts to revive the apparently dying measure.

JERUSALEM, July 25--Jordanian villagers attacked a team of United Nations military observers today near Jerusalem. Lieut. Col. E. H. Thalin of Sweden was seriously wounded by the Jordanian fire, United Nations sources said.
GENEVA, July 25--A major effort to straighten out the world radio frequency map is to be made in 1959.

CHICAGO, July 25--The strike interrupted operations of the Inland Steel Company at their highest levels, the company disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- The Board of Visitors to the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., today deplored a recent designation of academy students as officer candidates in the Naval Reserve, rather than as midshipmen.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25-- Robert Steinmeyer of St. Louis drew his eight-round match today to hold the lead in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP)-- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that farm production this year would fall short of last year's record levels.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 25-- Mass confusion over the sailing of courses and the resultant filing of protests in wholesale lots was the keynote of the second day of Eastern Junior Race Week.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Conferees from the Senate and House of Representatives agreed today on a compromise foreign aid appropriation of $3,766,570,000.

LONDON, July 25-Hardy Amies and John Cavanagh, most fashion experts attending the London collections agree, tie for first place. Amies builds his models on the "relaxed" empire line, which is never extreme, but subtly suggested by such devices as high belts and corselet waists on skirts.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 24--Premier Hermann Jonasson said today that foreign armed forces should not be stationed in Iceland in peacetime.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Spokesmen for The New York Times and the Cuneo Press of Chicago urged a Senate Post Office subcommittee today to reject a House-passed bill containing increases in second-class mail rates.

Capital expenditures by the General Foods Corporation are expected to exceed a record $2,000,000 a month during this fiscal year, stockholders were told at an annual meeting yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Ten thousand persons witnessed the dedication yesterday of a $40,000 mobile health center, the gift of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to its 3,000 members in Puerto Rico.

Two of the most honored teams in show business-Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse-have started mapping plans to collaborate on a musical version of 'Life With Father."

Steels gave the stock market a lift yesterday and, despite some selling near the close, the net result of the day was a small gain. Prospects for an early end of the steel strike were considered responsible.

DETROIT, July-25 (UP)-Frank House hit a three-run homer to cap a four-run eighth inning and give the Detroit Tigers a 6-2 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles today. House's four-bagger was his third in the last four games and his seventh this season.

Industry and union negotiators worked into the early hours today to clear the way for an end of the national steel strike this afternoon.

TLEMCEN, Algeria, July 6-- This town of 75,000 persons is known as the Pearl of the Moghreb (the Arabic word for Northwest Africa), but it is a jewel in a barbed wire setting.
OLD FORGE, N.Y., July 25 (AP)--Resort operators told a legislative committee today that strict enforcement of existing navigation laws would cut the number of boating accidents on the state's lakes.

The Board of Elections disclosed yesterday that it expected registration and voting in this fall's Presidential election to set a new high for New York City.

PORT DALHOUSE, Ont., July 25 (Canadian Press)--Hamilton's John Pearce, who yesterday won the singles event in the Canadian Olympic rowing trials, today took the high school singles championship for the second successive year in the seventyfourth annual Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

LONDON, July 25--Government funds failed to hold early gains on the Stock Exchange here today. By contrast, industrial shares resumed their rise. Reaction in gilt-edge issues left most prices with fractional net losses, with the war loan 1s 3d (17 cents) down.

The Police Department telephone call bodes are being relocated to be more accessible to the public.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 25 (UP)--Swaps added his fourth world record this year to his collection today as he coasted to victory by four and a quarter lengths in the Sunset Handicap at Hollywood Park. He ran the mile and five furlongs in 2:38 1/5.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 (UP)-- Howie Pollet, a 35-year-old lefthanded pitcher signed last week by the Pittsburgh Pirates as a free agent, checked a Chicago Cub threat in the eighth inning today to preserve a 4-0 victory and give the Pirates a sweep of the three-game series.

WARSAW, July 26-- "Emergency measures" to improve the living conditions of Polish workers within the next two years have been announced by Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz. These will be features of Poland's new Five-Year Plan.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 26--Soldiers can now talk to one another through their hats--if the hats contain the combat helmet radio unveiled today by the Army Signal Corps.

Sales and earnings of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., for the six months ended with June were the highest for any similar period in its 107-year history. John E. McKeen, president, so reported in the semi-annual statement issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- President Eisenhower's nomination of Wesley A. D'Ewart as Assistant Secretary of Interior seems destined to die without formal action by the Senate this session.

Radio and television stations and networks deployed crews over a wide area, extended broadcasting schedules and interrupted or canceled programs yesterday to cover the sinking of the Italian liner Andrea Doria.
LONDON, July 26--British business men received an official exhortation today to wake up to "clear and formidable" West German competition.
There were no "ifs, ands or buts" to yesterday's Giant defeat by the Braves. It was the eighth straight reversal for the abject Polo Grounders, who have dropped fifteen of their last sixteen games.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 --The question of trustworthiness will assume unexpected meaning in relation to the television show, "Do You Trust Your Wife," when Jean Antoine appears as a contestant on the filmed quiz program scheduled for Aug. 7.

The Port of New York last year lived up to its reputation of being the country's premier's foreign trade terminal. In doing so, the harbor picked up an additional 3,474,000 tons of highvalue cargoes over the 1954 calendar year. The extra cargo was valued at $951,000,000.
The income of the Suez Canal Company which President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt said his Government intended to use to build the Aswan High Dam, amounts to tens of millions of dollars yearly.

DULUTH, Minn., July 26 (AP)-- Mrs. Kathy Cornelius of Lake Worth, Fla., took the lead and the defending champion, Fay Crocker, was virtually eliminated today in the first round of the women's National Open golf tournament.
MANHASSET, L.I., July 26 --Miss Priscilla Kimball was married tonight to Thomas Henry Beddall Jr. in the Congregational Church of Manhasset.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)-- Congress sent to President Eisenhower today a compromise bill to raise the salaries of Cabinet members and hundreds of other Government executives.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Administration sources said today the United States had informed the Saudi Arabian Government that it would not pay rent for the Dhahran air base.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- Chief Justice Earl Warren will make a goodwill tour of India next month.

KITCHENER, Ont., July 26 (Canadian Press)--The Darling Valve and Manufacturing Company of Williamsport, Pa., has bought the Philip Gies Faundry. Ltd., here, C. Lorimer Rason of the local plant announced today.

CHICAGO, July 26--Wheat futures continued under pressure much of today's session, extend ing the declines of yesterday. Selling was credited in part to elevator interests and in part to longs, who were discouraged over the recent action of the market.
A suit to restrain the American Institute of Management from purchasing control of "Who's Who in America" was filed yesterday in Federal Court.

MANTOLOKING, N.J., July 26--Lew Hahn, President Emeritus of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and a leading figure in the department store field for many years, died today at the Point Pleasant Hospital, where he was taken Sunday night after suffering a heart attack in his summer home here, His age was 74.

A seven-story loft building at 114 West Thirteenth Street, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, has been sold by Benat Associates to an investing client of Newmark Co., brokers in the deal. The plot is 62 by 118 feet.

The International Finance Corporation, the idea for which was first officially proposed by Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank, five years ago, is at last a fact.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points up to 7 points off yesterday. Action was somewhat irregular in the late trading.

R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, one of the big three tobacco manufacturers, realized a 17.4 per cent increase in earnings in the first six months this year. This was on a sales gain of 10.3 per cent over the corresponding half of 1955.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 26--Mickey Homa, the 32-yearold pro at the Westchester Country Club, repeated as champion of the Westchester County Golf Association open tournament today when he turned in one of the strongest finishes ever carded on the difficult west course of the Winged Foot Country Club.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 26 (AP)--In a mock civil defense test last night, a Marine Corps Reserve company of fifty-two rifle men seized vital installations "to show what a few men can do in silencing a city ahead of an air attack."

FOUR major changes are included in regulations announced yesterday for the small game hunting season, which will open on Oct. 15 for all of New York State except Long Island and twelve Lake Plains counties.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Pairie, Webber, Jackson Curtis is offering for public subscription a new issue of $4,000,000 of National Research Corporation 5 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due July 1, 1976.
LONDON, July 26--The auto strike and the decline in sterling kept the stock markets subdued today, although several industrial issues advanced sharply on dividend announcements.

OKLAHOMA, CITY, July 26-- Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the United States chess champion, today handed Anthony F. Saidy of Douglaston. Queens, his first defeat in the United States Chess Federation's open championship tournament.

VERDI'S savage masterpiece, "Rigoletto," was presented last night at the Lewisohn Stadium without benefit of scenery or costumes, but with elemental impact.

Seven new high school principals were appointed yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting. The appointments go into effect Sept. 5, and are for the customary probationary period of three years.

Elias D. Cohen of 320 Central Park West, senior vice president, director and member of the executive committee of National Starch Products, Inc., adhesives, starches and resins, died Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. His age was 74.
In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer yesterday morning Miss Elizabeth Nesbitt was married to Dr. Henry Chase.

Capt. Piero Calamai of the sunken Andrea Doria arrived in New York last night, haggard and weary, yet fully composed. But he offered no clue to the cause of his ship's collision with the Stockholm late Wednesday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 --Hecht-Lancaster Productions has given up trying to keep secret its effort to acquire Carson McCullers' novel, "Reflections in a Golden Eye," as well as the services of Tennessee Williams to write the screen play and Sir Carol Reed to be the director.

The Southern California Edison Company is planning to borrow $40,000,000 in the public market on Sept. 5 on an issue of refunding mortgage bonds to be sold at competitive bidding. The company said a registration statement would be filed shortly with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Changes in lending trends evoke interesting observations by the Federal Reserve System. In its latest monthly bulletin, the Federal Reserve reports a slowdown in the growth of consumer credit in the first half of the year, compared with the 1955 activity.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) estimated yesterday net consolidated income for the first half of this year at $392,000 000, a new high for any six-month' period. This is equivalent to $2 each on the 196,393,922 shares outstanding.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 26 --Methods of fighting the new zoning law of the town of New Castle will be discussed by real estate developers and building contractors at a meeting here Monday night.

The General Dynamics Corporation is splitting its common stock for the second time in nineteen months and again raising the dividend rate on the stock. The market leader on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the stock closed at a new high of 71 for a gain of 4 points on the day.

BONN, Germany, July 26-- West Germany has called for a review by the Western European Union of Allied strategy and military planning in view of moves by the United States and Britain to cut their armed forces and rely more on nuclear weapons.
PARIS, Friday, July 27--The French National Assembly sat until past dawn today looking for a way to pay for the war in Algeria without hurting anyone, economically or politcally.
THREE luxury liner captains who have followed the sea for thirty years or more figured in the disaster off Nantucket.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 26 --Military helicopters were pressed into service today to remove from the scene persons injured in the collision between the Andrea Doria and the Stockholm. Five of the injured wereflown to Nantucket Cottage Hospital here.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 26 --The Official Gazette last night published a small list of applications for permission to drill for petroleum. Concessions were granted to Mene Grande Oil...
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 26 (Canadian Press)--Facing strong head winds and choppy water, the St. Catharines heavy eight defeated five other crews in the Royal Canadian Henley regatta today.
MOSCOW, July 26--The Soviet Union protested today its friendship for the Arab countries and denied that its policy toward them had changed.
Mayor Richarson Dilworth of Philadelphia was in the last lifeboat to be picked up by the Ile de France. His wife, another survivor of the Andrea Doria, had been rescued in an earlier lifeboat.
Arguments over details yesterday delayed a settlement of the national steel strike.
"Pictures in the Hallway," Sean O'Casey's absorbing impressions of his early struggles in the slums of Dublin, will be displayed at the Playhouse. Not as a regular engagement, though.

Capt. Theodore Joseph Fabik, engineer officer for the Fourteenth Coast Guard District, and Mrs. Fabik of Honolulu, formerly of Groton, Conn., have announced her a the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Theresa Jeanette Fabik, to Edward Robinson Stearns.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP)-- Gene Woodling's home run in the sixth inning today enabled the Cleveland Indians to score their sixth straight victory by beating the Washington Senators, 1--0, in a game ended by rain in the seventh.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 26--Louis Raemaekers, biting satirical antiGerman cartoonist during World War I, died today at Scheveningen, near The Hague, at the age of 87.
The father of a 4-year-old girl, standing helpless on the slanting deck of the Andrea Doria, threw the child over the liner's side into a lifeboat in a desperate effort to save his child.
WASHINGTON, July 26--The Republican party has begun a carefully planned campaign to obtain the votes of organized labor for all Republican candidates for Federal office.
Retaining their revived punching power, the Dodgers yesterday beat the Redlegs, 5--3, for a sweep of the three-game series, and ran their winning streak to five games.
The National Broadcasting Company is close to completing plans for a major realignment of its television program schedule on three and possibly four nights of the week.
LONDON, Friday, July 27-- Prime Minister Eden conferred hurriedly early today with United States and French diplomats on Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal Company.

Salt Lake City, Utah, borrowed $7,500,000 to finance school construction yesterday. The city sold an issue of serial bonds maturing on Feb. 1. from 1957 to 1971 to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank and Associates at an interest cost of 2.278 per cent.
The stricken Swedish liner Stockholm is moving toward New York under her own power at an estimated speed of seven knots and was expected early today to reach here this noon.
BONN, Germany, July 26-- The West German Cabinet has approved a draft law on atomic energy providing for a private rather than state-owned atomic industry.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 26--Three days have passed since Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, left Yugoslavia but the public is none the wiser about the purpose of his surprise call on President Tito on the island of Brioni.
John G. Johnson, retired vice president of the Sinclair Navigation Company of New York, died yesterday at his home in Providence. R.I. His age was 86.

WASHINGTON, July 27-- Prices received by farmers dropped 1 per cent between midJune and mid-July, the Crop Reporting Board announced today. The index of these prices fell from 247 to 244. This ended a six-month rise that has had considerable importance to political leaders as well as the farmers.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 27-- After three hours of play in ninety-degree heat, Arthur Larsen walked off the Merion Cricket Club turf the winner over Gilbert Shea today in the Pennsylvania State tennis championship. The scores were 8--6, 6--2, 8--10, 11--9.

LONDON, July 27--Britain protested sharply to Egypt today against the nationalization of the Suez Canal. She charged that Egypt's "arbitrary" action was "a serious threat to navigation."

BONN, Germany, July 27-- The gradual reduction of Allied troops in Germany and their replacement by German armed forces was advocated today by Dr. Erich Mende, deputy chairman of the opposition Free Democratic party.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 27-- A three-year study has found it feasible to dam the Volta River and generate electricity to produce aluminum. But the estimated cost of the undertaking has increased 60 per cent since a British-Gold Coast white paper outlined it in November, 1952.

CHICAGO, July 27--Coarse grains and soybeans displayed a decidedly strong undertone this morning while wheat was inclined to lag, presumably on selling against purchases of other grains in a backspreading movement. PARIS, July 27--After an emergency meeting of the principal ministers today it was said the French Government would be disposed to favor military occupation of the Suez Canal zone if Britain would join France in such an action.

Eddie Arcaro, who is in his twenty-fifth year as a race-rider, is going at his work with the zest of an apprentice this year. He's riding as many as six races an afternoon, and he says he's having a lot of fun. He had much fun at the Jamaica track yesterday.

DUBLIN, July 27--The Irish Republic's leaders have become seriously alarmed by the depopulation of their country. This was graphically shown in the debate, in the Dail Eireann (Parliament) that ended early this morning.
The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday filing of a revised rate schedule that would produce net additional revenues of $9,657,000 a year, effective Aug. 26.
BAMBERG, Bavaria, July 27 --Peace has descended on this tidy garrison city in the foothills of upper Franconia.
Miguel Berrios of Puerto Rico, a featherweight with a strong right hand, fought his way to a ten-round unanimous decision over Kid Anahuac of Mexico City in Madison Square Garden last night.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported its net income for the six months ended on June 30 at $187,824,657, equal to $4.01 a share. This compares with $186,392,722 or $3.98 a share shown for the corresponding period last year.
Survivors of the Andrea Doria were on both sides of the railing yesterday as the last contingent of those rescued arrived at Pier 84, Hudson River, at West Forty-fourth Street.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 (UP)-- Wally Post's triple in the ninth inning tonight scored Johnny Temple with the run that enabled the Cincinnati Redlegs to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3--2.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 --Screen Gems, Inc., has signed Stephen Longstreet, well-known author, to write and produce a new filmed television series titled "Mollie and Me."

SEOUL, Korea, July 27--The Korean front was quiet today on the third anniversary of the armistice of the 1950-53 war. However, in Seoul, demonstrating national assemblymen and South Korean policemen clashed in the downtown section of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 27-- The State Department said today that the United States Government "is consulting urgently with the other Governments concerned" on the Egyptian nationalization of the Suez Canal Company.

ROME, July 27--The entire Italian press, irrespective of political leanings, today faced tha loss of the Andrea Doria with a fierce determination to replace the liner as soon as possible with another and better ship from Italian yards.

CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP)-- Home runs by Rocky Colavito and Jim Hegan in the sixth inning powered the Cleveland Indians to a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight and extended the Tribe's winning string to seven games.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 15-- Recently uncovered frescoes and mosaics in Istanbul's Mosque of Ka'riye are considered by experts who have viewed them as the finest examples of Byzantine religious art in the world. The works were displayed to the public for the first time this month.
Steve Allen, who has spent his off-television hours in recent months as a one-man writing industry, may soon broaden his literary horizon to include a project for the Broadway stage.

Rear Admiral Milton E. Miles will take command of the Third Naval District Tuesday. He succeeds Rear Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who will become the Navy's Inspector General in Washington with the rank of vice admiral.

James P. Cummiskey Jr. has been named vice president in charge of finance of the Browning Lines, Inc., and its various subsidiaries, Troy H. Browning, president, announced yesterday. Mr. Cummiskey was formerly a vice president of the City Bank, Detroit.

ONE of the great debates of the art world has been over Fra Angelico. Does he belong to the Middle Ages or the Renaissance? Musicologists have had similar difficulties in classifying music that belongs to the transition from Gothic to Renaissance.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Mrs. Nixon arrived here yesterday from Washington. They went to the WaldorfAstoria Hotel and received no visitors.

VIENNA, July 28 (AP)--An organization of former Austrian war prisoners accused Soviet authorities today of having killed 1,300 slave laborers and wounded 3,000 others in quelling two revolts in camps last year.

CHICAGO, July 28--Mister Gus, a bay 5-year-old who chased Swaps to victory in his last three starts, broke into the winner's circle today with a one-length triumph in the $154,850 Arlington Handicap in American record time.
A Pennsylvania physician traveling on the liner Stockholm described yesterday how, from his cabin porthole, he had watched the Andrea Doria and his ship speed inexorably to the crash point.
A one-alarm fire in a Broadway restaurant near Times Square last night injured seven firemen and brought crowds of Saturday night strollers to the scene. Traffic was disrupted for a time.

MOSCOW, July 28--A few lines in a single Soviet newspaper this week revived the official reputation of V.E. Meyerhold who was purged in the Nineteen Thirties and his imaginative ideas of modern theatrical productions condemned to the fires of Soviet realism.
The Soviet Union, for the first time, is going to get the story in pictures, words--and prices--of the benefits of the American way of life.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 28 --Wally Lineburgh sailing Maid of Pligh and Dennis Posey at the tiller of Menace were tied for the Long Island Sound District Thistle Class championship after two races had been sailed today. The final event is scheduled for tomorrow.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28 Amortizor, a 5-year-old bay horse driven by Edward Cobb, held off Diamond Hal in a tight stretch duel to win the $7,500 Monitor, a mile free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
In Egypt, four years ago last Monday, a military junta under the leadership of a 34-year-old lieutenant colonel. Gamal Adbel Nasser, staged a bloodless coup and threw out the corrupt King Farouk.
Capt. Granville Conway, president of the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, yesterday announced the election of Granville Conway Jr. as vice president of the company.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (UP)-- Although they had to turn back three late threats, the Baltimore Orioles outlasted the Cleveland Indians for an 8-6 victory today to end the Indian winning streak at seven games.

LIMA, Peru, July 24--A cannon believed to date back to Peru's Spanish Colonial period was unearthed yesterday in the Rimac district of Lima. The gun is 4 feet 10 inches long and a foot thick and has a 10-inch bore.

PARIS, July 28--In preparation for the three-power talks on the Suez Canal crisis, French experts are studying a proposal to impose an international system of control. The purpose would be to insure the freedom of movement of ships through the canal.
White summer blossoms formed a floral background yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church for the marriage of Miss Susan Helen Rentschler to William D. Witter.

The John Hay Whitney Foundation has named twelve distinguished emeriti professors as Whitney Visiting Professors for the coming year.

STORRS, Conn., July 28--Miss Susan Emory, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Emory of Sharon, was married here today in the Congregational Church to Peter Lott, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugo Lott of Binghamton, N.Y. The Rev. J. Garland Waggoner performed the ceremony.

WORTH, Ill., July 28 (UP)-- Charles Boswell, a 39-year-old Alabaman who took up golf as a therapy, today had a twostroke lead in a drive to win his eighth United States Blind Golf Association championship.

YONKERS, July 28--One Yorkers man was killed and two others injured at 8:30 o'clock tonight on the Post Road when an automobile went out of control on a steep grade, crossed to the other side of the street, and crashed into a pole.

HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 28-- Gertrude Ederle, who learned to swim at beaches here and later became the first woman to swim the English Channel, will be honored Aug. 6 at a municipally sponored dinner at Bahrs Landing. It will mark the thirtieth anniversary of her crossing the Channel from Cape Griz Nez, France, to Dover, England, in 14 hours 31 minutes.

CORFU, Greece, July 28-- President Tito of Yugoslavia ended his visit to Greece today. The marshal had been on this wooded Ionian Sea island since Tuesday as guest of the Greek King and Queen.
SALISBURY, Conn., July 28-- The Salisbury Congregational Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Susanna Whitney Janes to Lieut. Donald Francis Bergenty, U.S.A.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28 (AP)--Martin B. McKneally of Newburgh was elected today state commander of the American Legion. He succeeds Frederick T. Devlin of Buffalo. Mrs. Leonard Miscall of Ithaca was elected president of the State Auxiliary, succeeding Mrs. John M. Milbury of Mount Vernon.

Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Sherman of Caracas, Venezuela, and Jamestown, R.I., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Hoyt Sherman, to William R. Joyce Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joyce of New York. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 28 (AP)--Andy Robustelli, all-pro end with the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League last season, was acquired by the New York Giants today in exchange for a high draft choice after the 1956 season.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 --Hank Enos' Bantam led the Luders-16 fleet in the Eastern Yacht Racing Association championship competition at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. Chick Whittelsey's Interlude was second.

NEW ORLEANS, July 28 (AP) --Maj. David F. MacAllister, Wilmington, Del., apparently won the Sabrejet race from Hamilton Air Force Base, Calif., to New Orleans today. His time was 3 hours, 30 minutes and 8 seconds. The 1,922-mile race was for the Earl T. Riggs Trophy.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- The National Science Foundation has granted $100,000 to Georgetown University for research in mechanical translation, the university announced this week.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 28-- Jefferson Davis Hospital, the city-county general charity hospital here, is making plans to offer tuition-free three-year nursing courses to students.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 28 --The engagement of Miss Marian Tappan Dowling, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Dowling of Providence, to Harry Heher Jr., son of Justice Harry Heher of the New Jersey State Supreme Court, and Mrs. Heher of Trenton, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

CLARKSVILLE, Va., July 28 --Tommy Young, an 18-year-old speed driver from the town of Wachapreague, won two events on the man-made Buggs Island lake today.

CINCINNATI (AP)--The Cincinnati Redlegs have come up with a 2l-year-old college star in Hank DeVincent. The Philadelphia youth was recommended by-Ed Liberatore, a Redleg scout.

FERNDALE, N.Y., July 28 (AP)--Fire today destroyed the Lakeside Inn, five-story frame resort hotel. About seventy guests fled the flames. Four persons were taken to a hospital for treatment for shock.

The United States Lines Company, operators of the American Pioneer Line services, has announced a 12 per cent increase in general cargo rates from Australia to United States Atlantic and Gulf ports and East Coast Canadian ports. The increase will go into effect Aug. 20.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 28 (AP)-- Gov. Allan Shivers said today that Senator Lyndon B. Johnson should decide whether Texas would take part in the proposed caucus Aug. 1 of Southern Democratic leaders in Atlanta.

TRENTON, July 28--Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the trustees of Rutgers University have selected eleven prominent residents of New Jersey to serve on the newly created board of governors of that institution. The board will henceforth oversee the operation of Rutgers.

BONN, Germany, July 28 (AP) --Sir Winston Churchill will have a day at the races tomorrow in West Germany. He is flying to Duesseldorf to watch his horse, Le Pretendant, run in the German Classic Grand Prize of North-Rhine Westphalia over 2,600 meters for 50,000 marks ($11,900).

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox backed up Willard Nixon's eight-hit pitching with a nineteen-hit attack today to crush the Chicago White Sox, 13 to 1. The defeat was the seventeenth for the White Sox in the last twenty games.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)--New Orleans took the lead over Chicago today in the yachting competition for the Dick Jones trophy.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 28-- Camilo Ponce Enriquez was officially declared last night the winner of the June 3 Presidential elections by a 3,043-vote margin.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 28--Tomorrow afternoon a man who says he doesn't like to watch baseball will go down to the Municipal Baseball Field to take part in an unusual ceremony preceding a semi-pro game and a youngsters' contest. The chances are that he will stay to watch the games.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 28--The nation's largest suburban shopping area is taking shape in fast-growing Bergen County--about sixteen miles from Times Square. Land that once bore neat rows of celery and potato crops--or tangled woodland--is now a beehive of construction activity. Fullscale work is proceeding on the two big regional shopping centers being erected here.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 28 (AP)--The Hungarian Government protested in a note delivered to the United States Legation today that American organizations in West Germany were launching "balloons loaded with inciting pamphlets into Hungary's air space."

HAVANA, July 28--Four hand grenades in a suitcase thrown from a speeding automobile exploded in the tunnel under the Almendares River today and caused minor damage. Seven unexploded grenades were found by the police. The tunnel connects with the residential area of Miramar, where many Americans live.
