Harry Klingel has been named director of research for the fine chemicals division of Shulton, Inc., manufacturer of toiletries and chemicals.
Five operations that mark an important advance in major heart surgery have been reported at Duke Hospital. In the operations Duke's new "artificial Heart-lung" or oxygenator was first used.
The 106 miles of tepid water and hot sand between Port Said and Suez in Egypt became once again last week the focus of national rivalries and personal ambitions.
Activity has developed on coats and stores are selling them earlier than they did last year, according to reports from New York resident buying offices.
For years some of the nation's largest railroads have found it increasingly unprofitable to carry Pullman passengers because of mounting operational costs and the competition of the airlines.

The national paddling championships will be held today on the Schuylkill River, Philadelphia, beginning at 1 P.M. Twelve events are scheduled. The American Canoe Association, affiliated with the Amateur Athletic Union, is conducting the tests.
IF the Soviet Union admits enough American tourists, there should be an early collapse of the illusion so long entertained in this country about the artistic superiority of the Russian theatre.
The soil bank may prove a dud in curtailing this year's cotton crop.
If competition in the housebuilding field is as keen as reputed, and if prospective purchasers are as quality-conscious as builders think, the Architects Display Building now rising in ...
Prospective home buyers will have the answers to many of their questions in the "Home Buyers' Handbook" being published today by the Housing Research Foundation of the Southwest Research Institute.
The city's proposed West Side $1,216,800 parking garage for 469 cars has become bogged down in the face of a determined fight of Eighth Avenue property owners to defeat it.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 Mr. and Mrs. George E. Mosley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sydnie Ann Mosley, to Ezra Cornell 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Cornell 3d of Upper Montclair, N.J.

A plan whereby a family may purchase a cooperative apartment on Cape Cod for vacation or year-round use at a carrying charge of less than $100 a year has been started by the Cape Cod Twinoaks Sea Club in Brewster, Mass.
CAIRO, July 28--Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser warned the West today that any interference with his seizure of the Suez Canal "will cause obstruction of navigation."

DULUTH, Minn., July 28-- Barbara McIntire, an amateur from Toledo, carded a threeunder-par 71 today to tie Mrs. Kathy Cornelius at 302 and force an eighteen-hole play-off for the women's National Open golf championship.
A new graduate program in nautical engineering embracing a "fresh dynamic approach" will be started in September at Stevens Institute of Technology,...
DURING the last fifty-six years, thousands of readers in America and abroad have been acquainted with Capt. Joshua Slocum's book, "Sailing Alone Around the World."

CLEVELAND, July 28--Miss Anne Van Rensselaer Lenihan was married this morning to Richard Edward McErlean in St. John's Roman Catholic Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Lennon, uncle of the bridegroom, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.
LONDON, July 28 (UP)-- Alan Oliver of Britain, riding Galway Boy, today won the Daily Mail Champion Cup, the final event in the horse show at White City Stadium.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28-- A few voices of doubt were heard today among the chorus of acclaim for Egypt's seizure of the Suez Canal.
Construction of 103 more houses will begin shortly at Seaview Village in Brooklyn, where some 650 homes have already been sold. The village, at Rockaway Parkway and Avenue M, ...
TOKYO, July 28 (AP)--Japan and the Himalayan Kingdom of Nepal agreed today to establish diplomatic relations.
A committee of 200 persons, with former President Herbert Hoover as honorary chairman, is being organized to sponsor a three-year development program for the Cooper Union.

WATERFORD, Conn., July 28 (AP)--A New Haven man will have to pay the charges for a boat he hired for tuna fishing and has no right to a swordfish caught by the boat's skipper, Judge William C. Fox ruled today.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 28--The marriage of Miss Patricia Ann Best, daughter of Lieut. Col. George H. Best, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Irma Volkman Best, to Ensign Russell ...

The marriage of Miss Joanne Clare Binder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald L. Binder of Leonia, N.J., to Friedrich August Otto Eckner, Son of Frau Otto Eckner of Plauden, Germany, and the late Herr Eckner, took place yesterday at noon.

HERSHEY, Pa., July 28 (UP) --Perserverance paid off today for Art Garrison, 37, a Hershey draftsman, when he won the Pennsylvania public links golf championship after nineteen years of trying. He beat his brother to do it, too.

BOSTON, July 28--A daughter was born on Thursday to Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Cowett of New York in the Beth Israel Hospital here. Mrs. Cowett is the former Miss Carla Barron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Clark Barron of Littlespoint, Swampscott. The child will be named Juliet Florence.

PANAMA, July 28--Juan D. Peron, former Argentine dictator, returned to Panama today after a nine-day visit in Managua, Nicaragua, where he was the guest of President Anastasio Somoza. He left Panama for Managua July 19 as the American Presidents began to arrive for their hemisphere conference.
A new industry has resulted from electronic "traffic cops" and argument-shattering highway radar speed traps.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28--Yugoslavia has embarked on a new course in agriculture designed to draw individual peasants into cooperatives with a carrot instead of a stick.

WASHINGTON, July 28--The record of the departing Democratic Eighty-fourth Congress is largely without striking blacks and whites in the national sense but it is studded with sharp potential local and regional issues.

The super-block type of public housing was condemned yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack. He called it a contributor to traffic congestion and a menace to small businesses forced to locate elsewhere.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 29 (AP) --British forces on Cyprus were armed today with wider powers to crack down on Greek Gypriote extremists. The Governor, Field Marshal Sir. John Harding, issued amendments to emergency regulations decreed last November.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (UP)-- Arnold Palmer, the former national amateur champion from Latrobe, Pa., won the Eastern open title with an eleven-underpar 277 total at the Mount Pleasant municipal course today.

The estimated cost of the "terminal city" being developed at New York International Airport, Idlewind, Queens, has been increased by 50 per cent. The figure, $60,000,000 when plans were made public in Feburary, 1955, is now $90,000,000.
MIDLAND, Ont., July 29 (Canadian Press)--Robert Young Eaton, a former president of the T. Eaton Company, Ltd., died last night in a hospital here. He was 81 years old.

LIMA, Peru, July 29--The gates of Peruvian prisons swung open for political prisoners last night. Dr. Manuel Prado y Ugarteche had signed an amnesty law two hours after he had been sworn in as President. Thus in a few hours, the laboriously constructed edifice of dictatorial rule collapsed in Peru.

WASHINGTON, July 29--The issue of Communists in Government has been perhaps the most durable political commodity of the Republican party since World War II. Dwight D. Eisenhower used it freely in his 1952 campaign.

PARIS, July 29--The investment of foreign capital to develop overseas areas in the French monetary zone is desirable and practicable. Such is the view of Francois Bloch-Laine, a larly versed in these areas who helped negotiate the French-Tunisian customs and monetary unions.

When the Germans broke across the borders of the Low Countries in May, 1940, the vast stores of industrial diamonds in Amsterdam were endangered. If taken, they would have been of incalculable value to the Nazi war machine and a "deadly" loss to the Allies.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29-- The probability of the America's Cup going back into competition in 1958 after twenty-one years on the shelf at the New York Yacht Club developed tonight. The complexities of challenge, design and building made it unlikely that a series could be held next summer.

ATLANTA, July 29 (UP)-- Scattered attempts to revive the Ku Klux Klan were growing in the South today. Klan leaders burned crosses and issued new threats in an attempt to win over Southerners disgruntled by the SupremeCourt's integration orders.
A revised statement on the teaching of moral and spiritual values is the city schools was made public yesterday by the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) --Mikhail A. Chekmarev, the Soviet Union's new economic minister to this country, called today for more trade between the United States and the Soviet.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 23--The first stage of an ambitious ten-year plan to put this country a long way ahead of its Central American neighbors in electrical development moved within practical sight of its goal this week.
JERICHO, L. I., July 29--Phil Iglehart scored twice in the final chukker to give the Jericho poloists a 9-7 decision over Meadow Brook at the Meadow Brook Club today.

DUMAS, Tex., July 29--Four huge petroleum tanks exploded near here today, enveloping nineteen men in a wall of intensely hot flame and killing them instantly. Thirty-two persons were in hospitals with burns. Some of them were in critical condition.

The Miami Beah contract bridge pair of Mrs. Edith Kemp and Harry Harkavy took an early lead yesterday in the top rated 1956 Life Master Pairs Championship. Their first session score was 412 match points.

With dad about to take his vacation, junior should get himself prepared for some stiff compe tition in the basement or attic where the model railroad complex he received for Christmas has been set up.
CHICAGO, July 29 (UP)--The chief aide to former State Auditor Orville E. Hodge characterized himself as stupid and a "damn fool," but has denied he knowingly took part in a $1,000,000 check scandal.
A police search for a man on trial for hijacking furs began yesterday after two of his codefendants were found murdered on the lower East Side Saturday night.

Van Norman Industries, Inc., announced over the week-end the acquisition of 17,128 shares of the common stock of American Pulley Company. The stock was acquired through an exchange of Van Norman common and preferred stock from a small number of, American Pulley...

The Central and Southwest Corporation had a net income of $20,924,282 for the twelve months ended on June 30. This was $2.16 a share on the common-stock, the company reported over the week-end. It compares with $19,006,665, or $1.96 a common share in the preceding twelve months. Gross revenues were $119,332,024, against $109,879,834.

WASHINGTON, July 29 ,(UP)--The Federation of American Scientists urged President Eisenhower today to do away with present regulations restricting international, exchange of basic scientific and technical information. "A free exchange of ideas is essential to stimulate the inventiveness of American technical minds," the group said.
BELLPORT, L.I., July 29-- Charley Dominy's Star, Independence, won the Queen-of-the Bay race today. A record total of twenty-five craft competed in the handicap test for the Growtage Trophy.

MAX HIRSCH is one of the nation's most famous trainers of race horses. He has been a trainer since the late Eighteen Nineties. Early this month, on his seventy-sixth birthday, Hirsch was asked to name the best jockey he'd ever seen.
WASHINGTON, July 29-- Secretary of State Dulles declared today that nationalization of the Suez Canal by Egypt was "a grievous blow to international confidence."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, July 29 --Twentieth Century-Fox plans to put three pictures before the cameras here next month, ending a temporary lull in filming at its spacious studio. The films scheduled are "Three Faces of Eve."
DULUTH, Minn., July 29 (AP) --Mrs. Kathy Cornelius of Lake Worth, Fla., defeated Barbara McIntire by seven strokes today in a play-off for the women's national open golf championship.

A man accused by the police of raping and killing a 3-yearold--girl was surrounded last night by an angry crowd of 2,000 persons at the scene of the crime. Five detectives drew their pistols to force the mob away.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 29 (AP) --Canada salvaged a final singles match of the Davis Cup American Zone semi-finals today as Paul Willey of Vancouver, B.C., defeated Barry MacKay of the University of Michigan, 14--16, 6--4, 6--3, 8--6.
A new $2,000,000,000 trunkline subway connecting Manhattan and Queens was advocated yesterday by Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority.

AMSTERDAM, July 29-- Though the termination of the American steel strike was welcomed here as an indication of the sense of reality and responsibility of American employers and workers, the report was entirely overshadowed by Suez developments.

The faith of Islam was described yesterday as the "most misunderstood of all religions." This was the consensus of a panel of imams, or spiritual leaders, who participated in one of the closing sessions of the fifth annual convention of the Federation of Islamic Associa
VIENNA, July 29 (Reuters) --Austria today granted political asylum to four Polish air cadets who escaped from Poland Saturday in two Soviet-built aircraft.

ON Saturday morning a crypt was opened in the basement of the Roman Cath olic Church of St. Paul the Apostle at Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street and the body of the Rev. Richard Stearns Cartwright, a Paulist father, went into it. The crypt was then sealed.
A four-year program of missionary work initiated this year by the Board of Missions of the Methodist Church was outlined here yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Troburn T. Brumbaugh.

The five-story apartment house for twenty-six families on a plot 100 by 120 feet at 80-30 Broadway, Elmhurst, Queens, was sold by the Jopar Realty Corporation to the G. B. Realty Company, which insured, title with the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company. Joseph R. Paretta, broker, negotiated the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to $82,000.
MADRID, July 28--The news of the expropriation by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt of the Suez Canal Company has had a deep effect in Spain.

ALGIERS, Algeria, July 29 --The Tunisian Government, plagued by grave economic problems, has made overtures in Paris for a resumption of the "interdependence" talks that were broken off abruptly July 13.

SEWANEE, Tenn., July 29-- The Rev. Dr. Marshall Bowyer Stewart, Protestant Episcopal theologian and retired professor at the University of the South here, died last night in a Sewanee hospital of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 75.
PARIS, July 28 (AP)--Paris fall fashion openings last night were rudely interrupted by a minor rebellion.

The Kennecott Copper Corpotion made record profits in the first half of 1956. The semi-annual report shows ration made record profits in the net income before depletion at $89,119,165, equal to $8.24 a share. The net in the first half of last year was $65,430,468, or $6.05 a share.

ZURICH, July 29--Although public opinion in Switzerland, where a great many people hold foreign investments, was profoundly shocked at the news of the abrupt seizure and nationalization of the Suez Canal, business on the Stock Exchange here was undisturbed. The general attitude was: "Wait and see."
The steel strike, now settled, may cause inflationary trends in the United States economy, the Chase Manhattan Bank said in its quarterly business review released over the week-end.

The presidents of twelve business concerns have been named to the board of trustees of the Committee for Economic Development, according to J.D. Zellerbach, chairman of the committee and president of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation.

CHICAGO, July. 29--Choppy fluctuations were the rule in the grain market last week. In wheat there was considerable profit taking by local professional traders, and also some hedge pressure against increased offerings from Ohio.
LONDON, July 29--Britain and France urged the United States today to join them in devising a policy aimed at putting the Suez Canal under international supervision.

WAKEFIELD, R.I., July 29-- John McNulty, who immortalized the bartenders, taxi drivers, horse players and other habitues of New York's Third Avenue in his sketches and short stories in The New Yorker magazine, died here tonight of a heart attack. His age was 60.

DALLAS, Tex., July 29 (UP)-- Senator Price Daniel, who ran as a conservative and moderate, piled up a growing lead today in the Democratic gubernatorial-primary, but failed to get the majority needed to prevent a run-off.
Skies as clear and blue as those in a resort advertisement drew throngs yesterday to the beaches in New York and New Jersey.

The Dodgers split a doubleheader with the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday, with Don Newcombe and Bob Rush each gaining his 100th major league triumph. Newk's victory, was a five-hit, 1-0 shutout. Rush's was by a 4-2 margin.
CAIRO, July 29--Egypt banned all exports to Britain and her colonies today unless payment was made through a third state with acceptable currency.

DETROIT, July 29 (UP)--Dean Stone's, four-hit pitching helped Washington to a 4-1 triumph in the second game today after the Senators had dropped the opener, 6--0, to Billy Hoeft of the Detroit Tigers.

William G. Henderson, manager-treasurer of the New York City News Association before it was acquired by The Associated Press, and later a member of the staff of The New York Times, died yesterday after a short illness at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 77 years old.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 29--The Empire State Music Festival came to its season's end this afternoon. At a concert attended by about 2,000 persons Igor Markevitch conducted the Symphony of the Air in three works--Stravinsky's "Pulcinella" Suite, Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" Overture and the First Symphony of Brahms.

The national index of consumer prices advanced between May 15 and June l5 by about seven-tenths of 1 per cent. The May-June rise was not only the fourth advance in as many months, but it was the widest recorded in five years.

LE MANS, France, July 29 (AP) --The Scottish team of Ron Flockhart and Ninian Sanderson streaked to victory today in the twenty-four-hour Le Mans Grand Prix endurance race marked by accidents, foul weather and one death.
MOSCOW, July 29--After a week of negotiations Billy Rose announced tonight an agreement in principle with Soviet officials for a vast cultural ex change of entertainment.

Another vivid piece of evidence showing the seething discontent in Poland has been provided by four young Polish air cadets. At the risk of their lives they flew two training planes into Austria and asked for political asylum to escape "unbearable living conditions" in their native land.

Major crime was reduced 8.6 per cent in the first six months of this year over the same period of 1955. However, misdemeanors rose 11 per cent, with the result that there was an over-all increase in crime of 4.3 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) --A group of scholars predicted today that the future of the world would be marked by industrial growth in all countries and a speed-up of the "scientific revolution."

There will be four sponsors for "The Young Strangers." Contracts have beep signed by Robert Fryer and Lawrence Carr to participate in the presentation of Irene Kamp's romantic comedy with the newly formed managerial team of Bertram Bloch and his wife, Edythe Latham.
LONDON, July 29--The English Channel was hit last night and today by a heavy gale that sank many small vessels and caused much damage ashore.

Underwritings of corporate securities for the first six months of 1956 were $3,966,101,312, about $690,000,000 more than in the same period last year, according to the semiannual statistical survey of the public capital market made by the Investors Dealers Digest, a trade publication.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., July 29--The East Meadow School District has a $426,000 Federalaid windfall that it cannot use for classroom construction without reducing its future state emergency building allowances.

PARIS, July 28--Castillo of Lanvin went cape crazy, Patou kept the waist high and Gres draped jersey to new degrees of perfection during the third day of the fall fashion openings. Castillo gives us the V line. This stands for the French "vie," or life. He says that he has liveliness in mind. His collection bears this out.
PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) --Roy Smalley's triple in the eight inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 5-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 29-- Victor Seixas won the Pennsylvania State grass court tennis championship for the seventh time today at the Merion Cricket Club.

The ninth annual Rodgers and Hammerstein Night, plus a lovely summer evening, plus the fact that it was the last concert of the season, drew about 18,000 people to Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday evening.

In 406 B.C., when Aristo phanes wrote "The Frogs" and cried out for the lost virtues of an earlier age, Franz Pick would have felt quite at home. They chief comic writer of ancient Greece and the author of "1956 Pick's Currency Yearbook" show the same blistering hatred for currency depreciation.

James E. Barsi, national sales manager of the Paul Masson Vineyards, Saratoga, Calif., has been elected vice president, John F. O'Connell, president, announced. Mr. Barsi is a former vice president and general sales manager of Anheuser-Busch, Inc.
KANSAS CITY, July 29-- With Bill Skowron still shelling the ramparts of Kansas City's Municipal Stadium, the Yankees today completed the rout of the tail-end Athletics.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 29--The wind played tricks one Long Island Sound again today as the Echo Bay Yacht Club ended its two-day Yacht Racing Association program. The happy trick was a late breeze of twelve miles blowing from the northwest that brbught the entire fleet of 113 boats home within the space of 20 minutes 26 seconds.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 29--Carll Tucker, a social leader, died of a coronary thrombosis at his home early today after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
John T. Dunlop, professor of economics at Harvard, speaking recently before a round table discussion group at the National Industrial Conference Board observed:
The Italian Line still has not abandoned the Andrea Doria legally and retains ownership of the luxury vessel now lying on the ocean bottom 250 feet deep off Nantucket Island.
Demolition of slum properties for the $20,000,000 New York University-Bellevue redevelopment project has been delayed by a flock of homing pigeons.

LONDON, July 29--Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal cast a pall over financial activity here at the end of last week. There was no panic of selling, but the withdrawal of buyers, led dealers to make precautionary markdowns of stocks on their books. Trading during the week was subdued.
MOSCOW, July 29--The Soviet Union announced today its support of Egypt's nationalizing of the Suez Canal. It stressed that it regarded the action as not only correct but legal.

Disillusioned by Shintoism, which they felt failed them during the Communism invasion, "thousands upon thousands" of Koreans are turning to the Roman Catholic Church, according to the Rev. Ambrose Gallagher of St. Columban's Foreign Mission Society.

Prices of cotton futures moved in a narrow range on the New York Cotton Exchange last week. At the close Friday quotations ranged from 60 cents a bale lower to 90 cents higher than in the preceding week.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 29-- Fear that Egypt's expropriation of the Suez Canal may jeopardize the Volta River development project in the Gold Coast is being expressed here by Africans and British alike.

CLARKSVILLE, Va., July 29 --A world record was established today on man-made Buggs Island Lake in speed boating, a sport still new and strange to this tobacco country. Today's thirteen-hour race meet was probably the biggest inboard and outboard regatta a Dixie waterway had ever had.

WASHINGTON, July 29--It wasn't generally known, but Southern Democratic Senators led by Richard B. Russell of Georgia had a show-down meeting with Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate majority leader, after the Civil rights bill reached the Senate in its closing days.

NEWTON, N.J., July 29-- Champion Adastra Magic Fame, a white miniature poodle owned by Mrs. Marguerite. S. Tyson of Washington, gained the top award in the thirteenth annual Lake Mohawk Kennel Club dog show at Memory Park today.

MANILA, July 29--Karl R. Bendetsen, former United States Under Secretary of Defense, conferred with President Ramon Magsaysay today on the delicate question of a revision of the Philippine-United States military bases agreement.
ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 29--Harry Nye of Chicago easily triumphed today in the second race of the final Olympic trial for Star Class yachts.
NEWARK, July 29--Miss Linda Ruth Mayer and Ira Gissen were married here this afternoon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun by Rabbi Ely Pilchik. A reception was given in Goetz Hall at the temple.

Harold Macmillan, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, called thirty of London's leading British and foreign bankers to the Treasury last week to urge them in person of the need for keeping a restraining hand on the supply of credit. This was the first time in history, according to London advices, that the Exchequer had ever sought to implement an anti-inflationary monetary policy with a personal plea of this kind.

DENVER, July 29 (AP)--Former Gov. Dan Thornton today challenged Charles F. Brannan, Democratic aspirant for a Senate seat, "to a cotton-picking, wheat-shocking, cow-milking, calf-roping, or calf-branding" contest. Mr. Brannan was Secretary of Agriculture in the Truman Administration."
The threat of a strike hung last night, over the aluminum industry even as contract negotions continued.
Credit General Foods with a promotional inspiration designed to help practically everybody, including the consumer. Here's how it works:
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 29 (AP)--President and Mrs. Eisenhower worshipped today in the Presbyterian church that Lincoln attended the day he delivered his Gettysburg address.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 29-- Miss Harriette Kurtz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Kurtz of Great Neck, and Burton Mahler Strauss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Strauss of New York, were married here at noon today in Temple Beth-El by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman of Temple Israel. A reception was given in the temple.
ONE of the most interesting television, scripts of the year, illuminated by fine performances and an impressive production, made last night's "Goodyear Playhouse" on Channel 4 an outstanding show.

The representatives of Britain, France and the United States meeting in London to discuss the problems that arise from President Nasser's seizure of the Suez Canal will be obliged to take into account the possible consequences of this irresponsibie act. This is a conference on Suez, but it is also a conference that must embrace the whole field of international relations and multilateral agreements.
WASHINGTON, July 27--Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended on July 28:

ALBANY, July 29 (AP)--A young Italian passenger aboard the Andrea Doria said today that orders to don life jackets and abondon ship had been "clearly sounded over a loudspeaker in both Italian and English."
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 29--Staff Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon will take the witness stand this week to tell his story of the night march into Ribbon Creek April 8.

WARSAW, July 29--The leaders of Poland have decided to create no new scapegoats for either crimes of Stalinism or the riots at Poznan. The seventh plenum of the Central Committee of the Polish Workers (Communist) party, which wound up ten days' deliberations late last night, concluded that much was wrong in Poland but decided that responsibility for it must be collective.

The Port of New York Authority announces that the 655-acre "terminal city" that is being built at New York International Airport is taking on the magnitude of a $90,000,000 job rather than the $60,000,000 cost figure used as recently as April 30.
Miss Carole Mitchell was married to Leonard A. Morris here last eveing in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by the Rev. Gunter Hirschberg of Rodeph Sholem Congregation. A reception followed.

COLD soups have become so much the mode that home cooks may forget one hot potage that long has been a summer stand-by on the New England coast. We refer, of course, to clam chowder: Yankee ambrosia of clams, potatoes, onions, milk. It is too good to be forgotten by any cooks, especially by those vacationing near the coast. There clams are at their best and breezes stiff enough to make a hot soup welcome.
CLEVELAND, July 29 (AP)-- The Cleveland 'Indians' two young left-handers--Herb Score and Hank Aguirre--hurled shutouts against the Baltimore Orioles today.

CALBE, Germany, July 23-- All the foundry Iron for East Germany comes from a smelting plant situated in this village. It uses a new process involving low-grade iron ore and coke made from lignite coal.

The anti-religious campaign launched by the Communists in the Soviet Union almost forty years ago has been singularly successful. There are many more unused churches and synagogues in Moscow and Leningrad than occupied ones.

Some months after Stalin's death Charles de Gaulle, that curious, angular general whose name will dominate France's mid-century history, was asked by a friend about his personal political future. With singular absence of modesty he replied:

Drastic changes in highway and licensing regulations for trucks were ordered yesterday by Governor Harriman in a move to cut accidents. The tighter controls were aimed particularly at the huge tractor-trailers, which, the Governor noted, are posing increasingly hazardous problems on the state's highways. There are more than 136,000 trailers among the 5,000,000 vehicles licensed in the state.
The whereabouts of twentynine more survivors of the Andrea Doria ship disaster was established yesterday and early today.

Weakness in the pound sterling highlighted the foreign exchange market during the past week. The decline mainly was attributed to the automobile strike. Other factors were the nationalization of the Suezz Canal Company by the EEEgyptian Government and heavy selling by oil interests on this side.

ROME, July 29--Pietro Nenni, leader of Italy's Left Wing Socialists, expressed some doubt, today as to whether the prestige of the men now ruling the Soviet Union would be able to weather the storm of their antiStalin campaign.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 28-- Dr. Nelson Glueck, American archaeologist, has discovered prehistoric settlements dating from the Paleolithic Period in the Negev Desert near the ancient Nabatean hill City of Abda.
James A. Michener, Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, has been signed by the National Broadcasting Company to write and narrate a documentary film titled "Assignment: Southeast Asia." .
WASHINGTON, July 29-- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota told his friends today that they could "work actively in my behalf" for the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination.

CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio, July 29 (AP)--America's top swimmers, warming up for the Olympic trials in Detroit next week, broke meet records in five of six events in the final day of the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships today.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP)-- The Cincinnati Redlegs swept a double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates today. The Redlegs took the second game 3--2, on a ninth-inning double by Smoky Burgess and won the opener, 6--1, behind the fourhit pitching of Brooks Lawrence.

PARIS, July 29--The Suez Canal is a relic and a symbol of an age of European imperialism that is passing. In the angry reactions of Paris and London to the Egyptian expropriation of the company operating the canal there was indignation at what was considered a violation of legal rights.

The Temporary Commission on the Courts is recommended yesterday that all sixteen city and state trial courts in New York City be consolidated into two courts. These two would be: The present State Supreme Court, expanded to have jurisdiction over all major civil and criminal cases.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)-- The Air Force is using B-52 jet bombers to test defenses against the comparable Bison bombers the Soviet could use in an attack on North America.
WASHINGTON, July 29-- Robert Murphy is a big, charming Irishman who at 61 has reached the pinnacle of his profession of career diplomacy.
ORANGE, N.J., July--29 (AP)-- Harry Mendel, publicity man for the International Boxing Club of New York, died tonight at St. Mary's Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy drew a gloomy picture yesterday of crime in the city. Juvenile delinquency, he noted, rose at the "alarming" rate of 41.3 per cent in the first six months of this year, compared with the same period last year. In addition, 41.2. per cent of arrests for serious crimes involved persons less than 21 years old.

POTTERSVILLE, N.J., July 29--Wortman's water-driven grist mill whirls at top speed these days. In a loft, Fred Fricke feeds ears of corn from century-old bins into a crude wooden chute. Twelve hundred pounds at a time, the ears tumble to the worn grinding plates in the musty cellar below.
The steamship charter market held firm last week with some rate advances. The volume of business done was only moderate.

The United Corporation, reporting for the first time as an investment trust, announced over the week-end net investment income and profits on sales of securities amounted to $4,192,878, or 30 cents a share, in the first half Of this year. This compares with $3,552,944 or 25 cents a shade in the similar period of 1955.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP)--Ford Motor Company pushed its production for 1956 above the 1,000,000 unit car mark last week. Rolling out 36,180 cars during the five-day period it raised its total for the year to 1,001,022 assemblies. The preceding week's output came to 35,982 cars.

TEL AVIV, July 31--With a goal in the last ten minutes, the Soviet Union soccer team scored a 2-1 victory over the Israeli National team today in an Olympic Games elimination contest. The Russians thus qualified for the games in Melbourne.
ALBANY, July 31--About 1,000,000 of the state's 6,250,000 driver licenses expire Sept. 30. The Bureau of Motor Vehicles will begin accepting applications for renewals tomorrow.

MELBOURNE, July 31 (AP)-- The Melbourne Olympic Games Organizing Committee is planning to switch the basketball tournament from the original site, the Melbourne Glaciarium ice skating rink. It is almost certain the committee will refuse to pay the 20,000 pounds (about $45,000) rental asked by the ice rink proprietors.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The Government said today it would offer added price inducements to nickel producers to develop new sources of that scarce metal.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- I.G. Chemie, (Interhandel), a Swiss holding company, lost another legal round today in its efforts to recover properties valued at more than $100,000,000 that were seized during World War II.
"Thor Heyerdahl, the Norwegian anthropologist, is more convinced than ever that the Polynesian Islands were first settled by Inca and pre-Inca Indians from Peru.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 31 (AP)--A third shift of about 700 workers joined 2,800 strikers today at a General Electric Company shop that produces large steam-turbine generators.

In the middle of the twelfth century there lived on the island of Gainsay in the Orkneys a remarkable man named Sweyn Asleifsson. Next to Earl Rognvald himself he was the mightiest man in the Orkneys.
Alex Kessler, builder of apartment houses and one and twofamily dwellings, died yesterday in his home at 84-43 Avon Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens. His age was 60.
QUEBEC, July 31 (UP)--The Government icebreaker D'Iberville, embarked today on the first leg of its third annual 13,000-mile summer supply tour of the Arctic.
VIENNA, July 31 (Reuters)-- Today's official medical bulletin on the health of President Theodor Koerner, 83 years old, ill with circulation trouble, said: "The improvement is very rapid."
ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 31 (AP)--Arlington county was ordered today by a Federal judge to end racial segregation in its public schools next year. Albert V. Bryan, District Court Judge, ...
TRENTON, July 31--John Ogden Bigelow is now rounding out a successful halfcentury career as lawyer, jurist and prosecutor.
ROME, July 31--The Italian Cabinet mildly reproved Egypt today for nationalizing the Suez Canal, but made it clear that it had no intention of taking any action in the matter.

WARSAW, July 31 (Reuters) --Poland's United Workers (Communist) party announced today it was stepping out from direct management of the nation's affairs but would provide "political inspiration" for Government leaders.
BUENOS AIRES, July 31 (AP) --Juan D. Peron, deposed Argentine dictator, was indicted today on charges that he seduced Nelida Haydee Rivas, a teen-ager.
ALBANY, July 31--Mr. and Mrs. S. Allan Beckhard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Beckhard, to Robert Irwin Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Goodman of Troy.

India plans to spend $200,000,000 on expansion of its communications systems during the next five years, Raj Bahadur, the country's Minister of Communications, said yesterday as he left here for London on his way home.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31--France moved today in the Trusteeship Council to obtain United Nations approval for a referendum in October in its trust territory of Togoland.

The Bay Petroleum Corporation, a subsidiary of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, has announced the completion of a construction program at its New Orleans refinery to produce higher quality gasoline and other products.
The Upjohn Company, pharmaceutical manufacturer, announced yesterday in Kalamazoo, Mich., the creation of two new divisions, advertising and ...

Governor Harriman claimed last night more than half of the 200 convention votes released yesterday by Senator Estes Kefauver and declared that he would remain in the race for the Democratic nomination for President "until the last ballot, is counted."
GALVESTON, Tex., July 31 (UP)--Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, the woman athlete, today set up the Babe Didrikson Zaharias trophy.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 31 (AP)--An effort by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to suspend a $100,000 contempt of court fine while it seeks a review was turned down today by the Alabama Supreme Court.
MILAN, Italy, July 31 (Reuters)--An Italian Air Force transport plane crashed into the courtyard of a restaurant near Milan's Malpensa Airport today, killing the crew of six.
WASHINGTON, July 31--Following is the text of a statement issued by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee today announcing his withdrawal as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31-- The University of Pennsylvania today requested the committee on student affairs to investigate reports of student drinking on the campus.

TORONTO, July 31 (Canadian Press)--Shirley Campbell, 20year-old stenographer and model, was pulled exhausted from Lake Ontario tonight, less than a mile from completion of an agonizing swim across the tough, thirty-two-mile lake.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) --Personal income of Americans rose in June to an annual rate of $324 billion, a jump of almost $1.5 billion over May, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- President Eisenhower will hold tomorrow his first news conference in eight weeks.
BERLIN, July 31--The Communist leadership of East Germany committed the country today to a long-range "socialistic" campaign against the "capitalistic" West.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- Fifty-five Americans, including high religious leaders, wrote an open letter today to "The Perplexed Among Communists," asking them to face manfully the doubts and promptings of their conscience.
Three men pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to conspiring to smuggle 4,500 watch movements valued at $45,000 into this country from Germany.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- Attorneys for four airlines today supported their companies' applications to begin flights across the Gulf of Mexico between Houston and Miami.
PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., July 31--Following are excerpts from the testimony of S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon at his court-martial here today:

The Commercial Credit Company is planning to borrow $50,000,000 in the public market on an issue of long-term notes to be sold through underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co.
The Esso Research and Engineering Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), has announced the election of D. Woodson Ramsey Jr. as a director.

Seventy-one refugees from Eastern Europe arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The refugees, who had been living in West Germany, were brought here under the auspices of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration. Forty-five of the group had come originally from the Soviet.

For almost a decade and a half Britain's political landscape was dominated by the hunched, bellicose figure of Winston Churchill. Even when his party was not in office his rich personality towered above the scene.

DENVER, July 31 (AP)--Pacific Northwest Pipeline officials said today they hoped to have their new pipeline, serving the Paradox and San Juan Basins of Colorado, Utah and New Mexico, ready for operation within a year.

CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP)-- New York and Detroit were left today as the only undefeated teams in the forty-second Union Printers baseball tournament. Boston and Pittsburgh were eliminated in the two-defeatsand-out tournament in secondround games.
LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) --Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, criticized today dishonest shop and restaurant managers "who swindle both state and public," the Moscow radio reported.
Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., will occupy a new milk processing and distribution plant to be built at 59th Street and Tyler Avenue in Queens.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 31 (Reuters)--The British Colonial Government announced today it would amend new emergency regulations that permit the use of "reasonable force" to arrest, detain or question suspects.

TRENTON, July 31--The Republican-controlled State Senate was the target today of widespread criticism led by Gov. Robert B. Meyner for its refusal to confirm the appointment of former Superior Court Judge John O. Bigelow as a member of the board of governors of Rutgers University.

Robert N. White has been elected a vice president of Barrington Associates, Inc., management consulting concern. Mr. White joined it in 1948. He previously had held management posts with Remington Rand and Sperry Gyroscope.

Two new playgrounds, have been opened in the Bronx adjacent to the Cross Bronx Expressway. They are at Watson and Havemeyer Avenue and Virginia and McGraw Avenues. The Department of Parks will operate the centers.
Alexander Trachtenberg has been a publisher of Marxist literature for more than thirty years.
CAIRO, July 31--President Gamal Abdel Nasser said today the nationalization of the Suez Canal would in no way affect Egypt's international obligations.
Company has declared a quarterly dividend at new rate of 30 cents a common share and an extra dividend of 80 cents a share, both payable Sept. 7.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 31 --Union negotiators for 2,600 linemen and mechanical employes of the Long Island Lighting Company agreed here today to am extension of their current contract from midnight tonight on a meeting-to-meeting basis.

The Gustavus and Louise Pfeiffer Research Foundation, 120 Broadway, will receive $8,397,320 from the $10,496,650 residuary estate of Gustavus A. Pfeiffer, according to an estate tax appraisal approved yesterday. Mr. Pfeiffer died in 1953.

James McCutcheon Co., 101year-old department store owned and operated by members of the family that founded it, has sold a controlling interest to Clement V. Conole, former president of the Hearn Department Store. No purchase price was made public, but the sale is said to approximate $1,000,000.
The country's traditional pacesetter on steel prices estimated yesterday that its operating costs would go up nearly $10 a ton in the first year of the new steel wage agreement.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) --Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia arrived today to discuss "some acute problems" with President Eisenhower and top Administration officials.

MARION, Mass., July .31-- A. Howard Fuller's Gesture in Class A and John R. Fales' Whisker in Class C were the winners for the second time on the New York Yacht Club cruise today. The occasion was the 102d annual regatta on Buzzards Bay in close to perfect sailing conditions.
The stock market advanced in July for the second consecutive month despite weakness in international oil shares towards the end of the month resulting from the nationalization of the Suez Canal.
Mrs. Lily Oppenheimer Pforzheimer of Hidden Brook Farm, Purchase, N.Y., wife of Carl H. Pforzheimer, investment banker, died yesterday in Nantucket, Mass. Her age was 71.

BERLIN, July 31 (AP)--West Berlin, a city of more than 2,000,000, was crippled from 9 to 11 A.M. today by a total failure of the electric power system. Street cars and subway trains were halted and thousands of riders were stranded. Generator failure was blamed.
DETROIT, July 31 (UP)--Fred Knorr, a Michigan broadcasting executive, and his ten partners moved a step nearer today to ownership of the Detroit Tigers and Briggs Stadium.
A patrolman alleged to have been friendly with two fur theft defendants found murdered Saturday night was arrested last night on a charge of criminally receiving stolen property.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) --Monty Irvin drove in five runs with a home run, single and double as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 9--4, before 13,788 fans at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.

Bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will visit Sing Sing Prison, Ossining, N.Y., today to collect blood from prisoners. They also will go to the parish hall of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, 838 Brook Avenue, the Bronx.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 31 --Richard McNeill Jr., of the Garden City Country Club won two matches to lead the way into the semi-finals of the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at his home club today.
TRENTON, July 31 (AP)--Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed today a bill to permit thirty-five municipalities to adopt rent control ordinances.

LONDON, July 31--Ranking British and French statesmen believe that the dispute over Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal Company has brought on the most serious international crisis since the Korean war.
CANTON, N.Y.,July 31 (AP)-- The New York member of the Waterfront Commission of New York envisioned tonight the time when the commission could "retire from the scene."

NORFOLK, Va., July 31 (U.P) --The battleship U.S.S. Mississippi joined the mothball fleet today. The vessel, commissioned in 1917, served in both World Wars. For the last ten years she has served as a gunnery training vessel.
GUATEMALA, July 31 (UP)-- A resolution calling for severance of diplomatic relations between Guatemala and Costa Rica was before the Foreign Relations Committee of the Guatemalan Congress today.
BUENOS AIRES, July 34-- Argentina's provisional Government announced tonight that it had proposed negotiation of a three-power pact for defense of the South Atlantic.

Net income of the Diamond Match Company in the first six months this year amounted to $4,317,000 on sales of $66,446,000, according to R.G. Fairburn, president. This compares with earnings of $4,254,000 on sales of $64,243,000 for the same period of 1955.

A 21-year-old Rutgers University second baseman was signed yesterday by the New York Giants organization to a Minneapolis contract and optioned to Johnstown. He is John Brugler from Nutley, N.J., Willard Marshall, former Giant outfielder, was the scout.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 31 (AP)--Prof. Albert Fischer, Danish cancer specialist, died here today. His age was 65.

The four films nominated for the annual Selznick Golden Laurel Award have been announced by Richard Griffith, curator of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library and chairman of the nominating committee.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP)--Franks Lary pitched the Tigers to a four hit 6-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight. Al Kaline and Ray Boone hit home runs for Detroit.

Miss Ann Hunter Atkin was married yesterday at noon to Dr. Howard L. Moscovitz in the Cottage of the Hampshire House by the Rev. Dr. William Berkowitz. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Atkin of Great Neck.
Two New York banks announced moves yesterday that will further broaden the market for American depositary receipts--certificates issued in this country against actual foreign ...
MOBILE, Ala., July 31 (AP)--A divorce action by the wife of Frank Yerby, noted Negro novelist, is on file in Mobile Circuit Court.

A six-month campaign to crack the "age barrier" against unemployed persons between 45 and 60 years old has been started by three private employment agencies in the city, it was announced yesterday by Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner.

Bonds called for redemption in July before maturity totaled $37,883,000, the smallest for any month since last November and the lowest for July since 1951. The total compared with $87,333,000 in June and $106,974,000 in July, 1955.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack has asked District Attorney. Frank S. Hogan for information about the alleged activities of John L. Vesce in connection with a raided bottle club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 --A pair of newcomers from television, Morton Fine, a writer-producer, and David Friedkin, a writer-director, have set a record in making a featurelength picture at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
The Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation, which resulted when Union Bag and Paper Corporation merged with the Camp Manufacturing Company recently, is further diversifying and expanding its operations.
The Grand Union Company's supermarket in East Paterson, N.J., was back in business yesterday under the "big top" eight days after fire had destroyed the regular store.

NEW ORLEANS, July 31 (UP) --A body found in a bayou today was tentatively identified as that of Joe Mandot, top lightweight who fought five world champions in the World War I period. He had been missing since Sunday night.

International Business Machines Corporation has entered into an agreement to borrow $150,000,000 from the Prudential Insurance Company of America on 3 7/8 per cent notes maturing in equal amounts in 1977, 1983 and 1989. There are no sinking fund requirements.

Karl Ehmer, owner of a chain of meat stores throughout the metropolitan area, has purchased from the F.R. C. Company the blockfront facing the Whitestone-Bronx Bridge approach between Farrington Street and Linden Avenue, ...

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--Motorola, Inc., reported today net income of $3,066,207, equal to $1.58 a share, for the six months ended June 30, compared with $2,945,001, equal to $1.52 a share in the 1955 period.
BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 31 --Miss Harriett J. Fletcher and William P. Portrude will be married Oct. 6.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 31 (AP) --The Atlantic City Race course today changed the date of the running of the invitation $100,000 United Nations Handicap from Sept. 8 to Sept. 15.
Sales and earnings of the American Can Company for the three and six months ended with June were the highest for any similar period in its history, William C. Stolk, president, reported.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--Robert Alexander Cole, a legend to Chicago Negroes, was buried today.
LONDON, July 31--Britain made a deal with West Germany here today that will provide competition for the United States in selling certain types of reactors for the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 31 (Reuters)--J.F. Naude, Minister of Health, was today appointed Minister of Finance in succession to Eric Louw. Mr. Louw's resignation as Finance Minister was announced last night. He will continue as Minister for External Affairs.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- Secretary of State Dulles left suddenly today for the London talks on the Suez crisis. He flew off after a ninety-minute session with the President and will be in London in the morning.
DETROIT, July 31--A Michigan engineering educator proposed today that greater emphasis be placed on applied mathematics and science in training engineers.
The harness racing program in the metropolitan area will shift to Yorkers Raceway tonight, when that track begins a record 105-night meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) --The United States Chamber of Commerce asked President Eisenhower today to veto the Social Security bill. It said the measure would encourage disabled persons to rely on Government benefits instead of trying to rehabilitate themselves.

DEAL, N.J., July 31.--Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood took the first-round lead in the Metropolitan Golf Association's Shore tournament today with a 38, 39--77, four over par for the Deal Country Club course.
Title to the fifteen-story apartment house at 910 West End Avenue, southeast corner of West 105th Street, was acquired yesterday by a syndicate of investors headed by Louis Saritsky, attorney.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- A Senate subcommittee was appointed today to study a bill that would grant Congressional consent for a Great Lakes basin compact.

SCARBOROUGH, England, July 31 (AP)--Salem Khaled of Egypt today defeated. Fred Perry, a three-time Wimbledon singles champion, 6-3, 1-6, 6-2, 7-5, in the second round of the professional lawn tennis tournament.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation reported yesterday net income of $3,377,074, or $2.67 a share, for the first six months of 1956. That contrasted to a loss of $610,069 in the same period of 1955.

Construction of new homes in this state in June was 29 per cent below that of June, 1955, continuing the lag of earlier months. The total for the half-year is 25 per cent below the comparable six months of 1955.

The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday its net earnings for the six months ended June 30 at $28,961,410, equal to $3.92 a share, compared with $23,032,871 or $3.13 a share for the 1955 period. Sales increased to $347,639,665 from $308,392,251.

Net earnings of the Sheraton Corporation of America were $6,651,047 or $1.80 a share in the year ended April 30, Ernest Henderson, president, reported yesterday. This compared with $8,874,454, or $2.39 a share in previous year.

MIAMI BEACH, July 31 (AP) --Russ Tague, 130, Davenport, Iowa, won a unanimous tenround decision from Martin Rodriguez, Havara, featherweight, tonight. Rodriguez, who weighed 131 pounds, was floored twice in the fifth.
WASHINGTON, July 31--Incomplete reports from importers of oil indicate that they are making progress in reducing third quarter imports, a high Government official said today.
ATHENS, July 31 (AP)--The Greek Government today awarded to Aristotle Onassis, Greekborn shipping magnate, a twenty-year contract to run Greece's state airline.

Earnings of Merrill Petroleums, Ltd., skyrocketed in the first six months this year. The net profit of $1,358,280 reported yesterday by the oil company was forty times larger than the $33,207 earned in the corresponding half of last year.
Theatre scholarships will be presented tomorrow at the Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Ont., by Vincent Massey, Governor General of Canada, during the third annual Tyrone Guthrie Award ceremonies.

L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, wrote yesterday, to 800 labor union officials urging them to back President Eisenhower and Republican candidates for the Senate and House of Representatives this year.
ITHACA N.Y., July 31 (AP)-- Six hundred and six farmers in New York State have signed up to participate in the 1956 acreage reserve part of the Soil Bank program, it was announced today.
Motty Eitingon, who had made and lost millions as a wholesale fur dealer, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and made his home at the Dover Hotel.
The Stanley Works, New Britain, Conn., began construction yesterday of a plant that is expected to double the company's capacity to produce steel strapping.

Dr. George S. Counts, chairman of the Liberal party, declared yesterday that the Eightyfourth Congress had compiled a "sorry record." Its failures and successes, he said in a statement, were essentially bipartisan.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy is taking steps to combat the rise in juvenile delinquency, which he described Sunday as "alarming."
WASHINGTON, July 31--The Weather Bureau announced today that it was buying thirtynine radar units to provide earlier and more accurate hurricane and tornado warnings.

Public offering of $77,000,000 of Federal Home Loan Banks 3.2 per cent consolidated non-callable notes is being made today by the Federal Home Loan Bank through Everett Smith, fiscal agent, and a nation-wide group of securities dealers. The notes are priced at par.
CREDITS for the first fullfledged college shop go to Lord Taylor, now celebrating the silver anniversary of its first such venture back in 1931.
The American Civil Liberties Union asked the New Jersey Senate yesterday to reconsider its refusal to confirm former Superior Court Judge John O. Bigelow of New Jersey.
All six second-string Communist leaders on trial in Federal Court here on conspiracy charges under the Smith Act were convicted yesterday by a jury of four women and eight men.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The Eisenhower Administration has charted a course toward a liberal foreigh economic policy. Here and there, under domestic political pressure, it has deviated from this course.

LOYOLA, Spain, July 31 (Reuters)--More than 35,000 Roman Catholic pilgrims, including Spain's head of state, General Francisco Franco, celebrat ed here today the 400th anniversary of the death of St. Ignatius of Loyola, founder of the Jesuit Order.

CLEVELAND, July 31--Babe Ruth was a realist. For a man who gave little, if any, time to serious study he possessed an extraordinary insight into such nebulous matters as crowd psychology. He had no illusions on the score of what befell even the greatest when fortune stacked against them.

Before the nation-wide steel strike halted its operations one month ago, the United States Steel Corporation had achieved higher earnings, sales and shipments this year than in any previous first half-year.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Phillips-of 737 Park Avenue on July 25 in Doctors Hospital.
A young twice-defeated and recently orphaned waterfront union challenged the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday to a third representation election among dock workers here.

Onondaga County, N.Y., announced yesterday plans to borrow $3,208,000 in the public market to finance various public improvements. On Aug. 8, the county will receive bids on an issue of serial bonds dated Sept. 1, 1956, and due serially on Sept. 1 from 1957 to 1984.
CHICAGO, July 31--Beaming confidence and affability, Adlai E. Stevenson expressed "gratitude," late today to Senator Estes Kefauver for throwing his support to him.

GALYATETOE, Hungary, July 31 (Reuters)--Leading Protestant churchmen from the United States and Europe said here today that the Christian Church should declare its opposition to continued tests of nuclear weapons.
Four British clergymen yesterday spoke of enthusiasm and efficient organization as characteristic of American church life today.

Extended negotiations for the rights to three books by Giovanni Guareschi have been consummated by David Susskind, Discussions spanning a year resulted in Mr. Susskind's acquiring a three-year option, expiring Sept. 1, 1959, on "The Little World of Don Camillo," "Don Camillo and His Flock" and "Don Camillo's Dilemma."
Fashion's little furry friend next season will be a broadtail jacket. Not always genuine, but always valuable as a wardrobe pepper-upper, this waist-length wrap has slim sleeves and fits snugly.
Eighteen young women will make their debuts on Dec. 27 at the eighth annual Forest Hills Gardens Cotillion which will be held in the Forest Hills Gardens Community House.

PARIS, July 31--The talks in London on seizure of the Suez Canal are regarded here as a test for the North Atlantic alliance. The issue is compared with those raised by the Soviet blockade of Berlin and the Communist attack on South Korea, which tested the willingness of the West to resist aggression.
Mary Martin, who last appeared on television as Peter Pan, has been signed to portray the dumb but triumphant heroine in "Born Yesterday," the Broadway, comedy hit of ten years ago.
PARIS, July 31 (AP)--The speleologists and the archaeologists of France are agog over some drawings in a cave. The Paris papers are poking delighted fun at all of them.
The shock of the Egyptian Government's nationalization of the Suez Canal is nowhere near as great for stockholders of the Suez Canal Company as it is to the users of the company's facilities.
GOODWOOD, England, July 31 (UP)--Matador, a 100-to-8 shot owned by the late John Ferguson, defeated Jack Gerber's Epaulette by a neck today in the $10,122 Stewards Cup race at the Goodwood track.

CONCORD, N.H., July 31 (AP) --J. Felix Daniel, chairman of New Hampshire's delegation to the Democratic National Convention, said tonight "a majority" of the state's eight convention votes would go to Governor Harriman of New York.
ALBANY, July 31.--Fiftyeight Republican candidates for the State Senate will hold a twoday meeting in Buffalo on Friday and Saturday to plan for the fall campaign.

The 1956 Life Master Pairs championship, blue-ribbon pair event of United States tournament contract bridge, yesterday seemed well in the grasp of Alvin Roth, Washington, D.C., and Tobias Stone, of New York City.
Paperboard production in the week ended on Saturday was 4.3 per cent below the level of last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
SIMCOE, Ont., July 31 (AP)--A body found on Lake Erie's north shore Sunday was identified today as that of Gordon Pollock, 28 years old.

Another Congressional session has come and gone without authorizing development of electric power from Niagara Falls. The failure to complete action this year was a bitter disappointment to New York State, ...
Earnings of Food Fair Stores, Inc., in the fiscal year ended with April rose 16.7 per cent on a sales gain of 15.9 per cent with new highs in virtually every phase of operations.

When a contestant appeared in the 1895 United States amateur golf championship with a billiard cue in his bag there was no consternation among the officials. And they remained calm when the player, Richard Peters of Newport, R.I., proceeded to use the cue as a putter.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday sizable gains in the sales of electricity, gas and steam for the six and twelve months ended June 30. But net income for the six months trailed slightly behind the year-earlier level.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 31 --The Government gazette announced today three more blocks of concessions of about 10,000 ...

WASHINGTON, July 31--A "Women's Showcase" has been announced for the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month. Details were given today by Mrs. Katie Louchheim, director of women's activities for the National Committee.

CHICAGO, July 31 (UP)--The motorcycle has gained a new lease on life because of the Democratic National Convention. Forty-two that were crated and headed for oblivion have been restorted to duty. After the convention they will be recrated and traded in on three-wheel vehicles.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Harold E. Stassen asserted today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon would cost President Eisenhower "millions of votes" if they ran together this year.

RANGOON, Burma, July 31-- Military sources said tonight Chinese Communist troops had occupied about 1,000 square miles of Burma's northern territory after clashes with Burmese forces. Some casualties were reported.
The Suez Canal Company is notifying shipping lines all over the world that it can no longer be responsible for safe operation of the canal.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 31 (UP)--Former President Harry S. Truman said today that Senator Estes Kefauver must have thought he "had no chance" for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Robert A. Futterman, New York realty investor, has purchased the Insurance Exchange Building in Sioux City, Iowa. The structure, nine stories high, is on the northeast corner of Pierce and Seventh Streets. Most of it is occupied by insurance companies.

Reassured by international moves to cope with the Egyptian crisis, the stock market moved ahead yesterday on a broad front. More than half the 1,177 issues traded advanced-- 619, with 326 lower and 232 unchanged--and The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks set, a historic high.

MANCHESTER, England, July 31 (Reuters)--Jim Laker, Surrey's off-spinner bowler, today set a world record by taking nineteen wickets in the fourth cricket test to help England beat Australia by an inning and 170 runs.
JERSEY CITY, July 31--The decision to return Jackie Robinson to the line-up paid handsome dividends to the Brooklyn Dodgers tonight.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation chalked up new records in sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30, according to the semi-annual report issued for publication today.

Stockholders of the Universal Match Corporation of St. Louis approved yesterday an increase in the authorized common stock to 1,000,000 shares from 500,000 as part of a program designed to provide for the acquisition of other companies.
JACQUET RIVER, N.B., July 31 (AP)--Four children died today in a fire that destroyed their home in Mitchell Settlement, a lumbering village.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) --A four-engine United Air Lines freight transport plane landed at International Airport without mishap today after the pilot had reported his alarm system indicated a blaze in an engine.

DETROIT, July 31 (AP)--Leo Kiely, a left-hander who has been unable to give the Red Sox effective hurling over a sustained period, today was optioned to Boston's Pacific Coast League farm at San Francisco.
One of the characteristic features of the Soviet regime under Stalin was its creation of what George Orwell so felicitously called "unpersons."

Sperry Rand Corporation expects sales to reach $1,000,000,000 a year within the next five years. General Douglas MacArthur, chairman, so informed the stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington Del. He added that sales this year would be about $775,000,000.

The world's shipbuilding yards are expected to produce, 5,000, 000 gross tons of new merchant vessels this year. The production would just about equal the 1954 record total for a peacetime year, Walter L. Green, chairman of the board and president of the American Bureau of Shipping, said yesterday.

AWAY from midtown, and off the beaten track, is a roomy Chinese restaurant, the Great Shanghai, at 2685 Broadway (103d Street). Despite its unprepossessing appearance, it is an excellent place to entertain people with a serious interest in food.
Joey Giambra, Buffalo middleweight, and Rocky Castellani of Luzerne, Pa., will complete training today for their scheduled ten-round fight Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 31 (AP)--Robert Folley of Utica today won the New York State Junior Chamber of Commerce junior golf tournament. He scored 77, 79--156 in the twoday, thirty-six-hole medal-play test at the Irondequoit Country Club.
ALBANY, July 31--Senator Estes Kefauver's withdrawal from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination will have no effect on the "sendoff" dinner for Governor Harriman ...
CAIRO, July 31 (AP)--Egypt's Middle East News Agency reports four Arab states--Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia and Jordan--will hold a meeting soon "to discuss joint petroleum interests."
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- The Air Force announced today the arrest of an airman who allegedly had leaked information that the May 21 hydrogen bomb had missed its test target in the Pacific.

Things are happening fast in Peru, where Manuel Prado y Ugarteche has assumed the Presidency he won in a free election. The new Administration has cleared Peruvian jails of political prisoners and it has restored the legal status of APRA. The latter step is likely to prove by far the more important.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., July 31-- Mr. and Mrs. W. Milton McCoy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Carolyn McCoy, to Christopher Wright. His parents are Quincy Wright, Professor of International Law at the University of Chicago, and Mrs. Wright of Chicago. The wedding is planned for September.

BONN, Germany, July 31--A central depot for guided missiles has been established by the United States armed forces at Zweibruecken in the RhinelandPalatinate. Some of the special weapons and new technical equipment were shown to German reporters at the new depot today.

PARIS, July 31--Coordination of communications and weather forecasts for Antarctic operations during the International Geophysical Year 1957-58 was outlined here today at a twelvenation scientific conference.
The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday that its net income was $48,615,304 in the first half of this year, compared with $44,310,167 in the like period last year.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., July 31 (UP)--Col. Walter C. Heinel was accused at a general courtmartial today of refusing to pay for his breakfast.
The streets of New York may not be paved with gold, but a few thousand peoph poked about midtown Manhattan yesterday searching for a scrap of paper worth $1,000.

A syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will offer for public subscription today a new issue of $25,000,000 of preferred stock of the El Paso Natural Gas Company. The offering consists of 250,000 shares of $100 par value 5.5 per cent cumulative dividend stock priced at $100 a share.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 31 (AP) --Two of nineteen young mountain climbers who fell into a crevasse Sunday remained in serious condition today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford says there is a marked tendency in this country to overestimate Communist air power, missiles and other military strength.

LONDON, July 31--A rally in oil shares, ascribed in part to American buying, brought allaround improvement to the stock market here today. Gains among industrials were generally limited to a few pence although several issues recouped yesterday's losses.
The Vanadium Corporation of America achieved record sales and earnings in the first half of 1956, according to a report issued yesterday by W.C. Keeley, president.

AKRON, Ohio, July 31 (AP)-- The General Tire and Rubber Company and the Seiberling Rubber Company said today prices on some of their tires and tubes would be raised 2 to 3 per cent tomorrow. They said labor and material costs had made the increase necessary. The B.F. Goodrich Company raised its prices a similar amount yesterday.

MISSOULA, Mont., July 31 (AP)--Northern Pacific Railway crews labored today to clear twenty-nine shattered freight cars blocking both of the road's main line tracks. The cars were derailed at Clinton, Mont., eighteen miles east of here, last night. Cause of the derailment was not determined.

PARIS, July 31--Jacques Grifte's elegant collection centers around a grand old fashion, the shirt. Americans, of course, feel that they have a monopoly on the shirt idea, but no more. Fashions today are international, and a good fashion is good anywhere.

The appointment of Miss Lucyle Hook as dean of the American College for Girls in Istanbul, Turkey, has been announced by Barnard College, where she is associate professor of English.
The Peabody Coal Company had a net profit of $3,040,796, or 47 cents a share, on sales of $47,655,442 in the six months ended June 30, the concern reported yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 --Three hundred years ago Capt. Daniel Patrick was appointed military commandant to protect this colonial settlement and an island offshore from marauding Petuquapaen Indians.
Two new films open at firstrun theatres today.
Under Secretary of State Herbert Hoover Jr. has been chosen as the 1956 recipient of the Hoover Medal, named for his father, former President Hoover.

OSLO, Norway, July 31 (AP)-- Norway's chief Olympic hope in the javelin, 23-year Egil Danielsen, registered a toss of 82.15 meters (269 feet 6 1/3 inches) today, in an international meet. Only three longer heaves have recorded.

Sales of Alco Products, Inc., producer of railway and industrial equipment, in the six months ended June 30 rose to $70,825,000 from $57,075,000 in the first half of 1955, Perry T. Egbert, president, announced in a report to stockholders yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 11 to 26 points (55 cents to $1.30 a bale) yesterday. The close was near the best levels of the day.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--A group of States' Rights advocates today planned a convention in early September "for people who have no political home."

NEW ORLEANS, July 31 (UP) --Gill Robb Wilson, president of the Air Force Association, said today he would ask the group to call for the transfer of all air arms to one command. The association's convention opens tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31.-- The Camp, a destroyer escort converted to a Navy enemy-warning ship, was recommissioned at the Philadelphia Naval Base today. As a floating radar installation, the Camp will be assigned to sport surface vessels, aircraft and submarines.

TOKYO, July 31.--Several thousand Japanese employed at a United States Air Force base near here struck today in protest against the dismissal of twentytwo union members as "security risks."

ACCRA, Gold Coast, July 31 --A policeman's devotion to duty and the reluctance of honorable members of the opposition coalition to walk to work got the new Gold Coast Legislative Assembly off to a somewhat confused start today.

TRENTON, Aug. 3--There appeared to be a strong possibility tonight that John O. Bigelow would be confirmed by the Republican-controlled State Senate on Thursday as a member of the board of governors of Rutgers University.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Secretary of State Dulles said tonight it was "inadmissible" for the Suez Canal to be "exploited by one country for highly selfish purposes."

WITH the delightful inconsistency that is part of summer, many a mother these days is letting her small-fry disport themselves in water the family dog wouldn't be allowed to drink in any other season. Unsanitary backyard wading pools are hardly a major public health hazard.
LONDON, Aug. 3--Suez developments again dominated sentiment today on the stock markets. Most local common stocks weakened slightly Canadian issues were in good demand.

BUFFALO, Aug. 3--Thirty Republican State Senators laid plans today to capture four additional seats in the fall campaign and thus provide a majority large enough to override vetoes by Governor Harriman.

VANCOUVER, Aug. 3 (Canadian Press)--British Columbia's huge forest products concern, MacMillan and Bloedel, Ltd., reported today a net profit of $13,221,209 for the nine-month period ended June 30. The figure was $587,593 lower than that reported in the same period last year.
WARSAW, Aug. 3--The leadership of the United Workers (Communist) party has ordered the transfer of a "substantial" part of Poland's defense industry to the production of consumer goods.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--Harold E. Stassen continued today his campaign-by-press-conference for the nomination of Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts as Vice President on the Republican ticket.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 3--Adolph L. Simon, a partner in Simon Brothers, a large New York building and real estate investment firm, died here today of a heart attack in Monmouth Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old.
Growing cooperation between steel companies in the United States and in West Germany is adding Significant new strength to the European country's industry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (U.P.)--Dick Mayer, a golf professional from St. Petersburg, Fla., solved Tam o' Shanter's soaked fairways and greens for a 69 today to take the midway lead in the $25,000 "all-American" golf with a score of 138.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)-- By a 98 per cent majority, shareholders of the Capital Transit Company today voted to sell the company for $13,500,000 and follow financier Louis E. Wolfson into new and unspecified enterprises.

The new issue market for prime corporate fixed-income securities is still up against heavy weather. The indifference of big institutional holders of life insurance and pension savings to buying new issues is probably due in some measure to reports of several large financing deals in negotiation.

A charity organization had to use a ticket broker to get rid of 109 left-over tickets for the musical hit "My Fair Lady." This was testified yesterday at a Department of Licenses hearing into the brokerage activities of Sylvia Siegler, whose license has been suspended.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 3--A comprehensive work conference to help the South assess its capabilities and needs in shaping a pioneer program to promote nuclear energy development on a regional basis neared completion today.

The Coast Guard yesterday ended its investigation of the collision between the tanker San Jose II and the freighter Fairisle. It occurred July 23 in a heavy fog off Ambrose Lightship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--More Democratic convention votes appeared today to be swinging toward Adlai E. Stevenson. Leaders in three favorite-son states indicated that their delegations might swing to the 1952 nominee on the first ballot in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (U.P.)-- President Eisenhower signed today a "second chance" $2,100,000,000 military construction bill. He took no note of the fact that it imposed some strings on the huge program.

An apartment building for thirty families at 2083 Creston Avenue, north of Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 54-60 Moylan Place Corporation to the Gelfman-Creston Building Corporation for investment. It is assessed at $110,000. The deal was negotiated by Ber ley Co., brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3--Yugoslavia agreed today to accept help from the Soviet Union and Communist East Germany in the development of her newborn aluminum industry.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 3 (AP) --The bells of nearly 100 churches here will toll for three minutes Monday at the start of the funeral of Albert Woolson, last Union Army veteran of the Civil War, who died yesterday at the age of 109.
