After four days of unbroken advance, stocks took a breather yesterday. Before they paused, however, both The New York Times industrial and combined averages had reached new historic highs.

The only non-claimer on the Jamaica racing program yesterday was the seventh race, a six furlong sprint for fillies and mares. It was won by the fourth choice, the $13.40-for-$2 Harbash, who is owned by Gerald S. Colella.

Gildo Romano, a Queens delicatessen man who has had enough of stores and the city, lost his chance yesterday to fulfill a dream of buying a farm. A hold-up man got away with the $1,500 he had saved for a down payment.
An air-conditioning unit weighing more than two tons was gingerly hauled up the Fortyfourth Street side of the Sheraton-Astor Hotel yesterday afternoon to the great entertainment of Broadway crowds.

John Adams Kingsbury, chairman of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He would have been 80 years old Aug. 30.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Treasury Department announced today it would offer $3,000,000,000 in tax anticipation certificates on Monday. HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 --William A. Wellman will make his long-projected film about the Lafayette Escadrille for Warner Brothers. The director was a member of the group of American volunteer fliers who served with the French Army in World War I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--A Government expert testified today that the civil airways system had no responsibility for the collision of two airliners over the Grand Canyon. He said they were flying in uncontrolled air space.

Congressional action broadening the powers of the Interstate Sanitation Commission was hailed yesterday by Dr. Leonard Greenburg, City Commissioner of Air Pollution Control. The commission now has the authority to make studies of air pollution.
The first long-range DC-7C delivered to a foreign airline was accepted yesterday by Scandinavian Airlines System at Santa Monica.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Aug. 12--Dr. Frederic Carl Sell, Professor of German and former chairman of the German Department at Mount Holyoke College, died in Holyoke Memorial Hospital last night of a heart attack.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 11-- A tour of this crown colony gives an indication of the preparations by the British for possible military action in the Suez Canal crisis.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12--Hamilton Richardson completed his conquest of the Australian team today to win the Eastern grass court tennis championship.

Alex Rothenberg, controller of the United Jewish Appeal, fundraising organization for needy Jews throughout the world, died Saturday of a heart attack at Lake Mahopac, N.Y., where he had been vacationing. His age was 77. He lived at 161 West Eighty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles emphasized in a meeting with Congressional leaders today their hope for a peaceful solution of the Suez Canal dispute.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12--Banished by an umpire for the seventh time this season, his freshman year as a manager, Bill Rigney was spared the misery of watching his Giants lose the second game, 11--3, to the Pirates at Forbes Field today. He had seen and suffered enough in the opener, which the Corsairs also won, 3--2, behind Vernon Law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Senator Stuart Symington, a dark horse for the Democratic Presidential nomination, declared today he was not an active candidate, but acted as if he would like to be under the lightning when it struck.
Four hundred followers of a nocturnal radio satirist who is about to be, as he put it, "canned," gathered in Manhattan last night "in a final pitiful show of non-strength and disorganization."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12--Rosalind Russell will star as Mrs. Perle Mesta in a motionpicture story about the colorful life of the noted Washington hostess and former diplomat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--The fall schedule of twelve International trade fairs in which the United States will participate was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks.
More than $300,000,000 worth of Federal surplus property is available free for Civil Defense use in New York State, the State Civil Defense Commission said yesterday.
New York finds itself host this morning to 10,000 GreekAmericans. They are members of the order of Ahepa, the American Hellenic Educational Progressive Association.
PARIS, Aug. 12--The Bank of France, in its annual report just released, expressed confidence in the national capacity to overcome inflation.
Restrictive insurance measures applied to the movement of world trade are attacked in a statement issued for publication today by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12-- A few voices of doubt are beginning to be heard in the Arab chorus that has been encouraging President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt to defy the West over the Suez Canal crisis.
HAVANA, Aug. 12--A group of youths attempting to hold an anti-Government demonstration in Luyano suburb today was dispersed by the police. Several young men were arrested.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12--When Foreign Minister Dmitri T. Shepilov arrives at the London conference on the Suez canal this week he will be confronted by a ten-year-old Soviet demand for effective international control of the strategic waterway.
WHEN most of today's parents went to school, geography in the early grades was taught largely in terms of the differences among countries and their people.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was pictured by a leading House Republican today as the key to Republican chances of winning control of the House and Senate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Averell Harriman's campaign manager contended today that former President Harry S. Truman's endorsement had brought the New York Governor the support of at least 100 additional delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Most of these delegates have only one-half vote.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP)--Ted Kroll threaded his way through the traffic of an estimated 61,000 fans today to score a closing 66 for first prize of $50,000 in Tam o' Shanter's "world championship" of golf.

The Yankees spent a long and profitable afternoon at the Stadium yesterday. They grabbed two games from the Orioles and Mickey Mantle edged a little closer to the Babe Ruth record of sixty by belting homer No. 41.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--One of the best-read books among State Department and diplomatic officials concerned with the Suez crisis is by Gamal Abdel Nasser, the Egyptian President.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22--If the television folk can produce blue politicians by 1960 their conquest of the national political conventions will be complete.
Thirty-three New York backers of Adlai E. Stevenson and ninety-nine supporters of Governor Harriman left by air yesterday afternoon for the Democratic. National Convention in Chicago.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug, 12 (AP)-- Hurricane Betsy struck Puerto Rico, then whipped west-northwest over the Atlantic Ocean tonight in the general direction of south Florida, 800 miles away.
THE late Dwight Davis, donor of the most famous of all tennis cups, and five other "immortals" of the courts will be enshrined this week in the Tennis Hall of Fame.

The public little comprehends how much police strength has been lost in New York City through shortening of the police work week. In 1932 our patrolmen were working fifty-two hours a week. They are now working forty-two.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--The Democratic National Convention convenes tomorrow with prospects for a fierce, perhaps protracted, struggle over its Presidential nomination.
The confirmation by the New Jersey Senate of the appointment of John O. Bigelow to the board of governors of Rutgers University is a victory for common sense and good judgment.

Customs collections during July aggregated almost $35,000,000 from steamship and airport activities here, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, said yesterday. Shipping accounted for more than $31,000,000 of the total.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told Harry S. Truman today it was time to let the young folks run the country.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8--Carmine Gerard De Sapio repre sents a new type of big city political boss. Instead of manipulating candidates and officeholders from behind the scenes and avoiding publicity as much as possible, he courts publicity and the limelight.
The hottest weather since early this summer sent thousands out of the city yesterday to near-by beaches or merely for a drive in the country.

LONDON, Aug. 12--The case of a man who committed suicide seventy years ago because of disbelief that he had discovered a Dead Sea scroll has been reopened at the British Museum by an American scholar.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Democratic planners wrote into the farm plank today subsidy proposals that smacked of the Brannan Plan.
Five six-family houses and one eight-family house at 409 to 421 Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Madow Corporation to an investor in a deal negotiated by Saul Siller, broker.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (U.P.)--Dr. Mincho Neichev, Bulgarian Foreing Minister, died last night after a prolonged illness, the Sofia radio has announced in a broadcast heard here today.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12--District Attorney George W. Percy Jr. assumed supervision today of an inquiry into two automobile accidents that took eight lives Saturday night.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--New Jersey Democratic leaders unanimously urged Gov. Robert B. Meyner today to permit his name to go before the convention as a favorite-son candidate for the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The Government is taking steps to remove the hardiest conversation-piece-of the returning traveler--crabbing about customs.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)--The St. Louis Cardinals and the Chicago Cubs played to a scoreless tie in nine innings of a second game of a double-header before 26,567 today. The Cubs won the opener, 6--2.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12--The steel industry last week was having a tough time getting its operations toward a higher level following the end of the nationwide strike.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)-- Adlai E. Stevenson forged past the 500 mark tonight in the Associated Press tabulation of indicated first-ballot strength for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

Logical persons, such as the late John Locke, the French Encyclopedists and the reasonable gentlemen who sweated out the Constitution of the United States, would never have dreamed of setting up anything as irrational as a Presidential nominating convention.
Modern man has adopted an ethic of "slickness" that is undermining society, the leader of the Negro boycott of buses in Montgomery, Ala., declared here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--On the eve of the quadrennial rites with which the Democrats choose their man for the Presidency, these are certainties:

Samuel Reshevsky and William Lombardy played twentyfive moves to a draw in the second encounter of their six-game match at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. The first game, adjourned Thursday night after forty-one moves with Reshevsky a pawn ahead, has not yet been resumed.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 12-- Tom Floyd-Jones' Quincy Adams17 Blitzen; Donald Mackenzie's Black Arrow in the International Class and Bill Wilson's Lightning Kachia turned in top showings as the joint invitation regatta of the Noroton Yacht Club and Stamford Yacht Club ended on Long Island Sound today.
Fair warning for the common cold: Close to $5,000,000 will be spent by Grove Laboratories, St. Louis drug and toiletries concern, to advertise its sniffle-andsneeze medicines from next month to May.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota pushed his campaign for the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination today with a call for understanding of Southern problems on the race issue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) --The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that the number of banks in the United States declined in 1955 for the eighth straight year.
Activity last week in the steamship charter market was at a virtual standstill. Yet the small amount of business done pushed up the over-all cargo rate index.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 12--Hungary has discarded the Rakosi plan, which sought to make the country industrially self-sufficient.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 12 Dick Sykes of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club completed a sweep of the Western Long Island Sound district Lightning Class championship regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 12--More than 500,000 German Protestants, massed around a giant steel cross, were exhorted today to "keep the faith" in face of all temptation and oppression by materialist "systems."
THE networks offered previews of their coverage of the Democratic National Convention yesterday afternoon. The viewer at home surely is going to have an armchair seat at Chicago.

Carl Furillo hit two home runs and Pee Wee Reese and Randy Jackson one apiece at Ebbets Field yesterday, making it fairly easy for the Dodgers to beat Robin Roberts and the Phillies, 7-3, for Roger Craig's eleventh victory.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y. Aug. 12--The New York Athletic Club won seven races today and successfully defended its New York Rowing Association metropolitan team championship. The regatta was held over the Pelham Bay Lagoon course off Travers Island.

HONG KONG, Aug. 12--The Asian press directed heavy criticism today at the United States for denying American newsmen the right to visit Communist China. Reports from Burma, Thailand and China accused the State Department of hypocrisy and of attempting to screen world news from the American public.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 12-- Added to the uneasiness regarding Suez developments last week was concern caused by Indonesia's renunciation of her debts to Holland. This breach of what has been considered the voluntarily accepted round-table agreements of 1949 has astonished Holland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Following is the text of a statement issued by the White House today following President Eisenhower's meeting with Congressional leaders on the Suez Canal situation:

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--The feature of grain trading here last week was a strong rally in wheat. Reacting from a midweek decline, it advanced to the highest prices on the crop for al deliveries except September.
There has been a change of directors for "The Happiest Millionaire," the forthcoming Kyle Crichton play suggested by the book, "My Philadelphia Father."
CRACOW, Poland, Aug. 12-- A story of murder being unfolded in a Cracow courtroom has captured the attention of all Poland.

There were some unusual aspects in connection with yesterday's Presidential Executive-Congressional conference on the Suez Canal problem. First was its timing. The London Suez conference will open on Thursday. Meanwhile, the Democratic National Convention will open today.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--Maurice Trintignant of France, driving a Ferrari, today won the Swedish Grand Prix. The victory enabled the Italian Ferrari works to win the 1956 world sports car manufacturers' championship.

Faith was discussed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. James W. Clarke of the Princeton Theological Seminary. He was guest preacher at the 11 A.M. service in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 12 --The mine disaster at Marcinelle last week has produced a new set of problems for officials already troubled by the Belgian economic dilemma known as the coal industry.
Cotton prices in the domestic market last week continued to climb upward, the New York Cotton Exchange reported over the week-end.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--It is logical to conjecture that the Soviet Union would endorse international supervision of the Suez Canal if, in exchange, the West accepts the principle of similar control over other strategic waterways. This is likely to be Moscow's asking price.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UP) --The Bureau of Mines has developed a revolutionary method for separating tantalum and columbium, two vital metals that have been as hard to split as Siamese twins.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 --Ernest Lehman's novelette, "The Comedian," described as a scathing profile of an anonymous television personality, is close to being purchased by Martin Manulis for presentation on the new "Playhouse 90" series.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP)--Frank Bolling blasted a three-run homer and a double that enabled Billy Hoeft and the Detroit Tigers to defeat Chicago's Billy Pierce, 5--2, today.
The Bureau of the Census, toying expertly a decade ago with the probable future population of the United States, came up with an estimate of a little under 150,000,000 for the year 1955.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) --The International Cotton Advisory Committee today estimated the free world cotton carryover on Aug. 1 at $21,900,000 bales, an increase of 1,400,000 bales from last year.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 12-- The rabbinate was frustrated tonight in its attempt to stymie the introduction of Reform services in Jerusalem.
CAIRO, Aug. 12--Egypt spurned today the West's invitation to the London conference on the Suez Canal, describing it as a conspiracy of "collective colonialism."
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--The Truman "government-in-exite" began an organized effort today to build up delegate support for Governor Harriman.

LONDON, Aug. 12--Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's statement rejecting an invitation to Egypt to attend the London conference on the Suez Canal. The statement was broadcast in Arabic by the Cairo radio.
Net earnings of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation for the first six months this year edged up to a new high of $18,677,437 from the previous peak of $18,383,166 in the initial half of last year.

A week ago today the United States Steel Corporation, with the thirty-four-day strike of the industry's 650,000 employes past, announced it was raising its prices by an average of $8.50 a ton. Other steel companies later followed the general pattern set by Big Steel in this general upward revision of prices.
Issues in the war between East Side teen-age gangs will be put to mediation tonight in an effort to prevent the conflict from spreading into city-wide violence.

THE original constitution and bylaws of the Society of Tammany, or the Columbian Order, written almost 170 years ago, have just come into the hands of Charles Hamilton, dealer in autographs here in town. Sheer accident brought the document to him on the eve of the Democratic Convention.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12-- President Eisenhower sounded a call to arms today to "Republicans everywhere." He urged tireless and devoted work in the precincts, the counties and the states.
The following dispatch is by David Chipp, a British correspondent of Reuters, who has just completed a 5,000-mile round trip from Peiping to the northwest of China.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug.13-- The Diamond Jubilee tournament of the Newport Casino started today with an entry led by Kenneth Rosewall of Australia and Hamilton Richardson of Westfield, N.J.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 13 (UP)-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told the fifty-seventh national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today that "we have adequate military strength to meet and defeat any aggressor in the world."
LONDON, Aug. 13--Trading volume was small and price movements insignificant on the stock market here today. Generally trading was steadier than on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UP) --Representatives of the Reynolds Metals Company and the United Steelworkers of America broke off negotiations tonight when they failed to reach a contract settlement of their twoweek-old strike.

Jerry Luedee, a New Haven (Conn.) middleweight, and Willie Troy of Washington fought a draw in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The Hospital Council of Greater New York reported yesterday that, as of last Jan. 1, the city had 50,880 hospital beds in 166 voluntary, municipal and proprietary hospitals. This was a net decline of 375 beds since Jan. 1, 1955.
GENEVA, Aug. 13--What promised to be a rather obscure little United Nations conference on the abolition of slavery has turned into quite a big show with sharp political overtones.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13--The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a new rule designed to provide more widespread dissemination of information on new securities offerings.
TOKYO, Aug. 13 (Reuters)-- Rusty railroad tracks, empty Warehouses and silent shipping berths have become symbols of the decline of Yokohama as an international port.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13-- The chairman of the Republican Committee on Resolutions said today that President Eisenhower and former President Herbert Hooves favored a "brief, fortright and honest" platform.

A new British airliner, forerunner of a model that will start the switch to jet-age planes in transatlantic service, arrived here yesterday to woo American customers.

Forty-six gamblers walked out of Felony Court yesterday after what court officials termed the largest mass hearing in that court's history.
The major league pension committee yesterday put the finishing touches on a new schedule of benefits to be submitted for approval by the sixteen player representatives next Monday in Cincinnati.

Yonkers has designated Aug. 23 for the sale of $6,421,000 of bonds dated Aug. 1, 1956, and due serially on Aug. 1 from 1957 to 1976. The money will be used to finance various public improvements.

A meteorology tower recently erected on the Whitney Bird Hall of the American Museum of Natural History is sending weather messages to the Hayden Planetarium. They show in sight-reading dials air pressure, outside temperature, wind direction and wind velocity.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 10--The Government of President Carlos Castillo Armas will not allow the return of Guatemalan newsmen who were expelled from the country after the political disorders in late June.

ON the flagged terrace of Walgrove Snood's house at Debenture Bay the Sunday talk drifted lazily from political conventions to baseball to summer reading and travel. A breeze rolled the boats in the harbor slowly. The setting sun, Kim Carruthers thought, looked like a glowing blurb behind the houses on the Connecticut shore.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 13-- Transportation and administrative units of the British Army of the Rhine are being moved from West Germany to strengthen the strategic reserves in Britain.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 24 points (25 cents to $1.20 a bale) yesterday. The 1956 crop deliveries showed the greatest strength. March, July and far October and December contracts established new highs for the life of the contracts.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday fell, to 1,730,000 shares as prices registered the lowest level since last Monday and the lowest close since July 30. Last Friday's volume was 2,035,650 shares.

Bernard Shaw is the subject of two biographies scheduled for publication this season.
Contract awards for future construction in the thirty-seven eastern states in July were 5 per cent below July of last year, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
Secretary Dulles leaves for London this afternoon on one of the most important missions of his career: namely, to try again for a just and peaceful settlement of the Suez Canal problem.
Seven winter and spring cruises to the Caribbean have been scheduled by the HollandAmerica Line.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13-- Senator William F. Knowland said on the White House doorstep today that the Republican party would renominate Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
BOSTON, Aug, 13--A fifth day of examining veniremen failed today to produce an ecceptable juror for the trial of eight men accused of the $1,219,000 Brink's, Inc., robbery.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13--Senator Estes Kefauver was pressed into service today to hold former Kefauver delegates in line for Adlai E. Stevenson.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 13-- Walking a beagle hound helped put an amateur astronomer on the track of a globe that maps the stars at all times, seasons, latitudes and longitudes.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 13--Gus Salerno and Elliott Oshins of Hampshire and Mickey Homa and John McNulty, Westchester, turned in the best performances at the Westchester Professional Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13-- Mme. Slavko Grouitch, widow of the first Yugoslav Minister to the United States, died today at Georgetown University Hospital. She had been a patient since July 28. Her age was 75.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) --The United States acted today to set in motion a plan by President Eisenhower for Western Hemisphere cooperation in developing nuclear electric power and other mutual benefit programs.

An inspection yesterday of three streets in Manhattan that were heavily littered in May, 1954, indicated conditions had generally improved. The streets were by no means clean, but the battle is perhaps half won.
PEIPING, Aug. 1--Along routes followed by camel caravans through the centuries, and at times in the steps of Marco Polo, a new railway is being pushed toward Urumchi and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13-- The Justice Department took a step today toward righting an injustice that arose out of World War II.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 13-- Whether the Marblehead syndicate's Quixotic earned selection today as the United States Olympic nominee in the international 5.5-meter class must wait until tomorrow because of a protest.
GALILEE, R. I., Aug. 13-- About 335 deep sea an glers gathered here tonight prepared to give their all for their clubs early tomorrow in the beginning of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug.13--The prototype of the atomic reactor in the submarine Nautilus has just completed a 1,600-hour nonstop full power run.

MADRID, Aug. 7--The sanctuary where Generalissimo Francisco Franco and some of the major figures of the Spanish Civil War are to be buried is at last reaching completion after fifteen years of hard, driving work.

Miss Kathleen Howard, former Metropolitan Opera contralto, motion-picture actress and magazine editor, died Wednesday evening in Hollywood, Calif., after a long illness. She had been an invalid for seven years. Her age was 77.

HONG KONG, Aug. 16 (UP)-- The Most Rev. Ambrose Pinger, a Roman Catholic Bishop who arrived here from Shanghai after five years in Chinese Communist prisons, said today there had been no progress toward freedom of religion in Red China.

AMERICAN Tobacco's move to its new headquarters at 150 East 42d Street is the company's first address change in 56 years. Its former address--111 Fifth Avenue, at 18th Street--evokes memories of brand names which granddad once knew as well as he knew his own. In fact, the story of the nation's No. 1 tobacco firm can be told almost entirely in terms of its brands.
